    The text below is an excerpt from a 10-K report. You must extract specific information and return it in a structured format.
    
    CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS:
    1. AVOID DUPLICATES: Never include duplicate items in any list
    2. BE CONCISE: Keep each item brief and to the point
    3. VALIDATE: Each piece of information must be explicitly stated in the text, do not make assumptions
    4. FORMAT: All fields must be lists, even if empty or single item
    
    Examples of GOOD responses:
    - Products: ["Google Search", "Google Cloud", "Android"]
    - Address: ["1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA 94043"]
    - Phone: ["+1 650-253-0000"]
    
    Examples of BAD responses (avoid these):
    - Duplicates: ["Google Search", "Search by Google", "Google Search Engine"]
    - Too verbose: ["Google Search is a web search engine that allows users to search the World Wide Web..."]
    - Made up data: Do not include information unless explicitly found in the text
    
    Please extract:
    1. Products and Services: List unique products/services (max 10 items)
    2. Risk Factors: List unique, critical risks (max 10 items)
    3. IRS Employer ID Number: List any EIN found
    4. Company Address: List primary address of the company
    5. Earnings Per Share (Basic): List basic EPS figure
    6. Net Income: List net income figure

    Text from the 10-K report:

Yes  ☒    No  ☐ \nIndicate by check mark whether the registrant has submitted electronically every Interactive Data File required to be submitted pursuant to Rule 405 of Regulation S-T \n(§ 232.405 of this chapter) during the preceding 12 months (or for such shorter period that the registrant was required to submit such files).    Yes  ☒    No  ☐\nIndicate by check mark whether the registrant is a large accelerated filer, an accelerated filer, a non-accelerated filer, a smaller reporting company, or an emerging growth\ncompany. See the definitions of "large accelerated filer," "accelerated filer," "smaller reporting company," and "emerging growth company" in Rule 12b-2 of the\nExchange Act.\nLarge accelerated filer ☒ Accelerated filer ☐\nNon-accelerated filer ☐ Smaller reporting company ☐\nEmerging growth company ☐\nIf an emerging growth company, indicate by check mark if the registrant has elected not to use the extended transition period for complying with any new or revised \nfinancial accounting standards provided pursuant to Section 13(a) of the Exchange Act. ☐ \nIndicate by check mark whether the registrant has filed a report on and attestation to its management\'s assessment of the effectiveness of its internal control over financial \nreporting under Section 404(b) of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (15 U.S.C. 7262(b)) by the registered public accounting firm that prepared or issued its audit report.  ☒ \nIndicate by check mark whether the registrant is a shell company (as defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act).    Yes  ☐    No   ☒ \nThe aggregate market value of the voting and non-voting stock held by non-affiliates of the registrant as of June 30, 2021, the last business day of the registrant\'s most \nrecently completed second fiscal quarter, was $857 billion based upon the closing price reported for such date on the Nasdaq Global Select Market. On January 28, 2022, \nthe registrant had 2,309,080,018 shares of Class A common stock and 412,861,942 shares of Class B common stock outstanding.\nDOCUMENTS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE\nPortions of the registrant\'s Proxy Statement for the 2022 Annual Meeting of Stockholders are incorporated herein by reference in Part III of this Annual Report on Form \n10-K to the extent stated herein. Such proxy statement will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission within 120 days of the registrant\'s fiscal year ended\nDecember 31, 2021. '), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 2}, page_content="Meta Platforms, Inc. \nForm 10-K \nTABLE OF CONTENTS \nPage\nNote About Forward-Looking Statements 3\nLimitations of Key Metrics and Other Data 4\nPART I\nItem 1. Form 10-K Summary 114\nSignatures\n2\n"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 3}, page_content='NOTE ABOUT FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS\nThis Annual Report on Form 10-K contains forward-looking statements. All statements contained in this Annual \nReport on Form 10-K other than statements of historical fact, including statements regarding our future results of operations \nand financial position, our business strategy and plans, and our objectives for future operations, are forward-looking \nstatements. The words "believe," "may," "will," "estimate," "continue," "anticipate," "intend," "expect," and similar \nexpressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. We have based these forward-looking statements largely on \nour current expectations and projections about future events and trends that we believe may affect our financial condition, \nresults of operations, business strategy, short-term and long-term business operations and objectives, and financial needs. \nThese forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks, uncertainties and assumptions, including those described \nin Part I, Item 1A, "Risk Factors" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Moreover, we operate in a very competitive and \nrapidly changing environment. New risks emerge from time to time. It is not possible for our management to predict all risks, \nnor can we assess the impact of all factors on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may \ncause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements we may make. In light of \nthese risks, uncertainties and assumptions, the future events and trends discussed in this Annual Report on Form 10-K may \nnot occur and actual results could differ materially and adversely from those anticipated or implied in the forward-looking \nstatements.\nWe undertake no obligation to revise or publicly release the results of any revision to these forward-looking statements, \nexcept as required by law. Given these risks and uncertainties, readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such \nforward-looking statements. \nIn October 2021, we changed our corporate name from Facebook, Inc. to Meta Platforms, Inc. We will not distinguish \nbetween our prior and current corporate name and will refer to our current corporate name throughout this Annual Report on \nForm 10-K. As such, unless expressly indicated or the context requires otherwise, the terms "Meta," "company," "we," "us," \nand "our" in this document refer to Meta Platforms, Inc., a Delaware corporation, and, where appropriate, its subsidiaries. The \nterm "Family" refers to our Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp products. For references to accessing Meta\'s \nproducts on the "web" or via a "website," such terms refer to accessing such products on personal computers. For references \nto accessing Meta\'s products on "mobile," such term refers to accessing such products via a mobile application or via a \nmobile-optimized version of our websites such as m.facebook.com, whether on a mobile phone or tablet.\n3'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 4}, page_content='LIMITATIONS OF KEY METRICS AND OTHER DATA\nThe numbers for our key metrics are calculated using internal company data based on the activity of user accounts. We \nhave historically reported the numbers of our daily active users (DAUs), monthly active users (MAUs), and average revenue \nper user (ARPU) (collectively, our "Facebook metrics") based on user activity only on Facebook and Messenger and not on \nour other products. Beginning with our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2019, we also report \nour estimates of the numbers of our daily active people (DAP), monthly active people (MAP), and average revenue per \nperson (ARPP) (collectively, our "Family metrics") based on the activity of users who visited at least one of Facebook, \nInstagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp (collectively, our "Family" of products) during the applicable period of measurement. \nWe believe our Family metrics better reflect the size of our community and the fact that many people are using more than one \nof our products. As a result, over time we intend to report our Family metrics as key metrics in place of DAUs, MAUs, and \nARPU in our periodic reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.\nWhile these numbers are based on what we believe to be reasonable estimates of our user base for the applicable \nperiod of measurement, there are inherent challenges in measuring usage of our products across large online and mobile \npopulations around the world. The methodologies used to measure these metrics require significant judgment and are also \nsusceptible to algorithm or other technical errors. In addition, we are continually seeking to improve our estimates of our user \nbase, and such estimates may change due to improvements or changes in our methodology. We regularly review our \nprocesses for calculating these metrics, and from time to time we discover inaccuracies in our metrics or make adjustments to \nimprove their accuracy, which can result in adjustments to our historical metrics. Our ability to recalculate our historical \nmetrics may be impacted by data limitations or other factors that require us to apply different methodologies for such \nadjustments. We generally do not intend to update previously disclosed Family metrics for any such inaccuracies or \nadjustments that are within the error margins disclosed below.\nIn addition, our Family metrics and Facebook metrics estimates will differ from estimates published by third parties \ndue to differences in methodology.\nFamily Metrics\nMany people in our community have user accounts on more than one of our products, and some people have multiple \nuser accounts within an individual product. Accordingly, for our Family metrics, we do not seek to count the total number of \nuser accounts across our products because we believe that would not reflect the actual size of our community. Rather, our \nFamily metrics represent our estimates of the number of unique people using at least one of Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, \nand WhatsApp. We do not require people to use a common identifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our \nFamily, and therefore must seek to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people. To \ncalculate these metrics, we rely upon complex techniques, algorithms and machine learning models that seek to count the \nindividual people behind user accounts, including by matching multiple user accounts within an individual product and across \nmultiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as one \nperson. These techniques and models require significant judgment, are subject to data and other limitations discussed below, \nand inherently are subject to statistical variances and uncertainties. We estimate the potential error in our Family metrics \nprimarily based on user survey data, which itself is subject to error as well. While we expect the error margin for our Family \nmetrics to vary from period to period, we estimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide \nMAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people, and \nit is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary significantly from our estimates, \npotentially beyond our estimated error margins. As a result, it is also possible that our Family metrics may indicate changes \nor trends in user numbers that do not match actual changes or trends.\nTo calculate our estimates of Family DAP and MAP, we currently use a series of machine learning models that are \ndeveloped based on internal reviews of limited samples of user accounts and calibrated against user survey data. We apply \nsignificant judgment in designing these models and calculating these estimates. For example, to match user accounts within \nindividual products and across multiple products, we use data signals such as similar device information, IP addresses, and \nuser names. We also calibrate our models against data from periodic user surveys of varying sizes and frequency across our \nproducts, which are inherently subject to error. The timing and results of such user surveys have in the past contributed, and \nmay in the future contribute, to changes in our reported Family metrics from period to period. In addition, our data limitations \nmay affect our understanding of certain details of our business and increase the risk of error for our Family metrics estimates. \nOur techniques and models rely on a variety of data signals from different products, and we rely on more limited data signals \n4'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 5}, page_content='for some products compared to others. For example, as a result of limited visibility into encrypted products, we have fewer \ndata signals from WhatsApp user accounts and primarily rely on phone numbers and device information to match WhatsApp \nuser accounts with accounts on our other products. Similarly, although Messenger Kids users are included in our Family \nmetrics, we do not seek to match their accounts with accounts on our other applications for purposes of calculating DAP and \nMAP. Any loss of access to data signals we use in our process for calculating Family metrics, whether as a result of our own \nproduct decisions, actions by third-party browser or mobile platforms, regulatory or legislative requirements, limitations \nwhile our personnel work remotely during the COVID-19 pandemic, or other factors, also may impact the stability or \naccuracy of our reported Family metrics, as well as our ability to report these metrics at all. Our estimates of Family metrics \nalso may change as our methodologies evolve, including through the application of new data signals or technologies, product \nchanges, or other improvements in our user surveys, algorithms, or machine learning that may improve our ability to match \naccounts within and across our products or otherwise evaluate the broad population of our users. In addition, such evolution \nmay allow us to identify previously undetected violating accounts (as defined below).\nWe regularly evaluate our Family metrics to estimate the percentage of our MAP consisting solely of "violating" \naccounts. We define "violating" accounts as accounts which we believe are intended to be used for purposes that violate our \nterms of service, including bots and spam. In the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that approximately 3% of our \nworldwide MAP consisted solely of violating accounts. Such estimation is based on an internal review of a limited sample of \naccounts, and we apply significant judgment in making this determination. For example, we look for account information and \nbehaviors associated with Facebook and Instagram accounts that appear to be inauthentic to the reviewers, but we have \nlimited visibility into WhatsApp user activity due to encryption. In addition, if we believe an individual person has one or \nmore violating accounts, we do not include such person in our violating accounts estimation as long as we believe they have \none account that does not constitute a violating account. From time to time, we disable certain user accounts, make product \nchanges, or take other actions to reduce the number of violating accounts among our users, which may also reduce our DAP \nand MAP estimates in a particular period. We intend to disclose our estimates of the percentage of our MAP consisting solely \nof violating accounts on an annual basis. Violating accounts are very difficult to measure at our scale, and it is possible that \nthe actual number of violating accounts may vary significantly from our estimates.\nThe numbers of Family DAP and MAP discussed in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, as well as ARPP, do not \ninclude users on our other products, unless they would otherwise qualify as DAP or MAP, respectively, based on their other \nactivities on our Family products.\nFacebook Metrics\nWe regularly evaluate our Facebook metrics to estimate the number of "duplicate" and "false" accounts among our \nMAUs. A duplicate account is one that a user maintains in addition to his or her principal account. We divide "false" accounts \ninto two categories: (1) user-misclassified accounts, where users have created personal profiles for a business, organization, \nor non-human entity such as a pet (such entities are permitted on Facebook using a Page rather than a personal profile under \nour terms of service); and (2) violating accounts, which represent user profiles that we believe are intended to be used for \npurposes that violate our terms of service, such as bots and spam. The estimates of duplicate and false accounts are based on \nan internal review of a limited sample of accounts, and we apply significant judgment in making this determination. For \nexample, to identify duplicate accounts we use data signals such as identical IP addresses and similar user names, and to \nidentify false accounts we look for names that appear to be fake or other behavior that appears inauthentic to the reviewers. \nAny loss of access to data signals we use in this process, whether as a result of our own product decisions, actions by third-\nparty browser or mobile platforms, regulatory or legislative requirements, limitations while our personnel work remotely \nduring the COVID-19 pandemic, or other factors, also may impact the stability or accuracy of our estimates of duplicate and \nfalse accounts. Our estimates also may change as our methodologies evolve, including through the application of new data \nsignals or technologies or product changes that may allow us to identify previously undetected duplicate or false accounts and \nmay improve our ability to evaluate a broader population of our users. Duplicate and false accounts are very difficult to \nmeasure at our scale, and it is possible that the actual number of duplicate and false accounts may vary significantly from our \nestimates.\nIn the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that duplicate accounts may have represented approximately 11% of our \nworldwide MAUs. We believe the percentage of duplicate accounts is meaningfully higher in developing markets such as the \nPhilippines and Vietnam, as compared to more developed markets. In the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that false \naccounts may have represented approximately 5% of our worldwide MAUs. Our estimation of false accounts can vary as a \nresult of episodic spikes in the creation of such accounts, which we have seen originate more frequently in specific countries \n5'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 6}, page_content="such as Indonesia, Nigeria, and Vietnam. From time to time, we disable certain user accounts, make product changes, or take \nother actions to reduce the number of duplicate or false accounts among our users, which may also reduce our DAU and \nMAU estimates in a particular period. We intend to disclose our estimates of the number of duplicate and false accounts \namong our MAUs on an annual basis.\nThe numbers of DAUs and MAUs discussed in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, as well as ARPU, do not include \nusers on Instagram, WhatsApp, or our other products, unless they would otherwise qualify as DAUs or MAUs, respectively, \nbased on their other activities on Facebook.\nUser Geography\nOur data regarding the geographic location of our users is estimated based on a number of factors, such as the user's IP \naddress and self-disclosed location. These factors may not always accurately reflect the user's actual location. For example, a \nuser may appear to be accessing Facebook from the location of the proxy server that the user connects to rather than from the \nuser's actual location. The methodologies used to measure our metrics are also susceptible to algorithm or other technical \nerrors, and our estimates for revenue by user location and revenue by user device are also affected by these factors. \n6"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 7}, page_content="PART I\nItem 1. Business \nOverview\nOur mission is to give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together. All of our products, \nincluding our apps, share the vision of helping to bring the metaverse to life.\nWe build technology that helps people connect, find communities, and grow businesses. Our useful and engaging \nproducts enable people to connect and share with friends and family through mobile devices, personal computers, virtual \nreality (VR) headsets, wearables, and in-home devices. We also help people discover and learn about what is going on in the \nworld around them, enable people to share their opinions, ideas, photos and videos, and other activities with audiences \nranging from their closest family members and friends to the public at large, and stay connected everywhere by accessing our \nproducts. Meta is moving beyond 2D screens toward immersive experiences like augmented and virtual reality to help build \nthe metaverse, which we believe is the next evolution in social technology.\nWe report financial results for two segments: Family of Apps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL). For FoA, we generate \nsubstantially all of our revenue from selling advertising placements to marketers. Ads on our platforms enable marketers to \nreach people based on a variety of factors including age, gender, location, interests, and behaviors. Marketers purchase ads \nthat can appear in multiple places including on Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and third-party applications and websites. \nRL generates revenue from sales of consumer hardware products, software and content. Our products include: \nFamily of Apps\n• Facebook. Facebook helps give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together. It's a\nplace for people to share life's moments and discuss what's happening, nurture and build relationships, discover\nand connect to interests, and create economic opportunity. They can do this through News Feed, Stories, Groups,\nWatch, Marketplace, Reels, Dating, and more.\n• Instagram. Instagram brings people closer to the people and things they love. Instagram Feed, Stories, Reels,\nVideo, Live, Shops, and messaging are places where people and creators can express themselves and push\nculture forward through photos, video, and private messaging, and connect with and shop from their favorite\nbusinesses.\n• Messenger. Messenger is a simple yet powerful messaging application for people to connect with friends, family,\ngroups, and businesses across platforms and devices through chat, audio and video calls, and Rooms.\n• WhatsApp. WhatsApp is a simple, reliable, and secure messaging application that is used by people and\nbusinesses around the world to communicate and transact in a private way.\nReality Labs\n• Reality Labs. Reality Labs' augmented and virtual reality products help people feel connected, anytime,\nanywhere. Meta Quest lets people defy distance with cutting-edge VR hardware, software, and content. Facebook\nPortal video calling devices help friends and families stay connected and share the moments that matter in\nmeaningful ways.\nCompetition\nOur business is characterized by innovation, rapid change, and disruptive technologies. We compete with companies \nproviding connection, sharing, discovery, and communication products and services to users online, as well as companies that \nsell advertising to businesses looking to reach consumers and/or develop tools and systems for managing and optimizing \nadvertising campaigns. We face significant competition in every aspect of our business, including, but not limited to, \ncompanies that facilitate the ability of users to share, communicate, and discover content and information online or enable \nmarketers to reach their existing or prospective audiences, including, for example, Alphabet (Google and YouTube), \n7"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 8}, page_content="Amazon, Apple, ByteDance (TikTok), Microsoft, Snap (Snapchat), Tencent (WeChat), and Twitter. We compete to attract, \nengage, and retain people who use our products, to attract and retain businesses who use our free or paid business and \nadvertising services, and to attract and retain developers to build compelling mobile and web applications that integrate with \nour products. We also compete with companies that develop and deliver consumer hardware and virtual and augmented \nreality products and services. As we introduce or acquire new products, as our existing products evolve, or as other \ncompanies introduce new products and services, including as part of efforts to develop the metaverse, we may become \nsubject to additional competition. \nTechnology\nOur product development philosophy centers on continuous innovation in creating and improving products that are \nsocial by design, which means that our products are designed to place people and their social interactions at the core of the \nproduct experience. As our user base grows, as engagement with products like video and VR increases, and as we deepen our \ninvestment in new technologies like artificial intelligence, our computing needs continue to expand. We make significant \ninvestments in technology both to improve our existing products and services and to develop new ones, as well as for our \nmarketers and developers. We are also investing in protecting the security, privacy, and integrity of our platform by investing \nin both people and technology to strengthen our systems against abuse. \nSales and Operations \nThe majority of our marketers use our self-service ad platform to launch and manage their advertising campaigns. We \nalso have a global sales force that is focused on attracting and retaining advertisers and providing support to them throughout \nthe stages of the marketing cycle from pre-purchase decision-making to real-time optimizations to post-campaign analytics. \nWe work directly with these advertisers, as well as through advertising agencies and resellers. We operate in more than \n80 cities around the globe, the majority of which have a sales presence. We also invest in and rely on self-service tools to \nprovide direct customer support to our users and partners.\nMarketing\nHistorically, our communities have generally grown organically with people inviting their friends to connect with \nthem, supported by internal efforts to stimulate awareness and interest. In addition, we have invested and will continue to \ninvest in marketing our products and services to grow our brand and help build community around the world. \nIntellectual Property \nTo establish and protect our proprietary rights, we rely on a combination of patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade \nsecrets, including know-how, license agreements, confidentiality procedures, non-disclosure agreements with third parties, \nemployee disclosure and invention assignment agreements, and other contractual rights. In addition, to further protect our \nproprietary rights, from time to time we have purchased patents and patent applications from third parties. We do not believe \nthat our proprietary technology is dependent on any single patent or copyright or groups of related patents or copyrights. We \nbelieve the duration of our patents is adequate relative to the expected lives of our products.\nGovernment Regulation \nWe are subject to a variety of laws and regulations in the United States and abroad that involve matters central to our \nbusiness, many of which are still evolving and being tested in courts, and could be interpreted in ways that could harm our \nbusiness. These laws and regulations involve matters including privacy, data use, data protection and personal information, \nbiometrics, encryption, rights of publicity, content, intellectual property, advertising, marketing, distribution, data security, \ndata retention and deletion, data localization and storage, data disclosure, artificial intelligence, electronic contracts and other \ncommunications, competition, protection of minors, consumer protection, civil rights, telecommunications, product liability, \ne-commerce, taxation, economic or other trade controls including sanctions, anti-corruption and political law compliance,\nsecurities law compliance, and online payment services. In particular, we are subject to federal, state, and foreign laws\nregarding privacy and protection of people's data. Foreign data protection, privacy, content, competition, consumer\nprotection, and other laws and regulations can impose different obligations, or penalties or fines for non-compliance, or be\nmore restrictive than those in the United States.\n8"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 9}, page_content="These U.S. federal and state and foreign laws and regulations, which in some cases can be enforced by private parties \nin addition to government entities, are constantly evolving and can be subject to significant change. As a result, the \napplication, interpretation, and enforcement of these laws and regulations are often uncertain, particularly in the new and \nrapidly evolving industry in which we operate, and may be interpreted and applied inconsistently from country to country and \ninconsistently with our current policies and practices. For example, regulatory or legislative actions affecting the manner in \nwhich we display content to our users or obtain consent to various practices, or otherwise relating to content that is made \navailable on our products, could adversely affect our financial results. In the United States, there have been, and continue to \nbe, various efforts to remove or restrict the scope of the protections available to online platforms under Section 230 of the \nCommunications Decency Act, and any such changes may increase our costs or require significant changes to our products, \nbusiness practices, or operations, which could adversely affect our business and financial results.\nWe are also subject to evolving laws and regulations that dictate whether, how, and under what circumstances we can \ntransfer, process and/or receive certain data that is critical to our operations, including data shared between countries or \nregions in which we operate and data shared among our products and services. If we are unable to transfer data between and \namong countries and regions in which we operate, or if we are restricted from sharing data among our products and services, \nit could affect our ability to provide our services, the manner in which we provide our services or our ability to target ads, \nwhich could adversely affect our financial results. For example, the Privacy Shield, a transfer framework we relied upon for \ndata transferred from the European Union to the United States, was invalidated in July 2020 by the Court of Justice of the \nEuropean Union (CJEU). In addition, the other bases upon which Meta relies to transfer such data, such as Standard \nContractual Clauses (SCCs), have been subjected to regulatory and judicial scrutiny. In August 2020, we received a \npreliminary draft decision from the Irish Data Protection Commission (IDPC) that preliminarily concluded that Meta \nPlatforms Ireland's reliance on SCCs in respect of European user data does not achieve compliance with the General Data \nProtection Regulation (GDPR) and preliminarily proposed that such transfers of user data from the European Union to the \nUnited States should therefore be suspended. We believe a final decision in this inquiry may issue as early as the first half of \n2022. If a new transatlantic data transfer framework is not adopted and we are unable to continue to rely on SCCs or rely \nupon other alternative means of data transfers from Europe to the United States, we will likely be unable to offer a number of \nour most significant products and services, including Facebook and Instagram, in Europe, which would materially and \nadversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operations.\nWe have been subject to other significant legislative and regulatory developments in the past, and proposed or new \nlegislation and regulations could significantly affect our business. For example, the GDPR includes operational requirements \nfor companies that receive or process personal data of residents of the European Union that are different from those \npreviously in place in the European Union, requires submission of personal data breach notifications to our lead European \nUnion privacy regulator, the IDPC, and includes significant penalties for non-compliance with the notification obligation as \nwell as other requirements of the regulation. The GDPR is still a relatively new law, its interpretation is still evolving, and \ndraft decisions in investigations by the IDPC are subject to review by other European privacy regulators as part of the \nGDPR's consistency mechanism, which may lead to significant changes in the final outcome of such investigations. As a \nresult, the interpretation and enforcement of the GDPR, as well as the imposition and amount of penalties for non-\ncompliance, are subject to significant uncertainty. In addition, Brazil, the United Kingdom, and other countries have enacted \nsimilar data protection regulations imposing data privacy-related requirements on products and services offered to users in \ntheir respective jurisdictions. The California Consumer Privacy Act, which took effect in January 2020, and its successor, the \nCalifornia Privacy Rights Act, which will take effect in January 2023, also establish certain transparency rules and create new \ndata privacy rights for users. In addition, effective December 2020, the European Union's ePrivacy Directive includes \nadditional limitations on the use of data across messaging products and includes significant penalties for non-compliance. \nChanges to our products or business practices as a result of these or similar developments may adversely affect our \nadvertising business. Similarly, there are a number of legislative proposals in the European Union, the United States, at both \nthe federal and state level, as well as other jurisdictions that could impose new obligations or limitations in areas affecting our \nbusiness. For example, the proposed Digital Markets Act in the European Union and pending proposals to modify \ncompetition laws in the United States and other jurisdictions could cause us to incur significant compliance costs and could \npotentially impose new restrictions and requirements on companies like ours, including in areas such as the combination of \ndata across services, mergers and acquisitions, and product design. In addition, some countries, such as India, are considering \nor have passed legislation implementing data protection requirements or requiring local storage and processing of data or \nsimilar requirements that could increase the cost and complexity of delivering our services. New legislation or regulatory \ndecisions that restrict our ability to collect and use information about minors may also result in limitations on our advertising \nservices or our ability to offer products and services to minors in certain jurisdictions.\n9"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 10}, page_content='We are, and expect to continue to be, the subject of investigations, inquiries, data requests, requests for information, \nactions, and audits by government authorities and regulators in the United States, Europe, and around the world, particularly \nin the areas of privacy, data protection, law enforcement, consumer protection, civil rights, content moderation, and \ncompetition, as we continue to grow and expand our operations. We are also currently, and may in the future be, subject to \nregulatory orders or consent decrees, including the modified consent order we entered into with the U.S. Federal Trade \nCommission (FTC), which took effect in April 2020 and, among other matters, requires us to maintain a comprehensive \nprivacy program. Orders issued by, or inquiries or enforcement actions initiated by, government or regulatory authorities \ncould cause us to incur substantial costs, expose us to unanticipated civil and criminal liability or penalties (including \nsubstantial monetary remedies), interrupt or require us to change our business practices in a manner materially adverse to our \nbusiness, result in negative publicity and reputational harm, divert resources and the time and attention of management from \nour business, or subject us to other structural or behavioral remedies that adversely affect our business.\nFor additional information about government regulation applicable to our business, see Part I, Item 1A, "Risk Factors" \nin this Annual Report on Form 10-K. \nHuman Capital\nAt Meta, we design products to bring the world closer together, one connection at a time. As a company, we believe \nthat people are at the heart of every connection we build. We are proud of our unique company culture where ideas, \ninnovation, and impact win, and we work hard to build strong teams across engineering, product design, marketing, and other \nareas to further our mission. \nWe had a global workforce of 71,970 employees as of December 31, 2021, which represents a 23% year-over-year \nincrease in employee headcount. We expect headcount growth to continue for the foreseeable future, particularly as we \ncontinue to focus on recruiting employees in technical functions. In addition, we plan to continue to hire a number of \nemployees and contractors to continue to bolster various privacy, safety, security, and content review initiatives as well as \nother functions to support our expected growth. \nOur headquarters are located in Menlo Park, California and we have offices in more than 80 cities around the globe. \nThe vast majority of our personnel are currently working remotely as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, and in the long \nterm, we expect some personnel to continue to transition to working remotely on a regular basis. We offer most of our full-\ntime employees the option to work remotely on a regular basis.\nDiversity, Equity and Inclusion\nDiversity, equity and inclusion are core to our work at Meta. We seek to build a diverse and inclusive workplace where \nwe can leverage our collective cognitive diversity to build the best products and make the best decisions for the global \ncommunity we serve. While we have made progress, we still have more work to do.\nAs part of our diversity and inclusion report, we publish our global gender diversity and U.S. ethnic diversity \nworkforce data annually. As of June 30, 2021, our global employee base was comprised of 36.7% females and 63.3% males, \nand our U.S. employee base was comprised of the following ethnicities: 45.7% Asian, 39.1% White, 6.5% Hispanic, \n4.4% Black, 3.9% two or more ethnicities, and 0.4% additional groups (including American Indian or Alaska Native and \nNative Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander). In recent years, we also announced our goals to have 50% of our workforce made \nup of underrepresented groups by 2024, and to increase the representation of people of color in leadership positions in the \nUnited States, including Black leadership, by 30% from 2020 to 2025. We will also continue our ongoing efforts to increase \nthe representation of women in leadership.\nWe work to support our goals of diversifying our workforce through recruiting, retention, people development, and \ninclusion. We employ our Diverse Slate Approach in our global recruitment efforts, which ensures that teams and hiring \nmanagers have the opportunity to consider qualified people from underrepresented groups for open roles. We have seen \nsteady increases in hiring rates of people from underrepresented groups since we started testing this approach in 2015. We \nalso continue to develop inclusive internship programs, and Meta University, our training program for college freshmen and \nsophomores with an interest in Computer Science, also utilizes a proactive and inclusive approach to promote participation by \npeople from underrepresented groups. To help build community among our people and support their professional \ndevelopment, we invest in our internal Meta Resource Groups and our annual Community events such as Women\'s \n10'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 11}, page_content='Community Summit, Black Community Summit, Latin Community Summit, and Pride Community Summit. We also offer \nManaging Unconscious Bias, Managing Inclusion, Be the Ally, and other trainings to promote an inclusive workplace by \nhelping people understand the issues that affect underrepresented communities and how to reduce the effects of bias in the \nworkplace.\nCompensation and Benefits\nWe offer competitive compensation to attract and retain the best people, and we help care for our people so they can \nfocus on our mission. Our employees\' total compensation package includes market-competitive salary, bonuses or sales \nincentives, and equity. We generally offer full-time employees equity at the time of hire and through annual equity grants \nbecause we want them to be owners of the company and committed to our long-term success. We have conducted pay equity \nanalyses for many years, and continue to be committed to pay equity. In 2021, we announced that our analyses indicate that \nwe continue to have pay equity across genders globally and race in the United States for people in similar jobs, accounting for \nfactors such as location, role, and level.\nThrough Life@ Meta, our holistic approach to benefits, we provide our employees and their loved ones with resources \nto help them thrive. We offer a wide range of benefits across areas such as health, family, finance, community, and time \naway, including healthcare and wellness benefits, family building benefits, family care resources, retirement savings plans, \naccess to tax and legal services, Meta Resource Groups to build community at Meta, family leave, and paid time off.\nCorporate Information\nWe were incorporated in Delaware in July 2004. We completed our initial public offering in May 2012 and our \nClass A common stock is currently listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol "FB." In October 2021, we \nchanged our corporate name from Facebook, Inc. to Meta Platforms, Inc. We expect our Class A common stock to cease \ntrading under the symbol "FB" and begin trading under the new symbol, "META," on the Nasdaq Global Select Market in the \nfirst half of 2022. Our principal executive offices are located at 1601 Willow Road, Menlo Park, California 94025, and our \ntelephone number is (650) 543-4800.\nMeta, the Meta logo, Facebook, FB, Instagram, Oculus, WhatsApp, and our other registered or common law \ntrademarks, service marks, or trade names appearing in this Annual Report on Form 10-K are the property of Meta Platforms, \nInc. or its affiliates. Other trademarks, service marks, or trade names appearing in this Annual Report on Form 10‑K are the \nproperty of their respective owners.\nAvailable Information\nOur Annual Reports on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, Current Reports on Form 8-K, and amendments \nto reports filed pursuant to Sections 13(a) and 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (Exchange Act), are \nfiled with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). We are subject to the informational requirements of the \nExchange Act and file or furnish reports, proxy statements, and other information with the SEC. Such reports and other \ninformation filed by us with the SEC are available free of charge on our website at investor.fb.com when such reports are \navailable on the SEC\'s website. We use our investor.fb.com and about.fb.com/news/ websites as well as Mark Zuckerberg\'s \nFacebook Page (www.facebook.com/zuck) and Instagram account (www.instagram.com/zuck) as means of disclosing \nmaterial non-public information and for complying with our disclosure obligations under Regulation FD. \nThe SEC maintains an Internet site that contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information \nregarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC at www.sec.gov.\nThe contents of the websites referred to above are not incorporated into this filing. Further, our references to the URLs \nfor these websites are intended to be inactive textual references only.\n11'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 12}, page_content='Item 1A. Risk Factors\nCertain factors may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. You should \nconsider carefully the risks and uncertainties described below, in addition to other information contained in this Annual \nReport on Form 10-K, including our consolidated financial statements and related notes. The risks and uncertainties \ndescribed below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties that we are unaware of, or that we \ncurrently believe are not material, may also become important factors that adversely affect our business. If any of the \nfollowing risks actually occurs, our business, financial condition, results of operations, and future prospects could be \nmaterially and adversely affected. In that event, the trading price of our Class A common stock could decline, and you could \nlose part or all of your investment.\nSummary Risk Factors \nOur business is subject to a number of risks, including risks that may prevent us from achieving our business \nobjectives or may adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows, and prospects. rights; and\nRisks Related to Ownership of Our Class A Common Stock\n• limitations on the ability of holders of our Class A Common Stock to influence corporate matters due to the dual\nclass structure of our common stock and the control of a majority of the voting power of our outstanding capital\nstock by our founder, Chairman, and CEO.\nRisks Related to Our Product Offerings\nIf we fail to retain existing users or add new users, or if our users decrease their level of engagement with our products, \nour revenue, financial results, and business may be significantly harmed.\nThe size of our user base and our users' level of engagement across our products are critical to our success. Our \nfinancial performance has been and will continue to be significantly determined by our success in adding, retaining, and \nengaging active users of our products that deliver ad impressions, particularly for Facebook and Instagram. We anticipate that \nour active user growth rate will continue to generally decline over time as the size of our active user base increases. In \naddition, we have experienced, and expect to continue to experience, fluctuations and declines in the size of our active user \nbase in one or more markets from time to time, particularly in markets where we have achieved higher penetration rates. User \ngrowth and engagement are also impacted by a number of other factors, including competitive products and services, such as \nTikTok, that have reduced some users' engagement with our products and services, as well as global and regional business \nand macroeconomic conditions. For example, beginning in the first quarter of 2020, we experienced significant increases in \nthe size and engagement of our active user base across a number of regions as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. More \nrecently, we have seen these pandemic-related trends subside. We are unable to predict the impact of the pandemic on user \ngrowth and engagement with any certainty, and these trends may continue to be subject to volatility. In the fourth quarter of \n2021, we experienced a slight decline on a quarter-over-quarter basis in the total number of DAUs on Facebook, as well as a \nslight decline on a quarter-over-quarter basis in the number of DAUs on Facebook in the United States & Canada region. Any \nfuture declines in the size of our active user base may adversely impact our ability to deliver ad impressions and, in turn, our \nfinancial performance.\nIf people do not perceive our products to be useful, reliable, and trustworthy, we may not be able to attract or retain \nusers or otherwise maintain or increase the frequency and duration of their engagement. A number of other social networking \ncompanies that achieved early popularity have since seen their active user bases or levels of engagement decline, in some \ncases precipitously. There is no guarantee that we will not experience a similar erosion of our active user base or engagement \nlevels. Our user engagement patterns have changed over time, and user engagement can be difficult to measure, particularly \nas we introduce new and different products and services. For example, macroeconomic conditions have affected, and may in the future affect, \nmarketers' ability or willingness to spend with us, as we experienced in 2020 with the regional and worldwide economic \n16"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 17}, page_content="disruption related to the COVID-19 pandemic and associated declines in advertising activity on our products. The effects of \nthe pandemic previously resulted in reduced demand for our ads, a related decline in pricing of our ads, and additional \ndemands on our technical infrastructure as a result of increased usage of our services, and any similar occurrences in the \nfuture may impair our ability to maintain or increase the quantity or quality of ads shown to users and adversely affect our \nrevenue and financial results.\nOur advertising revenue is dependent on targeting and measurement tools that incorporate data signals from user activity \non websites and services that we do not control, and changes to the regulatory environment, third-party mobile operating \nsystems and browsers, and our own products have impacted, and we expect will continue to impact, the availability of such \nsignals, which will adversely affect our advertising revenue.\nWe rely on data signals from user activity on websites and services that we do not control in order to deliver relevant \nand effective ads to our users. Our advertising revenue is dependent on targeting and measurement tools that incorporate \nthese signals, and any changes in our ability to use such signals will adversely affect our business. For example, legislative \nand regulatory developments, such as the GDPR, ePrivacy Directive, and CCPA, have impacted, and we expect will continue \nto impact, our ability to use such signals in our ad products. In particular, we have seen an increasing number of users opt to \ncontrol certain types of ad targeting in Europe following adoption of the GDPR, which will increase further with expanded \ncontrol over certain third-party data as part of our ePrivacy Directive compliance, and we have introduced product changes \nthat limit data signal use for certain users in California following adoption of the CCPA. Regulatory guidance or decisions or \nnew legislation in these or other jurisdictions may require us to make additional changes to our products in the future that \nfurther reduce our ability to use these signals. In addition, mobile operating system and browser providers, such as Apple and \nGoogle, have implemented product changes and/or announced future plans to limit the ability of websites and application \ndevelopers to collect and use these signals to target and measure advertising. For example, in 2021, Apple made certain \nchanges to its products and data use policies in connection with changes to its iOS operating system that reduce our and other \niOS developers' ability to target and measure advertising, which has negatively impacted, and we expect will continue to \nnegatively impact, the size of the budgets marketers are willing to commit to us and other advertising platforms. In addition, \nwe have implemented, and may continue to implement, product changes that give users the ability to limit our use of such \ndata signals to improve ads and other experiences on our products and services, including our Off-Facebook Activity tool and \nour worldwide offering of certain product changes we implemented in connection with the GDPR. These developments have \nlimited our ability to target and measure the effectiveness of ads on our platform and negatively impacted our advertising \nrevenue. For example, our advertising revenue in the second half of 2021 was negatively impacted by marketer reaction to \ntargeting and measurement challenges associated with iOS changes. If we are unable to mitigate these developments as they \ntake further effect in the future, our targeting and measurement capabilities will be materially and adversely affected, which \nwould in turn significantly impact our future advertising revenue growth.\nOur user growth, engagement, and monetization on mobile devices depend upon effective operation with mobile operating \nsystems, networks, technologies, products, and standards that we do not control.\nThe substantial majority of our revenue is generated from advertising on mobile devices. There is no guarantee that \npopular mobile devices will continue to feature our products, or that mobile device users will continue to use our products \nrather than competing products. We are dependent on the interoperability of our products with popular mobile operating \nsystems, networks, technologies, products, and standards that we do not control, such as the Android and iOS operating \nsystems and mobile browsers. Any changes, bugs, or technical issues in such systems, or changes in our relationships with \nmobile operating system partners, handset manufacturers, browser developers, or mobile carriers, or in their terms of service \nor policies that degrade our products' functionality, reduce or eliminate our ability to update or distribute our products, give \npreferential treatment to competitive products, limit our ability to deliver, target, or measure the effectiveness of ads, or \ncharge fees related to the distribution of our products or our delivery of ads could adversely affect the usage of our products \nand monetization on mobile devices. For example, Apple previously released an update to its Safari browser that limits the \nuse of third-party cookies, which reduces our ability to provide the most relevant ads to our users and impacts monetization, \nand also released changes to iOS that limit our ability to target and measure ads effectively. We expect that any similar \nchanges to its, Google's, or other browser or mobile platforms will further limit our ability to target and measure the \neffectiveness of ads and impact monetization. Additionally, in order to deliver high quality mobile products, it is important \nthat our products work well with a range of mobile technologies, products, systems, networks, and standards that we do not \ncontrol, and that we have good relationships with handset manufacturers, mobile carriers, and browser developers. We may \nnot be successful in maintaining or developing relationships with key participants in the mobile ecosystem or in developing \nproducts that operate effectively with these technologies, products, systems, networks, or standards. In the event that it is \n17"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 18}, page_content="more difficult for our users to access and use our products on their mobile devices, or if our users choose not to access or use \nour products on their mobile devices or use mobile products that do not offer access to our products, our user growth and user \nengagement could be harmed. From time to time, we may also take actions regarding the distribution of our products or the \noperation of our business based on what we believe to be in our long-term best interests. Such actions may adversely affect \nour users and our relationships with the operators of mobile operating systems, handset manufacturers, mobile carriers, \nbrowser developers, other business partners, or advertisers, and there is no assurance that these actions will result in the \nanticipated long-term benefits. In the event that our users are adversely affected by these actions or if our relationships with \nsuch third parties deteriorate, our user growth, engagement, and monetization could be adversely affected and our business \ncould be harmed. We have in the past experienced challenges in operating with mobile operating systems, networks, \ntechnologies, products, and standards that we do not control, and any such occurrences in the future may negatively impact \nour user growth, engagement, and monetization on mobile devices, which may in turn materially and adversely affect our \nbusiness and financial results.\nOur new products and changes to existing products could fail to attract or retain users or generate revenue and profits.\nOur ability to retain, increase, and engage our user base and to increase our revenue depends heavily on our ability to \ncontinue to evolve our existing products and to create successful new products, both independently and in conjunction with \ndevelopers or other third parties. We may introduce significant changes to our existing products or acquire or introduce new \nand unproven products, including using technologies with which we have little or no prior development or operating \nexperience. For example, we do not have significant experience with consumer hardware products or virtual or augmented \nreality technology, which may adversely affect our ability to successfully develop and market these products and \ntechnologies. We continue to incur substantial costs, and we may not be successful in generating profits, in connection with \nthese efforts. In addition, the introduction of new products, or changes to existing products, may result in new or enhanced \ngovernmental or regulatory scrutiny, litigation, or other complications that could adversely affect our business and financial \nresults. We have also invested, and expect to continue to invest, significant resources in growing our WhatsApp and \nMessenger products to support increasing usage of such products. We have historically monetized messaging in only a \nlimited fashion, and we may not be successful in our efforts to generate meaningful revenue or profits from messaging over \nthe long term. In addition, we are moving forward with plans to implement end-to-end encryption across our messaging \nservices, as well as facilitate cross-app communication between these platforms, which plans have drawn governmental and \nregulatory scrutiny in multiple jurisdictions. If our new or enhanced products fail to engage users, marketers, or developers, \nor if our business plans are unsuccessful, we may fail to attract or retain users or to generate sufficient revenue, operating \nmargin, or other value to justify our investments, and our business may be adversely affected.\nWe make product and investment decisions that may not prioritize short-term financial results and may not produce the \nlong-term benefits that we expect.\nWe frequently make product and investment decisions that may not prioritize short-term financial results if we believe \nthat the decisions are consistent with our mission and benefit the aggregate user experience and will thereby improve our \nfinancial performance over the long term. For example, we have implemented, and we will continue to implement, changes to \nour user data practices. Some of these changes reduce our ability to effectively target ads, which has to some extent adversely \naffected, and will continue to adversely affect, our advertising business. For example, our Off-Facebook Activity tool enables \nusers to place limits on our storage and use of information about their interactions with advertisers' apps and websites, which \nreduces our ability to deliver the most relevant and effective ads to our users. Similarly, from time to time we update our \nNews Feed ranking algorithm to optimize the user experience, and these changes have had, and may in the future have, the \neffect of reducing time spent and some measures of user engagement with Facebook, which could adversely affect our \nfinancial results. From time to time, we also change the size, frequency, or relative prominence of ads as part of our product \nand monetization strategies. In addition, we have made, and we expect to continue to make, other changes to our products \nwhich may adversely affect the distribution of content of publishers, marketers, and developers, and could reduce their \nincentive to invest in their efforts on our products. We also may introduce new features or other changes to existing products, \nor introduce new stand-alone products, that attract users away from properties, formats, or use cases where we have more \nproven means of monetization, such as our feed products. In addition, as we focus on growing users and engagement across \nour family of products, from time to time these efforts have reduced, and may in the future reduce, engagement with one or \nmore products and services in favor of other products or services that we monetize less successfully or that are not growing as \nquickly. For example, we plan to continue to promote Reels, which we do not currently monetize at the same rate as our feed \nor Stories products. These decisions may adversely affect our business and results of operations and may not produce the \nlong-term benefits that we expect.\n18"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 19}, page_content="We may not be successful in our metaverse strategy and investments, which could adversely affect our business, \nreputation, or financial results.\nWe believe the metaverse, an embodied internet where people have immersive experiences beyond two-dimensional \nscreens, is the next evolution in social technology. In 2021, we announced a shift in our business and product strategy to \nfocus on helping to bring the metaverse to life. We expect this will be a complex, evolving, and long-term initiative that will \ninvolve the development of new and emerging technologies, continued investment in privacy, safety, and security efforts, and \ncollaboration with other companies, developers, partners, and other participants. However, the metaverse may not develop in \naccordance with our expectations, and market acceptance of features, products, or services we build for the metaverse is \nuncertain. In addition, we have limited experience with consumer hardware products and virtual and augmented reality \ntechnology, which may enable other companies to compete more effectively than us. We may be unsuccessful in our research \nand product development efforts, including if we are unable to develop relationships with key participants in the metaverse or \ndevelop products that operate effectively with metaverse technologies, products, systems, networks, or standards. Our \nmetaverse efforts may also divert resources and management attention from other areas of our business. We expect to \ncontinue to make significant investments in virtual and augmented reality and other technologies to support these efforts, and \nour ability to support these efforts is dependent on generating sufficient profits from other areas of our business. In addition, \nas our metaverse efforts evolve, we may be subject to a variety of existing or new laws and regulations in the United States \nand international jurisdictions, including in the areas of privacy and e-commerce, which may delay or impede the \ndevelopment of our products and services, increase our operating costs, require significant management time and attention, or \notherwise harm our business. As a result of these or other factors, our metaverse strategy and investments may not be \nsuccessful in the foreseeable future, or at all, which could adversely affect our business, reputation, or financial results.\nIf we are not able to maintain and enhance our brands, our ability to expand our base of users, marketers, and developers \nmay be impaired, and our business and financial results may be harmed.\nWe believe that our brands have significantly contributed to the success of our business. We also believe that \nmaintaining and enhancing our brands is critical to expanding our base of users, marketers, and developers. Many of our new \nusers are referred by existing users. Maintaining and enhancing our brands will depend largely on our ability to continue to \nprovide useful, reliable, trustworthy, and innovative products, which we may not do successfully. We may introduce new \nproducts or terms of service or policies that users do not like, which may negatively affect our brands. Additionally, the \nactions of our developers or advertisers may affect our brands if users do not have a positive experience using third-party \nmobile and web applications integrated with our products or interacting with parties that advertise through our products. We \nwill also continue to experience media, legislative, or regulatory scrutiny of our actions or decisions regarding user privacy, \ndata use, encryption, content, product design, algorithms, advertising, competition, and other issues, including actions or \ndecisions in connection with elections or the COVID-19 pandemic, which has in the past adversely affected, and may in the \nfuture adversely affect, our reputation and brands. For example, beginning in September 2021, we became the subject of \nmedia, legislative, and regulatory scrutiny as a result of a former employee's allegations and release of internal company \ndocuments relating to, among other things, our algorithms, advertising and user metrics, and content enforcement practices, \nas well as misinformation and other undesirable activity on our platform, and user well-being. In addition, in March 2018, we \nannounced developments regarding the misuse of certain data by a developer that shared such data with third parties in \nviolation of our terms and policies. We also may fail to respond expeditiously or appropriately to the sharing of objectionable \ncontent on our services or objectionable practices by advertisers or developers, or to otherwise enforce our policies or address \nuser concerns, which has occurred in the past and which could erode confidence in our brands. Our brands may also be \nnegatively affected by the actions of users that are deemed to be hostile or inappropriate to other users, by the actions of users \nacting under false or inauthentic identities, by the use of our products or services to disseminate information that is deemed to \nbe misleading (or intended to manipulate opinions), by perceived or actual efforts by governments to obtain access to user \ninformation for security-related purposes or to censor certain content on our platform, by the use of our products or services \nfor illicit or objectionable ends, including, for example, any such actions around the pandemic or elections in the United \nStates and around the world, by decisions or recommendations regarding content on our platform from the independent \nOversight Board, by research or media reports concerning the perceived or actual impacts of our products or services on user \nwell-being, or by our decisions to remove content or suspend participation on our platform by persons who violate our \ncommunity standards or terms of service. Maintaining and enhancing our brands will require us to make substantial \ninvestments and these investments may not be successful. Certain of our actions, such as the foregoing matter regarding \ndeveloper misuse of data and concerns around our handling of political speech and advertising, hate speech, and other \ncontent, as well as user well-being issues, have eroded confidence in our brands and may continue to do so in the future. If we \n19"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 20}, page_content='fail to successfully promote and maintain our brands or if we incur excessive expenses in this effort, our business and \nfinancial results may be adversely affected.\nWe may not be able to continue to successfully maintain or grow usage of and engagement with mobile and web \napplications that integrate with Facebook and our other products.\nWe have made and are continuing to make investments to enable developers to build, grow, and monetize mobile and \nweb applications that integrate with Facebook and our other products. Such existing and prospective developers may not be \nsuccessful in building, growing, or monetizing mobile and/or web applications that create and maintain user engagement. \nAdditionally, developers may choose to build on other platforms, including mobile platforms controlled by third parties, \nrather than building products that integrate with Facebook and our other products. We are continuously seeking to balance the \ndistribution objectives of our developers with our desire to provide an optimal user experience, and we may not be successful \nin achieving a balance that continues to attract and retain such developers. For example, from time to time, we have taken \nactions to reduce the volume of communications from these developers to users on Facebook and our other products with the \nobjective of enhancing the user experience, and such actions have reduced distribution from, user engagement with, and our \nmonetization opportunities from, mobile and web applications integrated with our products. In addition, as part of our efforts \nrelated to privacy, safety, and security, we conduct investigations and audits of platform applications from time to time, and \nwe also have announced several product changes that restrict developer access to certain user data. In some instances, these \nactions, as well as other actions to enforce our policies applicable to developers, have adversely affected, or will adversely \naffect, our relationships with developers. If we are not successful in our efforts to maintain or grow the number of developers \nthat choose to build products that integrate with Facebook and our other products or if we are unable to continue to build and \nmaintain good relations with such developers, our user growth and user engagement and our financial results may be \nadversely affected.\nRisks Related to Our Business Operations and Financial Results\nThe COVID-19 pandemic has previously had, and may in the future have, a significant adverse impact on our advertising \nrevenue and also exposes our business to other risks.\nThe COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in authorities implementing numerous preventative measures from time to time \nto contain or mitigate the outbreak of the virus, such as travel bans and restrictions, limitations on business activity, \nquarantines, and shelter-in-place orders. These measures have caused, and are continuing to cause, business slowdowns or \nshutdowns in certain affected countries and regions, which have previously significantly impacted our business and results of \noperations. For example, in the second quarter of 2020, our advertising revenue grew 10% year-over-year, which was the \nslowest growth rate for any fiscal quarter since our initial public offering. While our advertising revenue growth rate \nimproved in subsequent quarters, there can be no assurance that it will not decrease again as a result of the effects of the \npandemic. In addition, we believe that the pandemic previously contributed to an acceleration in the growth of online \ncommerce, which in turn increased demand for our advertising services. More recently, we believe this growth has moderated \nin many regions, and we may experience reduced advertising demand and related declines in pricing in future periods to the \nextent this trend continues, which could adversely affect our advertising revenue growth. The demand for and pricing of our \nadvertising services may be materially and adversely impacted by the pandemic for the foreseeable future, and we are unable \nto predict the duration or degree of such impact with any certainty. In addition to the impact on our advertising business, the \npandemic exposes our business, operations, and workforce to a variety of other risks, including:\n• volatility in the size of our user base and user engagement, particularly for our messaging products, whether as a\nresult of shelter-in-place measures or other factors;\n• delays in product development or releases, or reductions in manufacturing production and sales of consumer\nhardware, as a result of inventory shortages, supply chain or labor shortages;\n• increased misuse of our products and services or user data by third parties, including improper advertising practices\nor other activity inconsistent with our terms, contracts, or policies, misinformation or other illicit or objectionable\nmaterial on our platforms, election interference, or other undesirable activity;\n20'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 21}, page_content='• adverse impacts to our efforts to combat misuse of our products and services and user data as a result of limitations\non our safety, security, and content review efforts while our workforce is working remotely, such as the necessity to\nrely more heavily on artificial intelligence to perform tasks that our workforce is unable to perform;\n• significant volatility and disruption of global financial markets, which could cause fluctuations in currency exchange\nrates or negatively impact our ability to access capital in the future;\n• negative impact on our workforce productivity, product development, and research and development due to\ndifficulties resulting from our personnel working remotely;\n• illnesses to key employees, or a significant portion of our workforce, which may result in inefficiencies, delays, and\ndisruptions in our business; and\n• increased volatility and uncertainty in the financial projections we use as the basis for estimates used in our financial\nstatements.\nAny of these developments may adversely affect our business, harm our reputation, or result in legal or regulatory \nactions against us. The persistence of COVID-19, and the preventative measures implemented to help limit the spread of the \nillness, have impacted, and will continue to impact, our ability to operate our business and may materially and adversely \nimpact our business, financial condition, and results of operations.\nOur business is highly competitive. Competition presents an ongoing threat to the success of our business.\nWe compete with companies providing connection, sharing, discovery, and communication products and services to \nusers online, as well as companies that sell advertising to businesses looking to reach consumers and/or develop tools and \nsystems for managing and optimizing advertising campaigns. We face significant competition in every aspect of our business, \nincluding, but not limited to, companies that facilitate the ability of users to share, communicate, and discover content and \ninformation online or enable marketers to reach their existing or prospective audiences, including, for example, Alphabet \n(Google and YouTube), Amazon, Apple, ByteDance (TikTok), Microsoft, Snap (Snapchat), Tencent (WeChat), and Twitter. \nWe compete to attract, engage, and retain people who use our products, to attract and retain businesses that use our free or \npaid business and advertising services, and to attract and retain developers who build compelling mobile and web \napplications that integrate with our products. We also compete with companies that develop and deliver consumer hardware \nand virtual and augmented reality products and services. As we introduce or acquire new products, as our existing products \nevolve, or as other companies introduce new products and services, including as part of efforts to develop the metaverse, we \nmay become subject to additional competition.\nSome of our current and potential competitors may have greater resources, experience, or stronger competitive \npositions in certain product segments, geographic regions, or user demographics than we do. For example, some of our \ncompetitors may be domiciled in different countries and subject to political, legal, and regulatory regimes that enable them to \ncompete more effectively than us. These factors may allow our competitors to respond more effectively than us to new or \nemerging technologies and changes in market conditions. We believe that some users, particularly younger users, are aware \nof and actively engaging with other products and services similar to, or as a substitute for, our products and services, and we \nbelieve that some users have reduced their use of and engagement with our products and services in favor of these other \nproducts and services. In the event that users increasingly engage with other products and services, we may experience a \ndecline in use and engagement in key user demographics or more broadly, in which case our business would likely be \nharmed.\nOur competitors may develop products, features, or services that are similar to ours or that achieve greater acceptance, \nmay undertake more far-reaching and successful product development efforts or marketing campaigns, or may adopt more \naggressive pricing policies. Some competitors may gain a competitive advantage against us in areas where we operate, \nincluding: by making acquisitions; by limiting our ability to deliver, target, or measure the effectiveness of ads; by imposing \nfees or other charges related to our delivery of ads; by making access to our products more difficult or impossible; by making \nit more difficult to communicate with our users; or by integrating competing platforms, applications, or features into products \nthey control such as mobile device operating systems, search engines, browsers, or e-commerce platforms. For example, each \nof Apple and Google have integrated competitive products with iOS and Android, respectively. In addition, Apple has \nreleased changes to iOS that limit our ability, and the ability of others in the digital advertising industry, to target and \n21'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 22}, page_content="measure ads effectively. As a result, our competitors may, and in some cases will, acquire and engage users or generate \nadvertising or other revenue at the expense of our own efforts, which would negatively affect our business and financial \nresults. In addition, from time to time, we may take actions in response to competitive threats, but we cannot assure you that \nthese actions will be successful or that they will not negatively affect our business and financial results.\nWe believe that our ability to compete effectively depends upon many factors both within and beyond our control, \nincluding:\n• the popularity, usefulness, ease of use, performance, and reliability of our products compared to our competitors'\nproducts;\n• the size and composition of our user base;\n• the engagement of users with our products and competing
