enhancements to our or our competitors'\nproducts;\n• our safety and security efforts and our ability to protect user data and to provide users with control over their data;\n• our ability to distribute our products to new and existing users;\n• our ability to monetize our products;\n• the frequency, size, format, quality, and relative prominence of the ads displayed by us or our on their investments;\n• our ability to establish and maintain developers' interest in building mobile and web applications that integrate with\nFacebook and our other products;\n• our ability to establish and maintain publisher interest in integrating their content with Facebook and our other\nproducts;\n• changes mandated by legislation, regulatory authorities, or litigation, some of which may have a disproportionate\neffect on us;\n• acquisitions or consolidation within our industry, which may result in more formidable competitors;\n• our ability to attract, retain, and motivate talented employees, particularly software engineers, designers, and product\nmanagers;\n• our ability to cost-effectively manage and grow our operations; and\n• our reputation and brand strength relative to those of our competitors.\nIf we are not able to compete effectively, our user base, level of user engagement, and ability to deliver ad impressions\nmay decrease, we may become less page_content='Unfavorable media coverage negatively affects our business from time to time.\nWe receive a high degree of media coverage around the world. Unfavorable publicity regarding, for example, our \nprivacy practices, advertising policies, product changes, product quality, litigation or regulatory activity, government \nsurveillance, the actions of our advertisers, the actions of our developers whose products are integrated with our products, the \nuse of our products or services for illicit or objectionable ends, the substance or enforcement of our community standards, \nterms of service, or other policies, the actions of our users, the quality and integrity of content shared on our platform, the \nperceived or actual impacts of our products or services on user well-being, or the actions of other companies that provide \nsimilar services to ours, has in the past, and could in the future, adversely affect our reputation. For example, we have been \nthe subject of significant media coverage involving concerns around our handling of political speech and advertising, hate \nspeech, and other content, as well as user well-being issues, and we continue to receive negative publicity related to these \ntopics. Beginning in September 2021, we became the subject of significant media coverage as a result of allegations and the \nrelease of internal company documents by a former employee. In addition, we have been, and may in the future be, subject to \nnegative publicity in connection with our handling of misinformation and other illicit or objectionable use of our products or \nservices, including in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic and elections in the United States and around the world. Any \nsuch negative publicity could have an adverse effect on the size, engagement, and loyalty of our user base and marketer \ndemand for advertising on our products, which could result in decreased revenue and adversely affect our business and \nfinancial results, and we have experienced such adverse effects to varying degrees from time to time.\nOur financial results will fluctuate from quarter to quarter and are difficult to predict.\nOur quarterly financial results have fluctuated in the past and will fluctuate in the future. Additionally, we have a \nlimited operating history with the current scale of our business, which makes it difficult to forecast our future results. As a \nresult, you should not rely upon our past quarterly financial results as indicators of future performance. You should take into \naccount the risks and uncertainties frequently encountered by companies in rapidly evolving markets. Our financial results in \nany given quarter can be influenced by numerous factors, many of which we are unable to predict or are outside of our \ncontrol, including:\n• our ability to maintain and grow our user base and user engagement, particularly for our products that deliver ad\nimpressions;\n• our ability to attract and retain marketers in a particular period;\n• our ability to recognize revenue or collect payments from marketers in a particular period, including as a result of\nthe effects of the COVID-19 pandemic;\n• fluctuations in spending by our marketers due to seasonality, such as historically strong spending in the fourth\nquarter of each year, episodic regional or global events, including the COVID-19 pandemic, or other factors;\n• the frequency, prominence, size, format, to privacy, data protection, and content,\nor actions by governments or regulators, including fines, orders, or consent decrees;\n• the overall tax rate for our business, which is affected by the mix program;\n24'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 25}, page_content="• fluctuations in the market values of our investments in marketable securities, in the valuation of our equity\ninvestments, and in interest rates;\n• changes in U.S. generally accepted accounting principles; and\n• changes in regional or global business or macroeconomic conditions, including as a result of the COVID-19\npandemic, which may impact the other factors described above.\nOur rates of growth may be volatile in the near term as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, and we expect they will \ndecline over time in the future.\nWe have in the past experienced, and may in the future experience, volatility in our user and revenue growth rates as a \nresult of the COVID-19 pandemic, although we are unable to predict the duration or degree of such volatility with any \ncertainty. In the long term, we expect that our user growth rate will generally decline over time as the size of our active user \nbase increases, and the size of our active user base may fluctuate or decline in one or more markets, particularly as we \nachieve greater market penetration. We also expect our revenue growth rate will continue to decline over time as our revenue \nincreases to higher levels. As our growth rates experience volatility or decline, investors' perceptions of our business may be \nadversely affected and the trading price of our Class A common stock could decline.\nOur costs are continuing to grow, and some of our investments, particularly our investments in virtual and augmented \nreality, have the effect of reducing our operating margin and profitability. If our investments are not successful longer-\nterm, our business and financial performance will be harmed.\nOperating our business is costly, and we expect our expenses to continue to increase in the future as we broaden our \nuser base, as users increase the amount and types of content they consume and the data they share with us, for example with \nrespect to video, as we develop and implement new products, as we market new and existing products and promote our \nbrands, as we continue to expand our technical infrastructure, as we continue to invest in new and unproven technologies, and \nas we continue to hire additional employees and contractors to support our expanding operations, including our efforts to \nfocus on privacy, safety, security, and content review. In addition, from time to time we are subject to settlements, judgments, \nfines, or other monetary penalties in connection with legal and regulatory developments that may be material to our business. \nWe are also continuing to increase our investments in new platforms and technologies, including as we continue our efforts \nrelated to building the metaverse. Some of these investments, particularly our significant investments in virtual and \naugmented reality, have generated only limited revenue and reduced our operating margin and profitability, and we expect \nthe adverse financial impact of such investments to continue for the foreseeable future. For example, our investments in \nReality Labs reduced our 2021 overall operating profit by approximately $10 billion, and we expect our investments to \nincrease in future periods. If our investments are not successful longer-term, our business and financial performance will be \nharmed.\nWe plan to continue to make acquisitions and pursue other strategic transactions, which could impact our financial \ncondition or results of operations and may adversely affect the price of our common stock.\nAs part of our business strategy, we have made and intend to continue to make acquisitions to add specialized \nemployees and complementary companies, products, or technologies, and from time to time may enter into other strategic \ntransactions such as investments and joint ventures. We may not be able to find suitable acquisition candidates, and we may \nnot be able to complete acquisitions or other strategic transactions on favorable terms, or at all, including as a result of \nregulatory challenges. For example, in 2021, the United Kingdom Competition and Markets Authority issued an order \ndirecting us to divest our Giphy acquisition, which we have appealed. In some cases, the costs of such acquisitions or other \nstrategic transactions may be substantial, and there is no assurance that we will realize expected synergies from future growth \nand potential monetization opportunities for our acquisitions or a favorable return on investment for our strategic \ninvestments.\nWe may pay substantial amounts of cash or incur debt to pay for acquisitions or other strategic transactions, which has \noccurred in the past and could adversely affect our liquidity. The incurrence of indebtedness would also result in increased \nfixed obligations and increased interest expense, and could also include covenants or other restrictions that would impede our \nability to manage our operations. We may also issue equity securities to pay for acquisitions and we regularly grant RSUs to \nretain the employees of acquired companies, which could increase our expenses, adversely affect our financial results, and \n25"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 26}, page_content='result in dilution to our stockholders. In addition, any acquisitions or other strategic transactions we announce could be \nviewed negatively by users, marketers, developers, or investors, which may adversely affect our business or the price of our \nClass A common stock.\nWe may also discover liabilities, deficiencies, or other claims associated with the companies or assets we acquire that \nwere not identified in advance, which may result in significant unanticipated costs. The effectiveness of our due diligence \nreview and our ability to evaluate the results of such due diligence are dependent upon the accuracy and completeness of \nstatements and disclosures made or actions taken by the companies we acquire or their representatives, as well as the limited \namount of time in which acquisitions are executed. In addition, we may fail to accurately forecast the financial impact of an \nacquisition or other strategic transaction, including tax and accounting charges. Acquisitions or other strategic transactions \nmay also result in our recording of significant additional expenses to our results of operations and recording of substantial \nfinite-lived intangible assets on our balance sheet upon closing. Any of these factors may adversely affect our financial \ncondition or results of operations.\nWe may not be able to successfully integrate our acquisitions, and we incur significant costs to integrate and support the \ncompanies we acquire.\nThe integration of acquisitions requires significant time and resources, particularly with respect to companies that have \nsignificant operations or that develop products where we do not have prior experience, and we may not manage these \nprocesses successfully. We continue to make substantial investments of resources to support our acquisitions, which has in \nthe past resulted, and we expect will in the future result, in significant ongoing operating expenses and the diversion of \nresources and management attention from other areas of our business. We cannot assure you that these investments will be \nsuccessful. If we fail to successfully integrate the companies we acquire, we may not realize the benefits expected from the \ntransaction and our business may be harmed.\nOur business is dependent on our ability to maintain and scale our technical infrastructure, and any significant disruption \nin our service, including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, could damage our reputation, result in a potential loss of \nusers and engagement, and adversely affect our financial results.\nOur reputation and ability to attract, retain, and serve our users is dependent upon the reliable performance of our \nproducts and our underlying technical infrastructure. We have in the past experienced, and may in the future experience, \ninterruptions in the availability or performance of our products from time to time. Our systems may not be adequately \ndesigned or may not operate with the reliability and redundancy necessary to avoid performance delays or outages that could \nbe harmful to our business. If our products are unavailable when users attempt to access them, or if they do not load as \nquickly as expected, users may not use our products as often in the future, or at all, and our ability to serve ads may be \ndisrupted, any of which could adversely affect our business and financial performance. We have experienced such issues to \nvarying degrees from time to time. For example, in October 2021, a combination of an error and a bug resulted in an \napproximately six-hour outage of our services. In addition, as the amount and types of information shared on our products \ncontinue to grow and evolve, as the usage patterns of our global community continue to evolve, and as our internal \noperational demands continue to grow, we will need an increasing amount of technical infrastructure, including network \ncapacity and computing power, to continue to satisfy our needs. It is possible that we may fail to continue to effectively scale \nand grow our technical infrastructure to accommodate these increased demands, which may adversely affect our user \nengagement and advertising revenue growth. In addition, our business may be subject to interruptions, delays, or failures \nresulting from earthquakes, adverse weather conditions, other natural disasters, power loss, terrorism, geopolitical conflict, \nother physical security threats, cyber-attacks, or other catastrophic events. Global climate change could result in certain types \nof natural disasters occurring more frequently or with more intense effects. Any such events may result in users being subject \nto service disruptions or outages and we may not be able to recover our technical infrastructure and user data in a timely \nmanner to restart or provide our services, which may adversely affect our financial results. We also have been, and may in the \nfuture be, subject to increased energy or other costs to maintain the availability or performance of our products in connection \nwith any such events.\nIn 2020, the increase in the use of our products as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic increased demands on our \ntechnical infrastructure. We may not be able to accommodate any such demands in the future, including as a result of our \nreduced data center operations and personnel working remotely during the pandemic.\nA substantial portion of our network infrastructure is provided by third parties. Any disruption or failure in the services \n26'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 27}, page_content='we receive from these providers could harm our ability to handle existing or increased traffic and could significantly harm \nour business. Any financial or other difficulties these providers face may adversely affect our business, and we exercise little \ncontrol over these providers, which increases our vulnerability to problems with the services they provide. Due to the effects \nof the COVID-19 pandemic, we have experienced, and expect to continue to experience, supply and labor shortages and other \ndisruptions in logistics and the supply chain for our technical infrastructure. As a result, we have had to make certain changes \nto our procurement practices, and in the future we may not be able to procure sufficient components, equipment, or services \nfrom third parties to satisfy our needs, or we may be required to procure such components, equipment, or services on \nunfavorable terms. \nAny of these developments may result in interruptions in the availability or performance of our products, require \nunfavorable changes to existing products, delay the introduction of future products, or otherwise adversely affect our business \nand financial results. \nWe could experience unforeseen difficulties in building and operating key portions of our technical infrastructure.\nWe have designed and built our own data centers and key portions of our technical infrastructure through which we \nserve our products, and we plan to continue to significantly expand the size of our infrastructure primarily through data \ncenters, subsea and terrestrial fiber optic cable systems, and other projects. The infrastructure expansion we are undertaking is \ncomplex and involves projects in multiple locations around the world, including in emerging markets that expose us to \nincreased risks relating to anti-corruption compliance and political challenges, among others. We have in the past suspended, \nand may in the future suspend, certain of these projects as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional unanticipated \ndelays or disruptions in the completion of these projects, including due to any shortage of labor necessary in building portions \nof such projects, or availability of components, challenges in obtaining required government or regulatory approvals, or other \ngeopolitical challenges or actions by governments, whether as a result of the pandemic, trade disputes, or otherwise, may lead \nto increased project costs, operational inefficiencies, interruptions in the delivery or degradation of the quality or reliability of \nour products, or impairment of assets on our balance sheet. In addition, there may be issues related to this infrastructure that \nare not identified during the testing phases of design and implementation, which may only become evident after we have \nstarted to fully utilize the underlying equipment, that could further degrade the user experience or increase our costs. Further, \nmuch of our technical infrastructure is located outside the United States, and it is possible that action by a foreign \ngovernment, or our response to such government action, could result in the impairment of a portion of our technical \ninfrastructure, which may interrupt the delivery or degrade the quality or reliability of our products and lead to a negative \nuser experience or increase our costs. Any of these events could adversely affect our business, reputation, or financial results.\nReal or perceived inaccuracies in our community and other metrics may harm our reputation and negatively affect our \nbusiness.\nThe numbers for our key metrics, which include our Family metrics (DAP, MAP, and average revenue per person \n(ARPP)) and Facebook metrics (DAUs, MAUs, and average revenue per user (ARPU)), are calculated using internal \ncompany data based on the activity of user accounts. While these numbers are based on what we believe to be reasonable \nestimates of our user base for the applicable period of measurement, there are inherent challenges in measuring usage of our \nproducts across large online and mobile populations around the world. The methodologies used to measure these metrics \nrequire significant judgment and are also susceptible to algorithm or other technical errors. In addition, we are continually \nseeking to improve our estimates of our user base, and such estimates may change due to improvements or changes in our \nmethodology. We regularly review our processes for calculating these metrics, and from time to time we discover \ninaccuracies in our metrics or make adjustments to improve their accuracy, which can result in adjustments to our historical \nmetrics. Our ability to recalculate our historical metrics may be impacted by data limitations or other factors that require us to \napply different methodologies for such adjustments. We generally do not intend to update previously disclosed Family \nmetrics for any such inaccuracies or adjustments that are within the error margins disclosed below. \nIn addition, our Family metrics and Facebook metrics estimates will differ from estimates published by third parties \ndue to differences in methodology.\nMany people in our community have user accounts on more than one of our products, and some people have multiple \nuser accounts within an individual product. Accordingly, for our Family metrics, we do not seek to count the total number of \nuser accounts across our products because we believe that would not reflect the actual size of our community. Rather, our \nFamily metrics represent our estimates of the number of unique people using at least one of Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, \n27'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 28}, page_content='and WhatsApp. We do not require people to use a common identifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our \nFamily, and therefore must seek to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people. To \ncalculate these metrics, we rely upon complex techniques, algorithms and machine learning models that seek to count the \nindividual people behind user accounts, including by matching multiple user accounts within an individual product and across \nmultiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as one \nperson. These techniques and models require significant judgment, are subject to data and other limitations discussed below, \nand inherently are subject to statistical variances and uncertainties. We estimate the potential error in our Family metrics \nprimarily based on user survey data, which itself is subject to error as well. While we expect the error margin for our Family \nmetrics to vary from period to period, we estimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide \nMAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people, and \nit is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary significantly from our estimates, \npotentially beyond our estimated error margins. As a result, it is also possible that our Family metrics may indicate changes \nor trends in user numbers that do not match actual changes or trends.\nTo calculate our estimates of Family DAP and MAP, we currently use a series of machine learning models that are \ndeveloped based on internal reviews of limited samples of user accounts and calibrated against user survey data. We apply \nsignificant judgment in designing these models and calculating these estimates. For example, to match user accounts within \nindividual products and across multiple products, we use data signals such as similar device information, IP addresses, and \nuser names. We also calibrate our models against data from periodic user surveys of varying sizes and frequency across our \nproducts, which are inherently subject to error. The timing and results of such user surveys have in the past contributed, and \nmay in the future contribute, to changes in our reported Family metrics from period to period. In addition, our data limitations \nmay affect our understanding of certain details of our business and increase the risk of error for our Family metrics estimates. \nOur techniques and models rely on a variety of data signals from different products, and we rely on more limited data signals \nfor some products compared to others. For example, as a result of limited visibility into encrypted products, we have fewer \ndata signals from WhatsApp user accounts and primarily rely on phone numbers and device information to match WhatsApp \nuser accounts with accounts on our other products. Similarly, although Messenger Kids users are included in our Family \nmetrics, we do not seek to match their accounts with accounts on our other applications for purposes of calculating DAP and \nMAP. Any loss of access to data signals we use in our process for calculating Family metrics, whether as a result of our own \nproduct decisions, actions by third-party browser or mobile platforms, regulatory or legislative requirements, limitations \nwhile our personnel work remotely during the COVID-19 pandemic, or other factors, also may impact the stability or \naccuracy of our reported Family metrics, as well as our ability to report these metrics at all. Our estimates of Family metrics \nalso may change as our methodologies evolve, including through the application of new data signals or technologies, product \nchanges, or other improvements in our user surveys, algorithms, or machine learning that may improve our ability to match \naccounts within and across our products or otherwise evaluate the broad population of our users. In addition, such evolution \nmay allow us to identify previously undetected violating accounts (as defined below).\nWe regularly evaluate our Family metrics to estimate the percentage of our MAP consisting solely of "violating" \naccounts. We define "violating" accounts as accounts which we believe are intended to be used for purposes that violate our \nterms of service, including bots and spam. In the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that approximately 3% of our \nworldwide MAP consisted solely of violating accounts. Such estimation is based on an internal review of a limited sample of \naccounts, and we apply significant judgment in making this determination. For example, we look for account information and \nbehaviors associated with Facebook and Instagram accounts that appear to be inauthentic to the reviewers, but we have \nlimited visibility into WhatsApp user activity due to encryption. In addition, if we believe an individual person has one or \nmore violating accounts, we do not include such person in our violating accounts estimation as long as we believe they have \none account that does not constitute a violating account. From time to time, we disable certain user accounts, make product \nchanges, or take other actions to reduce the number of violating accounts among our users, which may also reduce our DAP \nand MAP estimates in a particular period. We intend to disclose our estimates of the percentage of our MAP consisting solely \nof violating accounts on an annual basis. Violating accounts are very difficult to measure at our scale, and it is possible that \nthe actual number of violating accounts may vary significantly from our estimates.\nWe also regularly evaluate our Facebook metrics to estimate the number of "duplicate" and "false" accounts among \nour MAUs. A duplicate account is one that a user maintains in addition to his or her principal account. We divide "false" \naccounts into two categories: (1) user-misclassified accounts, where users have created personal profiles for a business, \norganization, or non-human entity such as a pet (such entities are permitted on Facebook using a Page rather than a personal \nprofile under our terms of service); and (2) violating accounts, which represent user profiles that we believe are intended to \nbe used for purposes that violate our terms of service, such as bots and spam. The estimates of duplicate and false accounts \n28'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 29}, page_content="are based on an internal review of a limited sample of accounts, and we apply significant judgment in making this \ndetermination. For example, to identify duplicate accounts we use data signals such as identical IP addresses and similar user \nnames, and to identify false accounts we look for names that appear to be fake or other behavior that appears inauthentic to \nthe reviewers. Any loss of access to data signals we use in this process, whether as a result of our own product decisions, \nactions by third-party browser or mobile platforms, regulatory or legislative requirements, limitations while our personnel \nwork remotely during the COVID-19 pandemic, or other factors, also may impact the stability or accuracy of our estimates of \nduplicate and false accounts. Our estimates also may change as our methodologies evolve, including through the application \nof new data signals or technologies or product changes that may allow us to identify previously undetected duplicate or false \naccounts and may improve our ability to evaluate a broader population of our users. Duplicate and false accounts are very \ndifficult to measure at our scale, and it is possible that the actual number of duplicate and false accounts may vary \nsignificantly from our estimates.\nIn the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that duplicate accounts may have represented approximately 11% of our \nworldwide MAUs. We believe the percentage of duplicate accounts is meaningfully higher in developing markets such as the \nPhilippines and Vietnam, as compared to more developed markets. In the fourth quarter of 2021, we estimated that false \naccounts may have represented approximately 5% of our worldwide MAUs. Our estimation of false accounts can vary as a \nresult of episodic spikes in the creation of such accounts, which we have seen originate more frequently in specific countries \nsuch as Indonesia, Nigeria, and Vietnam. From time to time, we disable certain user accounts, make product changes, or take \nother actions to reduce the number of duplicate or false accounts among our users, which may also reduce our DAU and \nMAU estimates in a particular period. We intend to disclose our estimates of the number of duplicate and false accounts \namong our MAUs on an annual basis.\nOther data limitations also may affect our understanding of certain details of our business. For example, while user-\nprovided data indicates a decline in usage among younger users, this age data may be unreliable because a disproportionate \nnumber of our younger users register with an inaccurate age. Accordingly, our understanding of usage by age group may not \nbe complete.\nIn addition, our data regarding the geographic location of our users is estimated based on a number of factors, such as \nthe user's IP address and self-disclosed location. These factors may not always accurately reflect the user's actual location. \nFor example, a user may appear to be accessing Facebook from the location of the proxy server that the user connects to \nrather than from the user's actual location. The methodologies used to measure our metrics are also susceptible to algorithm \nor other technical errors, and our estimates for revenue by user location and revenue by user device are also affected by these \nfactors. \nIn addition, from time to time we provide, or rely on, certain other metrics and estimates, including those relating to \nthe reach and effectiveness of our ads. Many of our metrics involve the use of estimations and judgments, and our metrics \nand estimates are subject to software bugs, inconsistencies in our systems, and human error. Such metrics and estimates also \nchange from time to time due to improvements or changes in our terminology or methodology, including as a result of loss of \naccess to data signals we use in calculating such metrics and estimates. We have in the past been, and may in the future be, \nsubject to litigation as well as marketer, regulatory, and other inquiries regarding the accuracy of such metrics and estimates. \nWhere marketers, developers, or investors do not perceive our metrics or estimates to be accurate, or where we discover \nmaterial inaccuracies in our metrics or estimates, we may be subject to liability, our reputation may be harmed, and marketers \nand developers may be less willing to allocate their budgets or resources to our products that deliver ad impressions, which \ncould negatively affect our business and financial results.\nWe cannot assure you that we will effectively manage our growth.\nOur employee headcount and the scope and complexity of our business have increased significantly, with the number \nof employees increasing to 71,970 as of December 31, 2021 from 58,604 as of December 31, 2020, and we expect headcount \ngrowth to continue for the foreseeable future. In addition, we plan to continue to hire a number of employees and contractors \nto continue to bolster various privacy, safety, security, and content review initiatives as well as other functions to support our \nexpected growth. The growth and expansion of our business and products create significant challenges for our management, \noperational, and financial resources, including managing multiple relationships with users, marketers, developers, and other \nthird parties. As our operations and the number of our third-party relationships continue to grow, our information technology \nsystems or our internal controls and procedures may not be adequate to support such growth. In addition, some members of \nour management do not have significant experience managing a large global business operation, so our management may not \n29"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 30}, page_content='be able to manage such growth effectively. Additionally, the vast majority of our personnel are currently working remotely as \na result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which limits their ability to perform certain job functions and may negatively impact \nproductivity. In the long term, we may experience such challenges to productivity and collaboration as some personnel \ntransition to working remotely on a regular basis, and we may experience difficulties integrating recently hired personnel \nwhen our offices re-open. To effectively manage our growth, we must continue to adapt to a remote work environment; \nimprove our operational, financial, and management processes and systems; and effectively expand, train, and manage our \npersonnel. As our organization continues to grow, and we are required to implement more complex organizational \nmanagement structures, we may find it increasingly difficult to maintain the benefits of our corporate culture, including our \nability to quickly develop and launch new and innovative products. This could negatively affect our business performance.\nWe have significant international operations and plan to continue expanding our operations abroad where we have more \nlimited operating experience, and this may subject us to increased business, economic, and legal risks that could affect our \nfinancial results.\nWe have significant international operations and plan to continue the international expansion of our business \noperations and the translation of our products. We currently make Facebook available in more than 100 different languages, \nand we have offices or data centers in more than 30 different countries. We may enter new international markets where we \nhave limited or no experience in marketing, selling, and deploying our products. Our products are generally available \nglobally, but some or all of our products or functionality may not be available in certain markets due to legal and regulatory \ncomplexities. For example, several of our products are not generally available in China. We also outsource certain operational \nfunctions to third-party vendors globally. If we fail to deploy, manage, or oversee our international operations successfully, \nour business may suffer. In addition, we are subject to a variety of risks inherent in doing business internationally, including:\n• political, social, or economic instability;\n• risks related to legal, regulatory, and other government scrutiny applicable to U.S. companies with sales and\noperations in foreign jurisdictions, including with respect to privacy, tax, law enforcement, content, trade\ncompliance, supply chain, competition, consumer protection, intellectual property, environmental, health and safety,\nlicensing, and infrastructure matters;\n• potential damage to our brand and reputation due to compliance with local laws, including potential censorship or\nrequirements to provide user information to local authorities;\n• enhanced difficulty in reviewing content on our platform and enforcing our community standards across different\nlanguages and countries;\n• fluctuations in currency exchange rates and compliance with currency controls;\n• foreign exchange controls and tax and other regulations and orders that might prevent us from repatriating cash\nearned in countries outside the United States or otherwise limit our ability to move cash freely, and impede our\nability to invest such cash efficiently;\n• higher levels of credit risk and payment fraud;\n• enhanced difficulties of integrating any foreign acquisitions;\n• burdens of complying with a variety of foreign laws, including laws related to taxation, content removal, content\nmoderation, data localization, data protection, e-commerce and payments, and regulatory oversight;\n• reduced protection for intellectual property rights in some countries;\n• difficulties in staffing, managing, and overseeing global operations and the increased travel, infrastructure, and legal\ncompliance costs associated with multiple international locations, including difficulties arising from personnel\nworking remotely during the COVID-19 pandemic;\n• compliance with statutory equity requirements and management of tax consequences; and\n30'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 31}, page_content="• geopolitical events affecting us, our marketers or our industry, including trade disputes and pandemics.\nIn addition, we must manage the potential conflicts between locally accepted business practices in any given\njurisdiction and our obligations to comply with laws and regulations, including anti-corruption laws or regulations applicable \nto us, such as the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the U.K. Bribery Act 2010. We also must manage our obligations to \ncomply with laws and regulations related to import and export controls, trade restrictions, and sanctions, including \nregulations established by the U.S. Office of Foreign Assets Control. Government agencies and authorities have a broad \nrange of civil and criminal penalties they may seek to impose against companies for violations of anti-corruption laws or \nregulations, import and export controls, trade restrictions, sanctions, and other laws, rules, and regulations.\nIf we are unable to expand internationally and manage the complexity of our global operations successfully, our \nfinancial results could be adversely affected. We also may be required to or elect to cease or modify our operations or the \noffering of our products and services in certain regions, including as a result of the risks described above, which could \nadversely affect our business, user growth and engagement, and financial results.\nWe face design, manufacturing, and supply chain risks that, if not properly managed, could adversely impact our \nfinancial results.\nWe face a number of risks related to design, manufacturing, and supply chain management with respect to our \nconsumer hardware products. For example, the consumer hardware products we sell from time to time have had, and in the \nfuture may have, quality issues resulting from the design or manufacture of the products, or from the software used in the \nproducts. Sometimes, these issues may be caused by components we purchase from other manufacturers or suppliers. Our \nbrand and financial results could be adversely affected by any such quality issues, other failures to meet our customers' \nexpectations, or findings of our consumer hardware products to be defective.\nWe rely on third parties to manufacture and manage the logistics of transporting and distributing our consumer \nhardware products, which subjects us to a number of risks that have been exacerbated as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. \nWe have experienced, and may in the future experience, supply or labor shortages or other disruptions in logistics and the \nsupply chain, which could result in shipping delays and negatively impact our operations, product development, and sales. \nWe could be negatively affected if we are not able to engage third parties with the necessary capabilities or capacity on \nreasonable terms, or if those we engage with fail to meet their obligations (whether due to financial difficulties, \nmanufacturing or supply constraints, or other reasons), or make adverse changes in the pricing or other material terms of such \narrangements with them. The manufacturing, distribution, and sale of our consumer hardware products also may be \nnegatively impacted by macroeconomic conditions, geopolitical challenges, trade disputes, or other actions by governments \nthat subject us to supply shortages, increased costs, or supply chain disruptions.\nWe also require the suppliers and business partners of our consumer hardware products to comply with laws and \ncertain company policies regarding sourcing practices and standards on labor, health and safety, the environment, and \nbusiness ethics, but we do not control them or their practices and standards. If any of them violates laws, fails to implement \nchanges in accordance with newly enacted laws, or implements practices or standards regarded as unethical, corrupt, or non-\ncompliant, we could experience supply chain disruptions, government action or fines, canceled orders, or damage to our \nreputation.\nWe face inventory risk with respect to our consumer hardware products.\nWe are exposed to inventory risks with respect to our consumer hardware products as a result of rapid changes in \nproduct cycles and pricing, unsafe or defective merchandise, supply chain disruptions, changes in consumer demand and \nconsumer spending patterns, changes in consumer tastes with respect to our consumer hardware products, and other factors. \nThe demand for our products can also change significantly between the time inventory or components are ordered and the \ndate of sale. While we endeavor to accurately predict these trends and avoid overstocking or understocking consumer \nhardware products we may sell, from time to time we have experienced difficulties in accurately predicting and meeting the \nconsumer demand for our products. In addition, when we begin selling or manufacturing a new consumer hardware product \nor enter new international markets, it may be difficult to establish vendor relationships, determine appropriate product or \ncomponent selection, and accurately forecast demand. The acquisition of certain types of inventory or components may \nrequire significant lead-time and prepayment and they may not be returnable. Any one of the foregoing factors may adversely \n31"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 32}, page_content="affect our operating results.\nWe are involved in numerous class action lawsuits and other litigation matters that are expensive and time consuming, \nand, if resolved adversely, could harm our business, financial condition, or results of operations.\nWe are involved in numerous lawsuits, including stockholder derivative lawsuits and putative class action lawsuits, \nmany of which claim statutory damages and/or seek significant changes to our business operations, and we anticipate that we \nwill continue to be a target for numerous lawsuits in the future. Because of the scale of our user, advertiser, and developer \nbase, the plaintiffs in class action cases filed against us typically claim enormous monetary damages even if the alleged per-\nuser or entity harm is small or non-existent. In addition, we have in the past, and may in the future, be subject to additional \nclass action lawsuits based on claims related to advertising, antitrust, privacy, biometrics, content, algorithms, employment, \nactivities on our platform, consumer protection, or product performance or other claims related to the use of consumer \nhardware and software, including virtual reality technology and products, which are new and unproven. For example, we are \ncurrently the subject of multiple putative class action suits in connection with our platform and user data practices and the \nmisuse of certain data by a developer that shared such data with third parties in violation of our terms and policies; the \ndisclosure of our earnings results for the second quarter of 2018; our acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp, as well as \nother alleged anticompetitive conduct; and a former employee's allegations and release of internal company documents \nbeginning in September 2021. The results of any such lawsuits and claims cannot be predicted with certainty, and any \nnegative outcome from any such lawsuits could result in payments of substantial monetary damages or fines, or undesirable \nchanges to our products or business practices, and accordingly our business, financial condition, or results of operations could \nbe materially and adversely affected.\nThere can be no assurances that a favorable final outcome will be obtained in all our cases, and defending any lawsuit \nis costly and can impose a significant burden on management and employees. Any litigation to which we are a party may \nresult in an onerous or unfavorable judgment that may not be reversed upon appeal or in payments of substantial monetary \ndamages or fines, or we may decide to settle lawsuits on similarly unfavorable terms, which has occurred in the past and \nwhich could adversely affect our business, financial conditions, or results of operations.\nWe may have exposure to greater than anticipated tax liabilities.\nOur tax obligations, including income and non-income taxes, are based in part on our corporate operating structure and \nintercompany arrangements, including the manner in which we operate our business, develop, value, manage, protect, and use \nour intellectual property, and the valuations of our intercompany transactions. The tax laws applicable to our business, \nincluding the laws of the United States and other jurisdictions, are subject to interpretation and certain jurisdictions are \naggressively interpreting their laws in new ways in an effort to raise additional tax revenue from companies such as Meta. We \nare subject to regular review and audit by U.S. federal, state, and foreign tax authorities. Tax authorities may disagree with \ncertain positions we have taken, including our methodologies for valuing developed technology or intercompany \narrangements, and any adverse outcome of such a review or audit could increase our worldwide effective tax rate, increase \nthe amount of non-income taxes imposed on our business, and harm our financial position, results of operations, and cash \nflows. For example, in 2016 and 2018, the IRS issued formal assessments relating to transfer pricing with our foreign \nsubsidiaries in conjunction with the examination of the 2010 through 2013 tax years. Although we disagree with the IRS's \nposition and are litigating this issue, the ultimate resolution is uncertain and, if resolved in a manner unfavorable to us, may \nadversely affect our financial results.\nThe determination of our worldwide provision for income taxes and other tax liabilities requires significant judgment \nby management, and there are many transactions where the ultimate tax determination is uncertain. Our provision for income \ntaxes is determined by the manner in which we operate our business, and any changes to such operations or laws applicable to \nsuch operations may affect our effective tax rate. Although we believe that our provision for income taxes and estimates of \nour non-income tax liabilities are reasonable, the ultimate settlement may differ from the amounts recorded in our financial \nstatements and may materially affect our financial results in the period or periods for which such determination is made.\nOur future income tax rates could be volatile and difficult to predict due to changes in jurisdictional profit split, \nchanges in the amount and recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities, or by changes in tax laws, regulations, or \naccounting principles.\n32"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 33}, page_content='Changes in tax laws or tax rulings could materially affect our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows.\nThe tax regimes we are subject to or operate under, including income and non-income taxes, are unsettled and may be \nsubject to significant change. Changes in tax laws or tax rulings, or changes in interpretations of existing laws, could \nmaterially affect our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows. For example, the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act \n(Tax Act) enacted in December 2017 had a significant impact on our tax obligations and effective tax rate for the fourth \nquarter of 2017. The issuance of additional regulatory or accounting guidance related to the Tax Act, or other executive or \nCongressional actions in the United States or globally could materially increase our tax obligations and significantly impact \nour effective tax rate in the period such guidance is issued or such actions take effect, and in future periods. In addition, many \ncountries have recently proposed or recommended changes to existing tax laws or have enacted new laws that could \nsignificantly increase our tax obligations in many countries where we do business or require us to change the manner in \nwhich we operate our business.\nOver the last several years, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has been working on a Base \nErosion and Profit Shifting Project that, if implemented, would change various aspects of the existing framework under \nwhich our tax obligations are determined in many of the countries in which we do business. In 2021, more than 140 countries \ntentatively signed on to a framework that imposes a minimum tax rate of 15%, among other provisions. As this framework is \nsubject to further negotiation and implementation by each member country, the timing and ultimate impact of any such \nchanges on our tax obligations are uncertain. Similarly, the European Commission and several countries have issued \nproposals that would apply to various aspects of the current tax framework under which we are taxed. These proposals \ninclude changes to the existing framework to calculate income tax, as well as proposals to change or impose new types of \nnon-income taxes, including taxes based on a percentage of revenue. For example, several jurisdictions have proposed or \nenacted taxes applicable to digital services, which include business activities on digital advertising and online marketplaces, \nand which apply to our business.\nThe European Commission has conducted investigations in multiple countries focusing on whether local country tax \nrulings or tax legislation provides preferential tax treatment that violates European Union state aid rules and concluded that \ncertain member states, including Ireland, have provided illegal state aid in certain cases. These investigations may result in \nchanges to the tax treatment of our foreign operations. \nDue to the large and expanding scale of our international business activities, many of these types of changes to the \ntaxation of our activities described above could increase our worldwide effective tax rate, increase the amount of non-income \ntaxes imposed on our business, and harm our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows. Such changes may also \napply retroactively to our historical operations and result in taxes greater than the amounts estimated and recorded in our \nfinancial statements.\nGiven our levels of share-based compensation, our tax rate may vary significantly depending on our stock price.\nThe tax effects of the accounting for share-based compensation may significantly impact our effective tax rate from \nperiod to period. In periods in which our stock price is higher than the grant price of the share-based compensation vesting in \nthat period, we will recognize excess tax benefits that will decrease our effective tax rate. For example, in 2021, excess tax \nbenefits recognized from share-based compensation decreased our provision for income taxes by $1.13 billion and our \neffective tax rate by two percentage points as compared to the tax rate without such benefits. In future periods in which our \nstock price is lower than the grant price of the share-based compensation vesting in that period, our effective tax rate may \nincrease. The amount and value of share-based compensation issued relative to our earnings in a particular period will also \naffect the magnitude of the impact of share-based compensation on our effective tax rate. These tax effects are dependent on \nour stock price, which we do not control, and a decline in our stock price could significantly increase our effective tax rate \nand adversely affect our financial results.\nIf our goodwill or intangible assets become impaired, we may be required to record a significant charge to earnings.\nWe review our intangible assets for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value \nmay not be recoverable, such as a decline in stock price and market capitalization. We test goodwill for impairment at the \nreporting unit level at least annually. If such goodwill or intangible assets are deemed to be impaired, an impairment loss \nequal to the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds the fair value of the assets would be recognized. We may be \nrequired to record a significant charge in our financial statements during the period in which any impairment of our goodwill \n33'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 34}, page_content='or intangible assets is determined, which would negatively affect our results of operations.\nThe loss of one or more of our key personnel, or our failure to attract and retain other highly qualified personnel in the \nfuture, could harm our business.\nWe currently depend on the continued services and performance of our key personnel, including Mark Zuckerberg and \nSheryl K. Sandberg. Although we have entered into employment agreements with Mr. Zuckerberg and Ms. Sandberg, the \nagreements have no specific duration and constitute at-will employment. In addition, many of our key technologies and \nsystems are custom-made for our business by our personnel. The loss of key personnel, including members of management as \nwell as key engineering, product development, marketing, and sales personnel, could disrupt our operations and have an \nadverse effect on our business.\nAs we continue to grow, we cannot guarantee we will continue to attract and retain the personnel we need to maintain \nour competitive position. In particular, we intend to continue to hire a significant number of technical personnel in the \nforeseeable future, and we expect to continue to face significant challenges in hiring such personnel, particularly for \nengineering talent, whether as a result of competition with other companies or other factors. As we continue to mature, the \nincentives to attract, retain, and motivate employees provided by our equity awards or by future arrangements may not be as \neffective as in the past, and if we issue significant equity to attract additional employees or to retain our existing employees, \nwe would incur substantial additional share-based compensation expense and the ownership of our existing stockholders \nwould be further diluted. Our ability to attract, retain, and motivate employees may also be adversely affected by stock price \nvolatility. In addition, restrictive immigration policies or legal or regulatory developments relating to immigration may \nnegatively affect our efforts to attract and hire new personnel as well as retain our existing personnel. If we do not succeed in \nattracting, hiring, and integrating excellent personnel, or retaining and motivating existing personnel, we may be unable to \ngrow effectively.\nOur CEO has control over key decision making as a result of his control of a majority of the voting power of our \noutstanding capital stock.\nMark Zuckerberg, our founder, Chairman, and CEO, is able to exercise voting rights with respect to a majority of the \nvoting power of our outstanding capital stock and therefore has the ability to control the outcome of matters submitted to our \nstockholders for approval, including the election of directors and any merger, consolidation, or sale of all or substantially all \nof our assets. This concentrated control could delay, defer, or prevent a change of control, merger, consolidation, or sale of all \nor substantially all of our assets that our other stockholders support, or conversely this concentrated control could result in the \nconsummation of such a transaction that our other stockholders do not support. This concentrated control could also \ndiscourage a potential investor from acquiring our Class A common stock, which has limited voting power relative to the \nClass B common stock, and might harm the trading price of our Class A common stock. In addition, Mr. Zuckerberg has the \nability to control the management and major strategic investments of our company as a result of his position as our CEO and \nhis ability to control the election or, in some cases, the replacement of our directors. In the event of his death, the shares of \nour capital stock that Mr. Zuckerberg owns will be transferred to the persons or entities that he has designated. As a board \nmember and officer, Mr. Zuckerberg owes a fiduciary duty to our stockholders and must act in good faith in a manner he \nreasonably believes to be in the best interests of our stockholders. As a stockholder, even a controlling stockholder, \nMr. Zuckerberg is entitled to vote his shares, and shares over which he has voting control as governed by a voting agreement, \nin his own interests, which may not always be in the interests of our stockholders generally.\nWe cannot guarantee that our share repurchase program will be fully consummated or that it will enhance long-term \nstockholder value. Share repurchases could also increase the volatility of the trading price of our stock and will diminish \nour cash reserves.\nAlthough our board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program that does not have an expiration date, the \nprogram does not obligate us to repurchase any specific dollar amount or to acquire any specific number of shares of our \nClass A common stock. We cannot guarantee that the program will be fully consummated or that it will enhance long-term \nstockholder value. The program could affect the trading price of our stock and increase volatility, and any announcement of a \ntermination of this program may result in a decrease in the trading price of our stock. In addition, this program will diminish \nour cash reserves.\n34'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 35}, page_content='Risks Related to Government Regulation and Enforcement\nActions by governments that restrict access to Facebook or our other products in their countries, censor or moderate \ncontent on our products in their countries, or otherwise impair our ability to sell advertising in their countries, could \nsubstantially harm our business and financial results.\nGovernments from time to time seek to censor or moderate content available on Facebook or our other products in \ntheir country, restrict access to our products from their country partially or entirely, or impose other restrictions that may \naffect the accessibility of our products in their country for an extended period of time or indefinitely. For example, user \naccess to Facebook and certain of our other products has been or is currently restricted in whole or in part in China, Iran, and \nNorth Korea. In addition, government authorities in other countries may seek to restrict user access to our products if they \nconsider us to be in violation of their laws or a threat to public safety or for other reasons, and certain of our products have \nbeen restricted by governments in other countries from time to time. For example, in June 2020, Hong Kong adopted a \nNational Security Law that provides authorities with the ability to obtain information, remove and block access to content, \nand suspend user services, and if we are found to be in violation of this law then the use of our products may be restricted. In \naddition, if we are required to or elect to make changes to our marketing and sales or other operations in Hong Kong as a \nresult of the National Security Law, our revenue and business in the region will be adversely affected. It is also possible that \ngovernment authorities could take action that impairs our ability to sell advertising, including in countries where access to our \nconsumer-facing products may be blocked or restricted. For example, we generate meaningful revenue from a limited number \nof resellers representing advertisers based in China, and it is possible that the Chinese government could take action that \nreduces or eliminates our China-based advertising revenue, whether as a result of the trade dispute with the United States, in \nresponse to content issues or information requests in Hong Kong or elsewhere, or for other reasons, or take other action \nagainst us, such as imposing taxes or other penalties, which could adversely affect our financial results. Similarly, if we are \nfound to be out of compliance with certain legal requirements for social media companies in Turkey, the Turkish government \ncould take action to reduce or eliminate our Turkey-based advertising revenue or otherwise adversely impact access to our \nproducts. In the event that content shown on Facebook or our other products is subject to censorship, access to our products is \nrestricted, in whole or in part, in one or more countries, we are required to or elect to make changes to our operations, or other \nrestrictions are imposed on our products, or our competitors are able to successfully penetrate new geographic markets or \ncapture a greater share of existing geographic markets that we cannot access or where we face other restrictions, our ability to \nretain or increase our user base, user engagement, or the level of advertising by marketers may be adversely affected, we may \nnot be able to maintain or grow our revenue as anticipated, and our financial results could be adversely affected.\nOur business is subject to complex and evolving U.S. and foreign laws and regulations regarding privacy, data use and \ndata protection, content, competition, safety and consumer protection, e-commerce, and other matters. Many of these laws \nand regulations are subject to change and uncertain interpretation, and could result in claims, changes to our products \nand business practices, monetary penalties, increased cost of operations, or declines in user growth or engagement, or \notherwise harm our business.\nWe are subject to a variety of laws and regulations in the United States and abroad that involve matters central to our \nbusiness, including privacy, data use, data protection and personal information, biometrics, encryption, rights of publicity, \ncontent, intellectual property, advertising, marketing, distribution, data security, data retention and deletion, data localization \nand storage, data disclosure, artificial intelligence, electronic contracts and other communications, competition, protection of \nminors, consumer protection, civil rights, telecommunications, product liability, e-commerce, taxation, economic or other \ntrade controls including sanctions, anti-corruption and political law compliance, securities law compliance, and online \npayment services. The introduction of new products, expansion of our activities in certain jurisdictions, or other actions that \nwe may take may subject us to additional laws, regulations, or other government scrutiny. In addition, foreign data protection, \nprivacy, content, competition, consumer protection, and other laws and regulations can impose different obligations or be \nmore restrictive than those in the United States.\nThese U.S. federal and state and foreign laws and regulations, which in some cases can be enforced by private parties \nin addition to government entities, are constantly evolving and can be subject to significant change. As a result, the \napplication, interpretation, and enforcement of these laws and regulations are often uncertain, particularly in the new and \nrapidly evolving industry in which we operate, and may be interpreted and applied inconsistently from country to country and \ninconsistently with our current policies and practices. For example, regulatory or legislative actions affecting the manner in \nwhich we display content to our users or obtain consent to various practices could adversely affect user growth and \nengagement. Such actions could affect the manner in which we provide our services or adversely affect our financial results.\n35'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 36}, page_content="We are also subject to evolving laws and regulations that dictate whether, how, and under what circumstances we can \ntransfer, process and/or receive certain data that is critical to our operations, including data shared between countries or \nregions in which we operate and data shared among our products and services. For example, in 2016, the European Union \nand United States agreed to a transfer framework for data transferred from the European Union to the United States, called \nthe Privacy Shield, but the Privacy Shield was invalidated in July 2020 by the Court of Justice of the European Union \n(CJEU). In addition, the other bases upon which Meta relies to transfer such data, such as Standard Contractual Clauses \n(SCCs), have been subjected to regulatory and judicial scrutiny. For example, the CJEU considered the validity of SCCs as a \nbasis to transfer user data from the European Union to the United States following a challenge brought by the Irish Data \nProtection Commission (IDPC). Although the CJEU upheld the validity of SCCs in July 2020, our continued reliance on \nSCCs will be the subject of future regulatory consideration. In particular, in August 2020, we received a preliminary draft \ndecision from the IDPC that preliminarily concluded that Meta Platforms Ireland's reliance on SCCs in respect of European \nuser data does not achieve compliance with the GDPR and preliminarily proposed that such transfers of user data from the \nEuropean Union to the United States should therefore be suspended. Meta Platforms Ireland challenged procedural aspects of \nthis IDPC inquiry in a judicial review commenced in the Irish High Court in September 2020. In May 2021, the court rejected \nMeta Platforms Ireland's procedural challenges and the inquiry subsequently recommenced. We believe a final decision in \nthis inquiry may issue as early as the first half of 2022. If a new transatlantic data transfer framework is not adopted and we \nare unable to continue to rely on SCCs or rely upon other alternative means of data transfers from Europe to the United \nStates, we will likely be unable to offer a number of our most significant products and services, including Facebook and \nInstagram, in Europe, which would materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of \noperations. In addition, we have been managing investigations and lawsuits in Europe, India, and other jurisdictions regarding \nthe August 2016 update to WhatsApp's terms of service and privacy policy and its sharing of certain data with other Meta \nproducts and services, including a lawsuit currently pending before the Supreme Court of India, and also became subject to \ngovernment inquiries and lawsuits regarding the 2021 update to WhatsApp's terms of service and privacy policy. If we are \nunable to transfer data between and among countries and regions in which we operate, or if we are restricted from sharing \ndata among our products and services, it could affect our ability to provide our services, the manner in which we provide our \nservices or our ability to target ads, which could adversely affect our financial results.\nWe have been subject to other significant legislative and regulatory developments in the past, and proposed or new \nlegislation and regulations could significantly affect our business in the future. For example, we have implemented a number \nof product changes and controls as a result of requirements under the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), \nand may implement additional changes in the future. The GDPR also requires submission of personal data breach \nnotifications to our lead European Union privacy regulator, the IDPC, and includes significant penalties for non-compliance \nwith the notification obligation as well as other requirements of the regulation. The GDPR is still a relatively new law, its \ninterpretation is still evolving, and draft decisions in investigations by the IDPC are subject to review by other European \nprivacy regulators as part of the GDPR's consistency mechanism, which may lead to significant changes in the final outcome \nof such investigations. As a result, the interpretation and enforcement of the GDPR, as well as the imposition and amount of \npenalties for non-compliance, are subject to significant uncertainty. In addition, Brazil, the United Kingdom, and other \ncountries have enacted similar data protection regulations imposing data privacy-related requirements on products and \nservices offered to users in their respective jurisdictions. The California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), which took effect in \nJanuary 2020, and its successor, the California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA), which will take effect in January 2023, also \nestablish certain transparency rules and create new data privacy rights for users, including limitations on our use of certain \nsensitive personal information and more ability for users to control how their data is shared with third parties. These laws and \nregulations are evolving and subject to interpretation, and resulting limitations on our advertising services, or reductions of \nadvertising by marketers, have to some extent adversely affected, and will continue to adversely affect, our advertising \nbusiness. For example, regulators continue to issue guidance concerning the ePrivacy Directive's requirements regarding the \nuse of cookies and similar technologies. In addition, effective December 2020, the ePrivacy Directive includes additional \nlimitations on the use of data across messaging products and includes significant penalties for non-compliance. Changes to \nour products or business practices as a result of these or similar developments may adversely affect our advertising business. \nSimilarly, there are a number of legislative proposals in the European Union, the United States, at both the federal and state \nlevel, as well as other jurisdictions that could impose new obligations or limitations in areas affecting our business. For \nexample, the proposed Digital Markets Act in the European Union and pending proposals to modify competition laws in the \nUnited States and other jurisdictions could cause us to incur significant compliance costs and could potentially impose new \nrestrictions and requirements on companies like ours, including in areas such as the combination of data across services, \nmergers and acquisitions, and product design. In addition, some countries, such as India, are considering or have passed \nlegislation implementing data protection requirements or requiring local storage and processing of data or similar \n36"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 37}, page_content="requirements that could increase the cost and complexity of delivering our services. New legislation or regulatory decisions \nthat restrict our ability to collect and use information about minors may also result in limitations on our advertising services \nor our ability to offer products and services to minors in certain jurisdictions.\nThese laws and regulations, as well as any associated claims, inquiries, or investigations or any other government \nactions, have in the past led to, and may in the future lead to, unfavorable outcomes including increased compliance costs, \ndelays or impediments in the development of new products, negative publicity and reputational harm, increased operating \ncosts, diversion of management time and attention, and remedies that harm our business, including fines or demands or orders \nthat we modify or cease existing business practices.\nWe have been subject to regulatory and other government investigations, enforcement actions, and settlements, and we \nexpect to continue to be subject to such proceedings and other inquiries in the future, which could cause us to incur \nsubstantial costs or require us to change our business practices in a manner materially adverse to our business. \nWe receive formal and informal inquiries from government authorities and regulators regarding our compliance with \nlaws and regulations, many of which are evolving and subject to interpretation. We are and expect to continue to be the \nsubject of investigations, inquiries, data requests, requests for information, actions, and audits in the United States, Europe, \nand around the world, particularly in the areas of privacy, data protection, law enforcement, consumer protection, civil rights, \ncontent moderation, and competition, as we continue to grow and expand our operations. In addition, we are currently, and \nmay in the future be, subject to regulatory orders or consent decrees. For example, data protection, competition, and \nconsumer protection authorities in the European Union and other jurisdictions have initiated actions, investigations, or \nadministrative orders seeking to restrict the ways in which we collect and use information, or impose sanctions, and other \nauthorities may do the same. In addition, beginning in March 2018, we became subject to FTC, state attorneys general, and \nother government inquiries in the United States, Europe, and other jurisdictions in connection with our platform and user data \npractices as well as the misuse of certain data by a developer that shared such data with third parties in violation of our terms \nand policies. In July 2019, we entered into a settlement and modified consent order to resolve the FTC inquiry, which was \napproved by the federal court and took effect in April 2020. Among other matters, our settlement with the FTC required us to \npay a penalty of $5.0 billion and to significantly enhance our practices and processes for privacy compliance and oversight. \nThe state attorneys general inquiry and certain government inquiries in other jurisdictions remain ongoing. Beginning in \nSeptember 2018, we also became subject to IDPC and other government inquiries in connection with a third-party cyber-\nattack that exploited a vulnerability in Facebook's code to steal user access tokens and access certain profile information from \nuser accounts on Facebook. We also notify the IDPC, our lead European Union privacy regulator under the GDPR, of certain \nother personal data breaches and privacy issues, and are subject to inquiries and investigations by the IDPC and other \nEuropean regulators regarding various aspects of our regulatory compliance. \nIn addition, we are subject to various litigation and formal and informal inquiries and investigations by competition \nauthorities in the United States, Europe, and other jurisdictions, which relate to many aspects of our business, including with \nrespect to users and advertisers, as well as our industry. Such inquiries, investigations, and lawsuits concern, among other \nthings, our business practices in the areas of social networking or social media services, digital advertising, and/or mobile or \nonline applications, as well as our acquisitions. For example, in June 2019 we were informed by the FTC that it had opened \nan antitrust investigation of our company. In addition, beginning in the third quarter of 2019, we became the subject of \nantitrust inquiries and investigations by the U.S. Department of Justice and state attorneys general. Beginning in December \n2020, we also became subject to lawsuits by the FTC and the attorneys general from 46 states, the territory of Guam, and the \nDistrict of Columbia in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia alleging that we violated antitrust laws, including \nby acquiring Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 and by maintaining conditions on access to our platform, among other \nthings. The complaints of the FTC and attorneys general both sought a permanent injunction against our company's alleged \nviolations of the antitrust laws, and other equitable relief, including divestiture or reconstruction of Instagram and WhatsApp. \nWe are also subject to other government inquiries and investigations relating to our business activities and disclosure \npractices. For example, beginning in September 2021, we became subject to government investigations and requests relating \nto allegations and the release of internal company documents by a former employee.\nOrders issued by, or inquiries or enforcement actions initiated by, government or regulatory authorities could cause us \nto incur substantial costs, expose us to unanticipated civil and criminal liability or penalties (including substantial monetary \nremedies), interrupt or require us to change our business practices in a manner materially adverse to our business, result in \nnegative publicity and reputational harm, divert resources and the time and attention of management from our business, or \nsubject us to other structural or behavioral remedies that adversely affect our business, and we have experienced some of \n37"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 38}, page_content='these adverse effects to varying degrees from time to time.\nCompliance with our FTC consent order, the GDPR, the CCPA, the ePrivacy Directive, and other regulatory and \nlegislative privacy requirements require significant operational resources and modifications to our business practices, and \nany compliance failures may have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, and financial results.\nWe are engaged in ongoing privacy compliance and oversight efforts, including in connection with our modified \nconsent order with the FTC, requirements of the GDPR, and other regulatory and legislative requirements around the world, \nsuch as the CCPA and the ePrivacy Directive.
