In particular, we are maintaining a comprehensive privacy program in \nconnection with the FTC consent order that includes substantial management and board of directors oversight, stringent \noperational requirements and reporting obligations, prohibitions against making misrepresentations relating to user data, a \nprocess to regularly certify our compliance with the privacy program to the FTC, and regular assessments of our privacy \nprogram by an independent third-party assessor, which has been and will continue to be challenging and costly to maintain \nand enhance. These compliance and oversight efforts are increasing demand on our systems and resources, and require \nsignificant new and ongoing investments, including investments in compliance processes, personnel, and technical \ninfrastructure. We are reallocating resources internally to assist with these efforts, and this has had, and will continue to have, \nan adverse impact on our other business initiatives. In addition, these efforts require substantial modifications to our business \npractices and make some practices such as product and ads development more difficult, time-consuming, and costly. As a \nresult, we believe our ability to develop and launch new features, products, and services in a timely manner has been and will \ncontinue to be adversely affected. We also expect that our privacy compliance and oversight efforts will require significant \ntime and attention from our management and board of directors. The requirements of the FTC consent order and other \nprivacy-related laws and regulations are complex and apply broadly to our business, and from time to time we notify relevant \nauthorities of instances where we are not in full compliance with these requirements or otherwise discover privacy issues, and \nwe expect to continue to do so as any such issues arise in the future. In addition, regulatory and legislative privacy \nrequirements are constantly evolving and can be subject to significant change and uncertain interpretation. If we are unable to \nsuccessfully implement and comply with the mandates of the FTC consent order, GDPR, CCPA, ePrivacy Directive, or other \nregulatory or legislative requirements, or if we are found to be in violation of the consent order or other applicable \nrequirements, we may be subject to regulatory or governmental investigations or lawsuits, which may result in significant \nmonetary fines, judgments, or other penalties, and we may also be required to make additional changes to our business \npractices. Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, and financial results.\nWe may incur liability as a result of information retrieved from or transmitted over the internet or published using our \nproducts or as a result of claims related to our products, and legislation regulating content on our platform may require us \nto change our products or business practices and may adversely affect our business and financial results.\nWe have faced, currently face, and will continue to face claims relating to information or content that is published or \nmade available on our products, including our policies and enforcement actions with respect to such information or content. \nIn particular, the nature of our business exposes us to claims related to defamation, dissemination of misinformation or news \nhoaxes, discrimination, harassment, intellectual property rights, rights of publicity and privacy, personal injury torts, laws \nregulating hate speech or other types of content, online safety, consumer protection, and breach of contract, among others. \nThis risk is enhanced in certain jurisdictions outside the United States where our protection from liability for third-party \nactions may be unclear or where we may be less protected under local laws than we are in the United States. For example, in \nApril 2019, the European Union passed a directive (the European Copyright Directive) expanding online platform liability for \ncopyright infringement and regulating certain uses of news content online, which member states are currently implementing \ninto their national laws. In addition, the European Union revised the European Audiovisual Media Service Directive to apply \nto online video-sharing platforms, which member states are expected to implement by 2021. In the United States, there have \nbeen, and continue to be, various legislative and executive efforts to remove or restrict the scope of the protections available \nto online platforms under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, as well as to impose new obligations on online \nplatforms with respect to commerce listings, user content, counterfeit goods and copyright-infringing material, and our \ncurrent protections from liability for third-party content in the United States could decrease or change. We could incur \nsignificant costs investigating and defending such claims and, if we are found liable, significant damages. We could also face \nfines, orders restricting or blocking our services in particular geographies, or other government-imposed remedies as a result \nof content hosted on our services. For example, legislation in Germany and India has resulted in the past, and may result in \nthe future, in the imposition of fines or other penalties for failure to comply with certain content removal, law enforcement \ncooperation, and disclosure obligations. Numerous other countries in Europe, the Middle East, Asia-Pacific, and Latin \nAmerica are considering or have implemented similar legislation imposing potentially significant penalties, including fines, \n38'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 39}, page_content="service throttling, or advertising bans, for failure to remove certain types of content or follow certain processes. For example, \nwe have been subject to fines and may in the future be subject to other penalties in connection with social media legislation in \nRussia and Turkey. Content-related legislation also has required us in the past, and may require us in the future, to change our \nproducts or business practices, increase our costs, or otherwise impact our operations or our ability to provide services in \ncertain geographies. For example, the European Copyright Directive requires certain online services to obtain authorizations \nfor copyrighted content or to implement measures to prevent the availability of that content, which may require us to make \nsubstantial investments in compliance processes. Member states' laws implementing the European Copyright Directive may \nalso require online platforms to pay for content. In addition, our compliance costs may significantly increase as a result of the \nDigital Services Act proposed in the European Union, which is expected to take effect in 2023, and other content-related \nlegislative developments such as online safety bills in Ireland and the United Kingdom. In the United States, changes to \nSection 230 of the Communications Decency Act or new state or federal content-related legislation may increase our costs or \nrequire significant changes to our products, business practices, or operations, which could adversely affect user growth and \nengagement. Any of the foregoing events could adversely affect our business and financial results.\nPayment transactions may subject us to additional regulatory requirements and other risks that could be costly and \ndifficult to comply with or that could harm our business.\nSeveral of our products offer Payments functionality, including enabling our users to purchase virtual and digital \ngoods from developers that offer applications using our Payments infrastructure, send money to other users, and make \ndonations to certain charitable organizations, among other activities. We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations in the \nUnited States, Europe, and elsewhere, including those governing anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing, \nmoney transmission, stored value, gift cards and other prepaid access instruments, electronic funds transfer, virtual currency, \nconsumer protection, charitable fundraising, trade sanctions, and import and export restrictions. Depending on how our \nPayments products evolve, we may also be subject to other laws and regulations including those governing gambling, \nbanking, and lending. In some jurisdictions, the application or interpretation of these laws and regulations is not clear. To \nincrease flexibility in how our use of Payments may evolve and to mitigate regulatory uncertainty, we have received certain \npayments licenses in the United States, the European Economic Area, and other jurisdictions, which will generally require us \nto demonstrate compliance with many domestic and foreign laws in these areas. Our efforts to comply with these laws and \nregulations could be costly and result in diversion of management time and effort and may still not guarantee compliance. In \nthe event that we are found to be in violation of any such legal or regulatory requirements, we may be subject to monetary \nfines or other penalties such as a cease and desist order, or we may be required to make product changes, any of which could \nhave an adverse effect on our business and financial results.\nIn addition, we are subject to a variety of additional risks as a result of Payments transactions, including: increased \ncosts and diversion of management time and effort and other resources to deal with bad transactions or customer disputes; \npotential fraudulent or otherwise illegal activity by users, developers, employees, or third parties; restrictions on the \ninvestment of consumer funds used to transact Payments; and additional disclosure and reporting requirements. We have also \nlaunched certain payments functionality on WhatsApp and have announced plans to develop digital payments products and \nservices, which may subject us to many of the foregoing risks and additional licensing requirements.\nOur digital payments initiatives subject us to significant regulatory scrutiny and other risks that could adversely affect our \nbusiness, reputation, or financial results.\nWe are pursuing digital payments initiatives, such as Novi, a digital wallet that we expect to offer as both a standalone \napplication and subsequently integrated in other Meta products. These initiatives may use blockchain-based assets, such as \nthe USDP stablecoin issued by Paxos Trust Company, which is being used in a Novi pilot program in the United States and \nGuatemala beginning in October 2021. Our future initiatives to support commerce in the metaverse also may use blockchain-\nbased assets in digital payments. Use of blockchain-based assets in payments are a relatively new and unproven technology, \nand the laws and regulations surrounding them are uncertain and evolving. These digital payments efforts have drawn \nsignificant scrutiny from governments and regulators in multiple jurisdictions and we expect that scrutiny to continue. We are \nparticipating in responses to inquiries from governments and regulators related to our digital payments initiatives, and \nadverse government or regulatory actions or negative publicity resulting from such participation may adversely affect our \nreputation and harm our business.\nAs our digital payments initiatives evolve, we may be subject to a variety of laws and regulations in the United States \nand international jurisdictions, including those governing payments, financial services, virtual currency, anti-money \n39"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 40}, page_content="laundering, counter-terrorism financing, trade sanctions, data protection, tax, consumer protection, and competition. In addition, computer malware, viruses, social engineering (such as \nspear phishing attacks), scraping, and general hacking continue to be prevalent in our industry, have occurred on our systems \nin the past, and will occur on our systems in the future. We also regularly encounter attempts to create false or undesirable \nuser accounts, purchase ads, or take other actions on our platform for purposes such as spamming, spreading misinformation, \nor other objectionable ends. Because of the \nten-to-one voting ratio between our Class B and Class A common stock, the holders of our Class B common stock \ncollectively control a majority of the combined voting power of our common stock and therefore are able to control all \nmatters submitted to our stockholders for approval so long as the shares of Class B common stock represent at least 9.1% of \nall outstanding shares of our Class A and Class B common stock. Unresolved Staff Comments \nNone.\nItem 2. Properties\nOur corporate headquarters are located in Menlo Park, California. As of December 31, 2021, we owned and leased \napproximately 10 million square feet of office and building space for our corporate headquarters and in the surrounding areas, \nand approximately 69 acres of land to be developed to accommodate anticipated future growth.\nIn addition, we have offices in more than 80 cities across North America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia \nPacific, and Latin America. We also own 18 data centers globally.\nWe believe that our facilities are adequate for our current needs.\nItem 3. Legal Proceedings\nBeginning on March 20, 2018, multiple putative class actions and derivative actions were filed in state and federal \ncourts in the United States and elsewhere against us and certain of our directors and officers alleging violations of securities \nlaws, breach of fiduciary duties, and other causes of action in connection with our platform and user data practices as well as \nthe misuse of certain data by a developer that shared such data with third parties in violation of our terms and policies, and \nseeking unspecified damages and injunctive relief. Beginning on July 27, 2018, two putative class actions were filed in \nfederal court in the United States against us and certain of our directors and officers alleging violations of securities laws in \nconnection with the disclosure of our earnings results for the second quarter of 2018 and seeking unspecified damages. These \ntwo actions subsequently were transferred and consolidated in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California \nwith the putative securities class action described above relating to our platform and user data practices. On September 25, \n2019, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the consolidated putative securities class action, with leave to amend. \nOn November 15, 2019, a second amended complaint was filed in the consolidated putative securities class action. On \nAugust 7, 2020, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the second amended complaint, with leave to amend. On \nOctober 16, 2020, a third amended complaint was filed in the consolidated putative securities class action. On December 20, \n2021, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the third amended complaint, with prejudice. On January 17, 2022, the \nplaintiffs filed a notice of appeal of the order dismissing their case. In addition, our platform and user data practices, as well \nas the events surrounding the misuse of certain data by a developer, became the subject of U.S. Federal Trade Commission \n(FTC), state attorneys general, and other government inquiries in the United States, Europe, and other jurisdictions. We \nentered into a settlement and modified consent order to resolve the FTC inquiry, which took effect in April 2020 and required \nus to pay a penalty of $5.0 billion and to significantly enhance our practices and processes for privacy compliance and \noversight. The state attorneys general inquiry and certain government inquiries in other jurisdictions remain ongoing and \ncould subject us to additional substantial fines and costs, require us to change our business practices, divert resources and the \nattention of management from our business, or adversely affect our business. On July 16, 2021, a stockholder derivative \naction was filed in Delaware Chancery Court against certain of our directors and officers asserting breach of fiduciary duty \nand related claims relating to our historical platform and user data practices, as well as our settlement with the FTC. On \nJuly 20, 2021, other stockholders filed an amended derivative complaint in a related Delaware Chancery Court action, \nasserting breach of fiduciary duty and related claims against certain of our current and former directors and officers in \nconnection with our historical platform and user data practices. On November 4, 2021, the lead plaintiffs filed a second \namended and consolidated complaint in the stockholder derivative action. We believe the lawsuits described above are \nwithout merit, and we are vigorously defending them.\nWe also notify the Irish Data Protection Commission (IDPC), our lead European Union privacy regulator under the \nGeneral Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), of certain other personal data breaches and privacy issues, and are subject to \ninquiries and investigations by the IDPC and other European regulators regarding various aspects of our regulatory \ncompliance. For example, in August 2020, we received a preliminary draft decision from the IDPC that preliminarily \nconcluded that Meta Platforms Ireland's reliance on Standard Contractual Clauses in respect of European user data does not \nachieve compliance with the GDPR and preliminarily proposed that such transfers of user data from the European Union to \nthe United States should therefore be suspended. Meta Platforms Ireland challenged procedural aspects of this IDPC inquiry \nin a judicial review commenced in the Irish High Court in September 2020. On May 14, 2021, the court rejected Meta \nPlatforms Ireland's procedural challenges, and the inquiry subsequently recommenced. Any such inquiries or investigations could subject us to substantial fines and costs, require us to change our \nbusiness practices, divert resources and the attention of management from our business, or adversely affect our business.\nIn addition, we are subject to various litigation and government inquiries and investigations, formal or informal, by \ncompetition authorities in the United States, Europe, and other jurisdictions. Such investigations, inquiries, and lawsuits \nconcern, among other things, our business practices in the areas of social networking or social media services, digital \nadvertising, and/or mobile or online applications, as well as our acquisitions. For example, in June 2019 we were informed by \nthe FTC that it had opened an antitrust investigation of our company. On December 9, 2020, the FTC filed a complaint \nagainst us in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia alleging that we engaged in anticompetitive conduct and \nunfair methods of competition in violation of Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act and Section 2 of the Sherman \nAct, including by acquiring Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 and by maintaining conditions on access to our \nplatform. In addition, beginning in the third quarter of 2019, we became the subject of antitrust investigations by the U.S. \nDepartment of Justice and state attorneys general. On December 9, 2020, the attorneys general from 46 states, the territory of \nGuam, and the District of Columbia filed a complaint against us in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia \nalleging that we engaged in anticompetitive conduct in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act, including by acquiring \nInstagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 and by maintaining conditions on access to our platform. The complaint also \nalleged that we violated Section 7 of the Clayton Act by acquiring Instagram and WhatsApp. The complaints of the FTC and \nattorneys general both sought a permanent injunction against our company\'s alleged violations of the antitrust laws, and other \nequitable relief, including divestiture or reconstruction of Instagram and WhatsApp. On June 28, 2021, the court granted our \nmotions to dismiss the complaints filed by the FTC and attorneys general, dismissing the FTC\'s complaint with leave to \namend and dismissing the attorneys general\'s case without prejudice. On July 28, 2021, the attorneys general filed a notice of \nappeal of the order dismissing their case. On August 19, 2021, the FTC filed an amended complaint, and on October 4, 2021, \nwe filed a motion to dismiss this amended complaint. On January 11, 2022, the court denied our motion to dismiss the FTC\'s \namended complaint. Multiple putative class actions have also been filed in state and federal courts in the United States \nagainst us alleging violations of antitrust laws and other causes of action in connection with these acquisitions and other \nalleged anticompetitive conduct, and seeking damages and unspecified injunctive relief. Several of the cases brought on \nbehalf of certain advertisers and users were consolidated in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. On \nJanuary 14, 2022, the court granted, in part, and denied, in part, our motion to dismiss the consolidated actions. We believe \nthese lawsuits are without merit, and we are vigorously defending them. The result of such litigation, investigations or \ninquiries could subject us to substantial monetary remedies and costs, interrupt or require us to change our business practices, \ndivert resources and the attention of management from our business, or subject us to other structural or behavioral remedies \nthat adversely affect our business.\nWe are also subject to other government inquiries and investigations relating to our business activities and disclosure \npractices. For example, beginning in September 2021, we became subject to government investigations and requests relating \nto a former employee\'s allegations and release of internal company documents concerning, among other things, our \nalgorithms, advertising and user metrics, and content enforcement practices, as well as misinformation and other undesirable \nactivity on our platform, and user well-being. Beginning on October 27, 2021, multiple putative class actions were filed in \nfederal court in the United States against us and certain of our directors and officers alleging violations of securities laws in \nconnection with the same matters. We believe these lawsuits are without merit, and we are vigorously defending them.\nIn addition, we are subject to litigation and other proceedings involving law enforcement and other regulatory \nagencies, including in particular in Brazil, Russia, and other countries in Europe, in order to ascertain the precise scope of our \nlegal obligations to comply with the requests of those agencies, including our obligation to disclose user information in \nparticular circumstances. A number of such instances have resulted in the assessment of fines and penalties against us. We \nbelieve we have multiple legal grounds to satisfy these requests or prevail against associated fines and penalties, and we \nintend to vigorously defend such fines and penalties.\nWe are also party to various other legal proceedings, claims, and regulatory, tax or government inquiries and \ninvestigations that arise in the ordinary course of business, and we may in the future be subject to additional legal \nproceedings and disputes.\nItem 4. Mine Safety Disclosures\nNot applicable.\n47'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 48}, page_content='PART II\nItem 5. Market for Registrant\'s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity \nSecurities\nMarket Information for Common Stock\nOur Class A common stock has been listed on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol "FB" since May 18, \n2012. Prior to that time, there was no public market for our stock. We expect our Class A common stock to cease trading \nunder the symbol "FB" and begin trading under the new symbol, "META," on the Nasdaq Global Select Market in the first \nhalf of 2022.\nOur Class B common stock is not listed on any stock exchange nor traded on any public market.\nHolders of Record\nAs of December 31, 2021, there were 3,258 stockholders of record of our Class A common stock, and the closing price \nof our Class A common stock was $336.35 per share as reported on the Nasdaq Global Select Market. Because many of our \nshares of Class A common stock are held by brokers and other institutions on behalf of stockholders, we are unable to \nestimate the total number of stockholders represented by these record holders. As of December 31, 2021, there were \n32 stockholders of record of our Class B common stock.\nDividend Policy\nWe have never declared or paid any cash dividend on our common stock. We intend to retain any future earnings to \nfinance the operation and expansion of our business and fund our share repurchase program, and we do not expect to pay cash \ndividends in the foreseeable future. \nPurchases of Equity Securities by the Issuer and Affiliated Purchasers\nThe following table summarizes the share repurchase activity for the three months ended December 31, 2021:\nTotal Number of \nShares Purchased (1)\nAverage Price Paid \nPer Share (2)\nTotal Number of Shares \nPurchased as Part of \nPublicly Announced \nPrograms (1)\nApproximate Dollar \nValue of Shares that May \nYet Be Purchased Under \nthe Plans or Programs (1)\n(in thousands) (in thousands) (in millions)\nOctober 1 - 31, 2021 21,703 $ 326.20 21,703 $ 50,893 \nNovember 1 - 30, 2021 21,606 $ 335.09 21,606 $ 43,653 \nDecember 1 - 31, 2021 14,728 $ 329.97 14,728 $ 38,793 \n58,037 58,037 \n_________________________\n(1) Our board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program of our Class A common stock, which commenced in January 2017\nand does not have an expiration date. The timing and actual number of shares repurchased depend on a variety of factors, including\nprice, general business and market conditions, and other investment opportunities, and shares may be repurchased through open\nmarket purchases or privately negotiated transactions, including through the use of trading plans intended to qualify under Rule\n10b5-1 under the Exchange Act.\n(2) Average price paid per share includes costs associated with the repurchases.\nRecent Sale of Unregistered Securities and Use of Proceeds\nRecent Sale of Unregistered Securities \nNone.\n48'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 49}, page_content='Stock Performance Graph\nThis performance graph shall not be deemed "soliciting material" or to be "filed" with the SEC for purposes of Section 18 of \nthe Exchange Act, or otherwise subject to the liabilities under that Section, and shall not be deemed to be incorporated by \nreference into any filing of Meta Platforms, Inc. under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, or the Exchange Act.\nThe following graph shows a comparison of the cumulative total return for our Class A common stock, the Dow Jones \nInternet Composite Index (DJINET), the Standard & Poor\'s 500 Stock Index (S&P 500) and the Nasdaq Composite Index \n(Nasdaq Composite) for the five years ended December 31, 2021. [Reserved]\n49'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 50}, page_content='Item 7. Management\'s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations\nYou should read the following discussion of our financial condition and results of operations in conjunction with our \nconsolidated financial statements and the related notes included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and Supplementary \nData" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K. In addition to our historical consolidated financial information, the following \ndiscussion contains forward-looking statements that reflect our plans, estimates, and beliefs. Our actual results could differ \nmaterially from those discussed in the forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to these differences \ninclude those discussed below and elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, particularly in Part I, Item 1A, "Risk \nFactors." For a discussion of limitations in the measurement of certain of our community metrics, see the section entitled \n"Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.\nTo supplement our consolidated financial statements, which are prepared and presented in accordance with generally \naccepted accounting principles in the United States (GAAP), we present revenue on a constant currency basis and free cash \nflow, which are non-GAAP financial measures. Revenue on a constant currency basis is presented in the section entitled "—\nRevenue— Foreign Exchange Impact on Revenue." To calculate revenue on a constant currency basis, we translated revenue \nfor the full year 2021 using 2020 monthly exchange rates for our settlement or billing currencies other than the U.S. dollar. \nFor a full description of our free cash flow non-GAAP measure, see the section entitled "— Liquidity and Capital Resources\n—Free Cash Flow."\nThese non-GAAP financial measures are not intended to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for, or superior to, \nfinancial information prepared and presented in accordance with GAAP. These measures may be different from non‑GAAP \nfinancial measures used by other companies, limiting their usefulness for comparison purposes. Moreover, presentation of \nrevenue on a constant currency basis is provided for year-over-year comparison purposes, and investors should be cautioned \nthat the effect of changing foreign currency exchange rates has an actual effect on our operating results. We believe these \nnon-GAAP financial measures provide investors with useful supplemental information about the financial performance of our \nbusiness, enable comparison of financial results between periods where certain items may vary independent of business \nperformance, and allow for greater transparency with respect to key metrics used by management in operating our business.\nExecutive Overview of Full Year 2021 Results \nOur key community metrics and financial results for 2021 are as follows:\nFamily of Apps metrics:\n• Family daily active people (DAP) was 2.82 billion on average for December 2021, an increase of 8% year-over-year.\n• Family monthly active people (MAP) was 3.59 billion as of December 31, 2021, an increase of 9% year-over-year.\n• Facebook daily active users (DAUs) were 1.93 billion on average for December 2021, an increase of 5% year-over-\nyear.\n• Facebook monthly active users (MAUs) were 2.91 billion as of December 31, 2021, an increase of 4% year-over-year.\n• Ad impressions delivered across our Family of Apps increased by 10% year-over-year in 2021, and the average price\nper ad increased by 24% year-over-year in 2021.\n50'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 51}, page_content="Consolidated and segment results:\nBeginning in the fourth quarter of 2021, we report our financial results based on two reportable segments: Family of \nApps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL). FoA includes Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, WhatsApp, and other services. RL \nincludes our augmented and virtual reality related consumer hardware, software, and content. \nFamily of Apps Reality Labs Total\nYear Ended \nDecember 31, Year-over-\nYear \n% Change\nYear Ended \nDecember 31, Year-over-\nYear \n% Change\nYear Ended \nDecember 31, Year-over-\nYear \n% Change2021 2020 2021 2020 2021 2020\n(dollars in millions)\nRevenue $ 115,655 $ 84,826 36% $ 2,274 $ 1,139 100% $ 117,929 $ 85,965 37%\nCosts and expenses $ 58,709 $ 45,532 29% $ 12,467 $ 7,762 61% $ 71,176 $ 53,294 34%\nIncome (loss) from operations $ 56,946 $ 39,294 45% $ (10,193) $ (6,623) (54)% $ 46,753 $ 32,671 43%\nOperating margin 49% 46% (448)% (581)% 40% 38%\n• Net income was $39.37 billion with diluted earnings per share of $13.77 for the year ended December 31, 2021.\n• Capital expenditures, including principal payments on finance leases, were $19.24 billion for the year ended\nDecember 31, 2021.\n• Effective tax rate was 16.7% for the year ended December 31, 2021.\n• Cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities were $48.0 billion as of December 31, 2021.\n• Headcount was 71,970 as of December 31, 2021, an increase of 23% year-over-year.\nOur mission is to give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together. All of our products,\nincluding our apps, share the vision of helping to bring the metaverse to life.\nIn 2021, we continued to focus on our main revenue growth priorities: (i) helping marketers use our products to \nconnect with consumers where they are and (ii) making our ads more relevant and effective. We also continued to invest \nbased on the following company priorities: (i) continue making progress on the major social issues facing the internet and our \ncompany, including privacy, safety, and security; (ii) build new experiences that meaningfully improve people's lives today \nand set the stage for even bigger improvements in the future; (iii) keep building our business by supporting the millions of \nbusinesses that rely on our services to grow and create jobs; and (iv) communicate more transparently about what we're doing \nand the role our services play in the world.\nOur advertising revenue growth in the second half of 2021 was adversely affected by reduced marketer spending as a \nresult of limitations on our ad targeting and measurement tools arising from changes to the iOS operating system. We expect \nthat future advertising revenue growth will continue to be adversely affected by these and other limitations on our ad \ntargeting and measurement tools arising from changes to the regulatory environment and third-party mobile operating \nsystems and browsers. \nOur business and results of operations have also been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and the preventative \nmeasures implemented by authorities from time to time to help limit the spread of the illness, which have caused, and are \ncontinuing to cause, business slowdowns or shutdowns in certain affected countries and regions. Beginning in the first quarter \nof 2020, we experienced significant increases in the size and engagement of our active user base across a number of regions \nas a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. More recently, we have seen these pandemic-related trends subside, particularly in \ncertain developed markets. We are unable to predict the impact of the pandemic on user growth and engagement with any \ncertainty and these trends may continue to be subject to volatility.\nThe COVID-19 pandemic has also had a varied impact on the demand for and pricing of our ads from period to period. \nWhile we experienced a reduction in demand and a related decline in pricing during the onset of the pandemic, we believe the \npandemic subsequently contributed to an acceleration in the growth of online commerce, particularly during the second half \nof 2020, and we experienced increasing demand for advertising as a result of this trend. More recently, we believe this \ngrowth has moderated in many regions, which to some extent adversely affected our advertising revenue growth in the \nsecond half of 2021. We may experience reduced advertising demand and related declines in pricing in future periods to the \nextent this trend continues, which could adversely affect our advertising revenue growth. However, the impact of the \n51"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 52}, page_content="pandemic on user growth and engagement, the demand for and pricing of our advertising services, as well as on our overall \nresults of operations, remains highly uncertain for the foreseeable future.\nUser growth and engagement were also impacted by a number of other factors in the second half of 2021. For \nexample, competitive products and services have reduced some users' engagement with our products and services, and in \nresponse to competitive pressures, we have introduced new features such as Reels, which is growing in usage but is not \ncurrently monetized at the same rate as our feed or Stories products. We also saw a deceleration in our community growth \nrates as the size of our community continued to increase. In addition, we experienced year-over-year declines in ad \nimpressions delivered in the United States & Canada region. These trends adversely affected advertising revenue growth in \nthe second half of 2021 and we expect will continue to affect our advertising revenue growth in the foreseeable future. Other \nglobal and regional business and macroeconomic conditions also have had, and we believe will continue to have, an impact \non our user growth and engagement and advertising revenue growth.\nWe anticipate that additional investments in our data center capacity, servers, network infrastructure, and office \nfacilities, as well as scaling our headcount to support our growth, including in our Reality Labs initiatives, will continue to \ndrive expense growth in 2022. We expect 2022 capital expenditures to be in the range of $29-34 billion and total expenses to \nbe in the range of $90-95 billion. In 2022, we also expect that our year-over-year total expense growth rates may significantly \nexceed our year-over-year revenue growth rates, which would adversely affect our operating margin and profitability.\n52"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 53}, page_content='Trends in Our Family Metrics\nThe numbers for our key Family metrics, our DAP, MAP, and average revenue per person (ARPP), do not include \nusers on our other products unless they would otherwise qualify as DAP or MAP, respectively, based on their other activities \non our Family products. \nTrends in the number of people in our community affect our revenue and financial results by influencing the number of \nads we are able to show, the value of our ads to marketers, the volume of Payments transactions, as well as our expenses and \ncapital expenditures. Substantially all of our daily and monthly active people (as defined below) access our Family products \non mobile devices.\n• Daily Active People (DAP).  We define a daily active person as a registered and logged-in user of Facebook,\nInstagram, Messenger, and/or WhatsApp (collectively, our "Family" of products) who visited at least one of these\nFamily products through a mobile device application or using a web or mobile browser on a given day. We do not\nrequire people to use a common identifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our Family, and therefore\nmust seek to attribute multiple user accounts within and across products to individual people. Our calculations of\nDAP rely upon complex techniques, algorithms, and machine learning models that seek to estimate the underlying\nnumber of unique people using one or more of these products, including by matching user accounts within an\nindividual product and across multiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and\ncounting such group of accounts as one person. As these techniques and models require significant judgment, are\ndeveloped based on internal reviews of limited samples of user accounts, and are calibrated against user survey data,\nthere is necessarily some margin of error in our estimates. We view DAP, and DAP as a percentage of MAP, as\nmeasures of engagement across our products. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of\nKey Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.\nDaily\tActive\tPeople\nWorldwide\n(in\tbillions)\n(daily\taverage\tover\tmonth\tended)\n2.26 2.36 2.47 2.54 2.60 2.72 2.76 2.81 2.82\nDec\t31\n2019\nMar\t31\n2020\nJun\t30\n2020\nSep\t30\n2020\nDec\t31\n2020\nMar\t31\n2021\nJun\t30\n2021\nSep\t30\n2021\nDec\t31\n2021\n0.00\n1.00\n2.00\n3.00\nDAP/MAP: 78% 79% 79% 79% 79% 79% 79% 78% 79%\nNote: We report the numbers of DAP and MAP as specific amounts, but these numbers are estimates of the numbers of unique people using our \nproducts and are subject to statistical variances and errors. While we expect the error margin for these estimates to vary from period to period, we \nestimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide MAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user \naccounts within and across products to individual people, and it is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary \nsignificantly from our estimates, potentially beyond our estimated error margins. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of \nKey Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. In the second quarter of 2020, we updated our Family metrics calculations to \nreflect recent data from a periodic WhatsApp user survey and to incorporate certain methodology improvements, and we estimate such updates \ncontributed an aggregate of approximately 40 million DAP to our reported worldwide DAP in June 2020. In the first quarter of 2021, we updated \nour Family metrics calculations to maintain calibration of our models against recent user survey data, and we estimate such update contributed an \naggregate of approximately 60 million DAP to our reported worldwide DAP in March 2021.\nWorldwide DAP increased 8% to 2.82 billion on average during December 2021 from 2.60 billion during December \n2020. \n53'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 54}, page_content='• Monthly Active People (MAP).  We define a monthly active person as a registered and logged-in user of one or more\nFamily products who visited at least one of these Family products through a mobile device application or using a\nweb or mobile browser in the last 30 days as of the date of measurement. We do not require people to use a common\nidentifier or link their accounts to use multiple products in our Family, and therefore must seek to attribute multiple\nuser accounts within and across products to individual people. Our calculations of MAP rely upon complex\ntechniques, algorithms, and machine learning models that seek to estimate the underlying number of unique people\nusing one or more of these products, including by matching user accounts within an individual product and across\nmultiple products when we believe they are attributable to a single person, and counting such group of accounts as\none person. As these techniques and models require significant judgment, are developed based on internal reviews of\nlimited samples of user accounts, and are calibrated against user survey data, there is necessarily some margin of\nerror in our estimates. We view MAP as a measure of the size of our global active community of people using our\nproducts. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of Key Metrics and Other Data" in this\nAnnual Report on Form 10-K.\nMonthly\tActive\tPeople\nWorldwide\n(in\tbillions)\n2.89 2.99 3.14 3.21 3.30 3.45 3.51 3.58 3.59\nDec\t31\n2019\nMar\t31\n2020\nJun\t30\n2020\nSep\t30\n2020\nDec\t31\n2020\nMar\t31\n2021\nJun\t30\n2021\nSep\t30\n2021\nDec\t31\n2021\n0.00\n1.00\n2.00\n3.00\n4.00\nNote: We report the numbers of DAP and MAP as specific amounts, but these numbers are estimates of the numbers of unique people using our \nproducts and are subject to statistical variances and errors. While we expect the error margin for these estimates to vary from period to period, we \nestimate that such margin generally will be approximately 3% of our worldwide MAP. At our scale, it is very difficult to attribute multiple user \naccounts within and across products to individual people, and it is possible that the actual numbers of unique people using our products may vary \nsignificantly from our estimates, potentially beyond our estimated error margins. For additional information, see the section entitled "Limitations of \nKey Metrics and Other Data" in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. In the second quarter of 2020, we updated our Family metrics calculations to \nreflect recent data from a periodic WhatsApp user survey and to incorporate certain methodology improvements, and we estimate such updates \ncontributed an aggregate of approximately 50 million MAP to our reported worldwide MAP in June 2020. In the first quarter of 2021, we updated \nour Family metrics calculations to maintain calibration of our models against recent user survey data, and we estimate such update contributed an \naggregate of approximately 70 million MAP to our reported worldwide MAP in March 2021.\nAs of December 31, 2021, we had 3.59 billion MAP, an increase of 9% from 3.30 billion as of December 31, 2020. \n54'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 55}, page_content='• Average Revenue Per Person (ARPP).  We define ARPP as our total revenue during a given quarter, divided by the\naverage of the number of MAP at the beginning and end of the quarter. While the share of revenue \nfrom users who are not also Facebook or Messenger MAUs has grown over time, we estimate that revenue from users who \nare Facebook or Messenger MAUs represents the substantial majority of our total revenue. See "Average Revenue Per Person \n(ARPP)" above for our estimates of trends in our monetization of our Family products. The geography of our users affects \nour revenue and financial results because we currently monetize users in different geographies at different average rates. Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 59}, page_content='Our revenue by user geography in the charts above is geographically apportioned based on our estimation of the geographic location of our users \nwhen they perform a revenue-generating activity. This allocation differs from our revenue disaggregated by geography disclosure in Note 2 — \nRevenue in our consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and Supplemental Data" where revenue is \ngeographically apportioned based on the addresses of our customers. \nOur annual worldwide ARPU in 2021, which represents the sum of quarterly ARPU during such period, was $40.96, \nan increase of 28% from 2020. For 2021, ARPU increased by 40% in Rest of World, 35% in Europe, 31% in the United \nStates & Canada, and 26% in Asia‑Pacific, as compared with 2020. In addition, user growth was more rapid in geographies \nwith relatively lower ARPU, such as Asia ‑Pacific and Rest of World. We expect that user growth in the future will be \nprimarily concentrated in those regions where ARPU is relatively lower, such that worldwide ARPU may continue to \nincrease at a slower rate relative to ARPU in any geographic region, or potentially decrease even if ARPU increases in each \ngeographic region.\n59'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 60}, page_content='Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates\nOur consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP. The preparation of these \nconsolidated financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, \nliabilities, revenue, costs and expenses, and related disclosures. On an ongoing basis, we evaluate our estimates and \nassumptions based on historical experience and on various other assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the \ncircumstances. Our actual results could differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.\nAn accounting policy is deemed to be critical if the nature of the estimates or assumptions is material due to the levels \nof subjectivity and judgment necessary to account for highly uncertain matters or the susceptibility of such matters to change, \nand the impact of the estimates and assumptions on our consolidated financial statements is material. We believe that the \nassumptions and estimates associated with gross vs. net in revenue recognition, valuation of equity investments, income \ntaxes, loss contingencies, and valuation of long-lived assets including goodwill, intangible assets, and property and \nequipment, and their associated estimated useful lives, when applicable, have the greatest potential impact on our \nconsolidated financial statements. Therefore, we consider these to be our critical accounting policies and estimates. For \nfurther information on all of our significant accounting policies, see Note 1 — Summary of Significant Accounting Policies \nin the accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and \nSupplementary Data" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.\nGross vs. Net in Revenue Recognition\nFor revenue generated from arrangements that involve third parties, there is significant judgment in evaluating whether \nwe are the principal, and report revenue on a gross basis, or the agent, and report revenue on a net basis. In this assessment, \nwe consider if we obtain control of the specified goods or services before they are transferred to the customer, as well as \nother indicators such as the party primarily responsible for fulfillment, inventory risk, and discretion in establishing price. \nThe assessment of whether we are considered the principal or the agent in a transaction could impact our revenue and cost of \nrevenue recognized on the consolidated statements of income. \nValuation of Equity Investments\nFor our equity securities without readily determinable fair values accounted for using the measurement alternative, \ndetermining whether an equity security issued by the same issuer is similar to the equity security we hold may require \njudgment in (a) assessment of differences in rights and obligations associated with the instruments such as voting rights, \ndistribution rights and preferences, and conversion features, and (b) adjustments to the observable price for differences such \nas, but not limited to, rights and obligations, control premium, liquidity, or principal or most advantageous markets. In \naddition, the identification of observable transactions will depend on the timely reporting of these transactions from our \ninvestee companies, which may occur in a period subsequent to when the transactions take place. Therefore, our fair value \nadjustment for these observable transactions may occur in a period subsequent to when the transaction actually occurred. For \nequity investments, we perform a qualitative assessment at each reporting date to determine whether there are triggering \nevents for impairment. The qualitative assessment considers factors such as, but not limited to, the investee\'s financial \ncondition and business outlook; industry and sector performance; regulatory, economic or technological environment; \noperational and financing cash flows; and other relevant events and factors affecting the investee. When indicators of \nimpairment exist, we estimate the fair value of our equity investments using the market approach and/or the income approach \nand recognize impairment loss in the consolidated statements of income if the estimated fair value is less than the carrying \nvalue. Estimating fair value requires judgment and use of estimates such as discount rates, forecast cash flows, holding \nperiod, and market data of comparable companies, among others.\nIncome Taxes\nWe are subject to income taxes in the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions. Significant judgment is \nrequired in determining our provision for income taxes and income tax assets and liabilities, including evaluating \nuncertainties in the application of accounting principles and complex tax laws. \nWe recognize tax benefits from uncertain tax positions only if we believe that it is more likely than not that the tax \nposition will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities based on the technical merits of the position. These \nuncertain tax positions include our estimates for transfer pricing that have been developed based upon analyses of appropriate \n60'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 61}, page_content='arms-length prices. Similarly, our estimates related to uncertain tax positions concerning research and development tax \ncredits are based on an assessment of whether our available documentation corroborating the nature of our activities \nsupporting the tax credits will be sufficient. Although we believe that we have adequately reserved for our uncertain tax \npositions (including net interest and penalties), we can provide no assurance that the final tax outcome of these matters will \nnot be materially different. We make adjustments to these reserves in accordance with the income tax accounting guidance \nwhen facts and circumstances change, such as the closing of a tax audit or the refinement of an estimate. To the extent that \nthe final tax outcome of these matters is different from the amounts recorded, such differences will affect the provision for \nincome taxes in the period in which such determination is made, and could have a material impact on our financial condition \nand operating results.\nLoss Contingencies\nWe are involved in legal proceedings, claims, and regulatory, tax or government inquiries and investigations that arise \nin the ordinary course of business. Certain of these matters include speculative claims for substantial or indeterminate \namounts of damages. Additionally, we are required to comply with various legal and regulatory obligations around the world, \nand we regularly become subject to new laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate. The requirements for \ncomplying with these obligations may be uncertain and subject to interpretation and enforcement by regulatory and other \nauthorities, and any failure to comply with such obligations could eventually lead to asserted legal or regulatory action. With \nrespect to these matters, asserted and unasserted, we evaluate the associated developments on a regular basis and accrue a \nliability when we believe that it is both probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated. If \nwe determine there is a reasonable possibility that we may incur a loss and the loss or range of loss can be reasonably \nestimated, we disclose the possible loss in the accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements to the extent \nmaterial.\nWe review the developments in our contingencies that could affect the amount of the provisions that have been \npreviously recorded, and the matters and related reasonably possible losses disclosed. We make adjustments to our provisions \nand changes to our disclosures accordingly to reflect the merits of our defenses and the impact of negotiations, settlements, \nregulatory proceedings, rulings, advice of legal counsel, and updated information. Significant judgment is required to \ndetermine the probability of loss and the estimated amount of loss, including when and if the probability and estimate has \nchanged for asserted and unasserted matters. Certain factors, in particular, have resulted in significant changes to these \nestimates and judgments in prior quarters based on updated information available. For example, in certain jurisdictions where \nwe operate, fines and penalties may be the result of new laws and preliminary interpretations regarding the basis of assessing \ndamages, which may make it difficult to estimate what such fines and penalties would amount to if successfully asserted \nagainst us. In addition, certain government inquiries and investigations, such as matters before our lead European Union \nprivacy regulator, the IDPC, are subject to review by other regulatory bodies before decisions are finalized, which can lead to \nsignificant changes in the outcome of an inquiry. As a result of these and other factors, we reasonably expect that our \nestimates and judgments with respect to our contingencies may continue to be revised in future quarters. \nThe ultimate outcome of these matters, such as whether the likelihood of loss is remote, reasonably possible, or \nprobable or if and when the reasonably possible range of loss is estimable, is inherently uncertain. Therefore, if one or more \nof these matters were resolved against us for amounts in excess of management\'s estimates of losses, our results of operations \nand financial condition, including in a particular reporting period in which any such outcome becomes probable and \nestimable, could be materially adversely affected. See Note 11 — Commitments and Contingencies and Note 14 — Income \nTaxes of the accompanying notes to our consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements \nand Supplementary Data" and Part I, Item 3, "Legal Proceedings" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for additional \ninformation regarding these contingencies.\nValuation of Long-lived Assets including Goodwill, Intangible Assets, and Property and Equipment and Estimated Useful \nLives \nWe allocate the fair value of purchase consideration to the tangible assets acquired, liabilities assumed, and intangible \nassets acquired based on their estimated fair values. The excess of the fair value of purchase consideration over the fair values \nof these identifiable assets and liabilities is recorded as goodwill to reporting units based on the expected benefit from the \nbusiness combination. Such valuations require management to make significant estimates and assumptions, especially with \nrespect to intangible assets. Significant estimates in valuing certain intangible assets include, but are not limited to, estimated \nreplacement costs and future expected cash flows from acquired users, acquired technology, acquired patents, and trade \nnames from a market participant perspective, useful lives, and discount rates. Management\'s estimates of fair value are based \n61'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 62}, page_content='upon assumptions believed to be reasonable, but which are inherently uncertain and unpredictable and, as a result, actual \nresults may differ from estimates. Allocation of purchase consideration to identifiable assets and liabilities affects our \namortization expense, as acquired finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over the useful life, whereas any indefinite-\nlived intangible assets, including goodwill, are not amortized. During the measurement period, which is not to exceed one \nyear from the acquisition date, we may record adjustments to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, with the \ncorresponding offset to goodwill. Upon the conclusion of the measurement period, any subsequent adjustments are recorded \nto earnings.\nGoodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level annually or more frequently if events or changes in \ncircumstances would more likely than not reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value. We have two \nreporting units subject to goodwill impairment testing. As of December 31, 2021, no impairment of goodwill has been \nidentified.\nLong-lived assets, including property and equipment and finite-lived intangible assets are reviewed for possible \nimpairment whenever events or circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. The \nevaluation is performed at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of \nother assets and liabilities. Recoverability of these assets is measured by a comparison of the carrying amounts to the future \nundiscounted cash flows the assets are expected to generate from the use and eventual disposition. If such review indicates \nthat the carrying amount of property and equipment and intangible assets is not recoverable, the carrying amount of such \nassets is reduced to fair value. We have not recorded any material impairment charges during the years presented.\nThe useful lives of our long-lived assets including property and equipment and finite-lived intangible assets are \ndetermined by management when those assets are initially recognized and are routinely reviewed for the remaining estimated \nuseful lives. The current estimate of useful lives represents our best estimate based on current facts and circumstances, but \nmay differ from the actual useful lives due to changes in future circumstances such as changes to our business operations, \nchanges in the planned use of assets, and technological advancements. When we change the estimated useful life assumption \nfor any asset, the remaining carrying amount of the asset is accounted for prospectively and depreciated or amortized over the \nrevised estimated useful life. \nIn connection with our periodic reviews of the estimated useful lives of property and equipment, we extended the \nestimated average useful lives of our server and network assets category. The effect of the 2021 change was a reduction in \ndepreciation expense of $620 million and an increase in net income of $516 million, or $0.18 per diluted share. The impact \nfrom the changes in our estimates was calculated based on the asset bases existing as of the effective dates of the changes and \napplying the revised useful lives prospectively. See Note 1 — Summary of Significant Accounting Policies in the \naccompanying notes to consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and \nSupplementary Data" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, for additional information regarding changes in the estimated \nuseful lives of our property and equipment.\n62'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 63}, page_content='Components of Results of Operations\nRevenue \nFamily of Apps (FoA)\nAdvertising. We generate substantially all of our revenue from advertising. Our advertising revenue is generated by \ndisplaying ad products on Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and third-party affiliated websites or mobile applications. \nMarketers pay for ad products either directly or through their relationships with advertising agencies or resellers, based on the \nnumber of impressions delivered or the number of actions, such as clicks, taken by users. \nWe recognize revenue from the display of impression-based ads in the contracted period in which the impressions are \ndelivered. Impressions are considered delivered when an ad is displayed to a user. We recognize revenue from the delivery of \naction-based ads in the period in which a user takes the action the marketer contracted for. The number of ads we show is \nsubject to methodological changes as we continue to evolve our ads business and the structure of our ads products. We \ncalculate price per ad as total advertising revenue divided by the number of ads delivered, representing the effective price \npaid per impression by a marketer regardless of their desired objective such as impression or action. For advertising revenue \narrangements where we are not the principal, we recognize revenue on a net basis. \nOther revenue. Other revenue consists of net fees we receive from developers using our Payments infrastructure and \nrevenue from various other sources.\nReality Labs (RL)\nRL revenue is generated from the delivery of consumer hardware products, such as Meta Quest, Facebook Portal, and \nwearables, and related software and content.\nCost of Revenue and Operating Expenses \nCost of revenue. Our cost of revenue consists primarily of expenses associated with the delivery and distribution of \nour products. These include expenses related to the operation of our data centers and technical infrastructure, such as \ndepreciation expense from servers, network infrastructure and buildings, as well as payroll and related expenses which \ninclude share-based compensation for employees on our operations teams, and energy and bandwidth costs. Cost of revenue \nalso includes costs associated with partner arrangements, including traffic acquisition costs and credit card and other fees \nrelated to processing customer transactions; RL cost of products sold; and content costs. \nResearch and development. Research and development expenses consist primarily of payroll and related expenses \nwhich include share-based compensation, facilities-related costs for employees on our engineering and technical teams who \nare responsible for developing new products as well as improving existing products, and professional services. \nMarketing and sales. Marketing and sales expenses consist primarily of marketing and promotional expenses and \npayroll and related expenses which include share-based compensation for our employees engaged in sales, sales support, \nmarketing, business development, and customer service functions. Our marketing and sales expenses also include \nprofessional services such as content reviewers to support our community and product operations.\nGeneral and administrative. General and administrative expenses consist primarily of legal-related costs, which \ninclude accruals for estimated fines, settlements, or other losses in connection with legal and related matters, as well as other \nlegal fees; payroll and related expenses which include share-based compensation for certain of our executives as well as our \nlegal, finance, human resources, corporate communications and policy, and other administrative employees; other taxes, such \nas digital services taxes, other tax levies, and gross receipts taxes; and professional services. \n63'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 64}, page_content='Results of Operations\nIn this section, we discuss the results of our operations for the year ended December 31, 2021 compared to the year \nended December 31, 2020. For comparative purposes, amounts in prior periods have been \nrecast:\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\n2021 vs 2020 \n% Change\n2020 vs 2019 \n% Change\n(dollars in millions)\nAdvertising $ 114,934 $ 84,169 $ 69,655  37 %  21 %\nOther revenue 721 657 541  10 %  21 %\nFamily of Apps 115,655 84,826 70,196  36 %  21 %\nReality Labs 2,274 1,139 501  100 %  127 %\nTotal revenue $ 117,929 $ 85,965 $ 70,697  37 %  22 %\nFamily of Apps\nFoA revenue in 2021 increased $30.83 billion, or 36%, compared to 2020. The increase was mostly driven by an \nincrease in advertising revenue.\nAdvertising\nAdvertising revenue in 2021 increased $30.76 billion, or 37%, compared to 2020 as a result of increases in both the \naverage price per ad and the number of ads delivered. In 2021, the average price per ad increased by 24%, as compared with a \ndecrease of approximately 10% in 2020. The increase in average price per ad in 2021 was mainly caused by a recovery from \ndeclines in advertising demand in the first two quarters of 2020, due to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, \noverall advertising demand increased, as compared to 2020, across our ad products and in all regions in part due to the \ncontinued growth of online commerce. In 2021, the number of ads delivered increased by 10%, as compared with an \napproximate 34% increase in 2020. The increase in the ads delivered in 2021 was driven by increases in users and the number \nand frequency of ads displayed across our products. We anticipate that future advertising revenue growth will be driven by a \ncombination of price and the number of ads delivered. \n65'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 66}, page_content="Reality Labs\nRL revenue increased $1.14 billion, or 100%, from 2020 to 2021, and $638 million, or 127%, from 2019 to 2020. The \nincreases in both periods were mostly driven by increases in the volume of our consumer hardware products sold.\nRevenue Seasonality and Customer Concentration\nRevenue is traditionally seasonally strong in the fourth quarter of each year due in part to seasonal holiday demand. \nWe believe that this seasonality in both advertising revenue and RL consumer hardware sales affects our quarterly results, \nwhich generally reflect significant growth in revenue between the third and fourth quarters and a decline between the fourth \nand subsequent first quarters. For instance, our total revenue increased 16%, 31%, and 19% between the third and fourth \nquarters of 2021, 2020, and 2019, respectively, while total revenue for the first quarters of 2021, 2020, and 2019 declined \n7%, 16%, and 11% compared to the fourth quarters of 2020, 2019, and 2018, respectively. We note the decline in total \nrevenue in the first quarter of 2020 was exacerbated by the non-seasonal impact of the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.\nNo customer represented 10% or more of total revenue during the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020, and 2019.\nForeign Exchange Impact on Revenue \nThe general weakening of the U.S. dollar relative to certain foreign currencies in the full year 2021 compared to the \nsame period in 2020 had a favorable impact on revenue. If we had translated revenue for the full year 2021 using the prior \nyear's monthly exchange rates for our settlement or billing currencies other than the U.S. dollar, our total revenue and \nadvertising revenue would have been $116.29 billion and $113.31 billion, respectively. Using these constant rates, total \nrevenue and advertising revenue would have been $1.64 billion and $1.62 billion lower than actual total revenue and \nadvertising revenue, respectively, for the full year 2021. Using the same constant rates, full year 2021 total revenue and \nadvertising revenue would have been $30.32 billion and $29.15 billion, respectively, higher than actual total revenue and \nadvertising revenue for the full year 2020.\nCost of revenue\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\n2021 vs 2020 \n% Change\n2020 vs 2019 \n% Change\n(dollars in millions)\nCost of revenue $ 22,649 $ 16,692 $ 12,770  36 %  31 %\nPercentage of revenue  19 %  19 %  18 %\nCost of revenue in 2021 increased $5.96 billion, or 36%, compared to 2020. The majority of the increase was due to an \nincrease in Reality Labs cost of products sold and an increase in operational expenses related to our data centers and technical \ninfrastructure, partially offset by a decrease in the depreciation growth rate mostly due to increases in the useful lives of \nservers and network assets. The increase was \nprimarily due to an increase in payroll and related expenses as a result of a 30% growth in employee headcount from \nDecember 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021 in engineering and other technical functions supporting our continued investment \nin our family of products and Reality Labs. To a lesser extent, Realty Labs technology development costs also increased.\nIn 2022, we plan to continue to hire software engineers and other technical employees, and to increase our investment \nto support our research and development initiatives in our family of products and in Reality Labs.\nMarketing and sales\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\n2021 vs 2020 \n% Change\n2020 vs 2019 \n% Change\n(dollars in millions)\nMarketing and sales $ 14,043 $ 11,591 $ 9,876  21 %  17 %\nPercentage of revenue  12 %  13 %  14 %\nMarketing and sales expenses in 2021 increased $2.45 billion, or 21%, compared to 2020.
