The increase was due to an \nincrease in other income from net unrealized gains recognized for our equity investments, partially offset by a decrease in \ninterest income as a result of lower interest rates compared to 2020.\n68'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 69}, page_content='Provision for income taxes\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\n2021 vs 2020 % \nChange\n2020 vs 2019 % \nChange\n(dollars in millions)\nProvision for income taxes $ 7,914 $ 4,034 $ 6,327  96 %  (36) %\nEffective tax rate  16.7 %  12.2 %  25.5 %\nOur provision for income taxes in 2021 increased $3.88 billion, or 96%, compared to 2020, primarily due to an \nincrease in income from operations and the effects of the tax election described below.\nOur effective tax rate in 2021 increased compared to 2020, mostly due to the effects of the tax election described \nbelow and tax effects of a shift in jurisdictional mix of earnings.\nIn the third quarter of 2020, as part of finalizing our U.S. income tax return, we elected to capitalize and amortize \ncertain research and development expenses for U.S. income tax purposes. As a result, we recorded a total of $1.07 billion \nincome tax benefit for the year ended December 31, 2020. \nEffective Tax Rate Items. Our effective tax rate in the future will depend upon the proportion between the following \nitems and income before provision for income taxes: U.S. tax benefits from foreign-derived intangible income, tax effects \nfrom share-based compensation, tax effects of integrating intellectual property from acquisitions, settlement of tax \ncontingency items, tax effects of changes in our business, and the effects of changes in tax law.\nThe accounting for share-based compensation may increase or decrease our effective tax rate based upon the \ndifference between our share-based compensation expense and the deductions taken on our tax return, which depend upon the \nstock price at the time of employee award vesting. If our stock price remains constant to the January 28, 2022 price, and \nabsent U.S. tax legislation changes and other one-time events, we expect our effective tax rate for the full year 2022 to be \nsimilar to the effective tax rate for the full year 2021. This includes the effects of the mandatory capitalization and \namortization of research and development expenses starting in 2022, as required by the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (Tax \nAct). The mandatory capitalization requirement increases our cash tax liabilities but also decreases our effective tax rate due \nto increasing the foreign-derived intangible income deduction. If the mandatory capitalization requirement is deferred, our \neffective tax rate in 2022 could be a few percentage points higher when compared to current law and our cash tax liabilities \ncould be several billion dollars lower.\nIntegrating intellectual property from acquisitions into our business generally involves intercompany transactions that \nhave the impact of increasing our provision for income taxes. Consequently, our provision for income taxes and our effective \ntax rate may initially increase in the period of an acquisition and integration. The magnitude of this impact will depend upon \nthe specific type, size, and taxing jurisdictions of the intellectual property as well as the relative contribution to income in \nsubsequent periods.\nSee Note 14 — Income Taxes in the notes to consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial \nStatements and Supplementary Data" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for additional information regarding income tax \ncontingencies.\n69'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 70}, page_content='Liquidity and Capital Resources\nOur principal sources of liquidity are our cash and cash equivalents, marketable securities, and cash generated from \noperations. Cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities consist mostly of cash on deposit with banks, investments in \nmoney market funds, investments in U.S. government securities, U.S. government agency securities, and investment grade \ncorporate debt securities. Cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities were $48.0 billion as of December 31, 2021, a \ndecrease of $13.96 billion from December 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily due to $44.54 billion for repurchases of our \nClass A common stock, $19.24 billion for capital expenditures, including principal payments on finance leases, and \n$5.51 billion of taxes paid related to net share settlement of employee restricted stock units (RSU) awards, offset by \n$57.68 billion of cash generated from operations for the year ended December 31, 2021.\nCash paid for income taxes was $8.52 billion for the year ended December 31, 2021. As of December 31, 2021, our \nfederal net operating loss carryforward was $10.61 billion and our federal tax credit carryforward was $527 million. We \nanticipate the utilization of a significant portion of these net operating losses and credits within the next two years. \nOur board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program of our Class A common stock, which commenced in \nJanuary 2017 and does not have an expiration date. In 2021, we repurchased and subsequently retired 136 million shares of \nour Class A common stock for $44.81 billion. As of December 31, 2021, $38.79 billion remained available and authorized for \nrepurchases. \nAs of December 31, 2021, $10.61 billion of the $48.0 billion in cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities \nwas held by our foreign subsidiaries. The Tax Act imposed a mandatory transition tax on accumulated foreign earnings and \neliminated U.S. taxes on foreign subsidiary distributions. As a result, earnings in foreign jurisdictions are available for \ndistribution to the U.S. without incremental U.S. taxes.\nWe currently anticipate that our available funds and cash flow from operations will be sufficient to meet our \noperational cash needs and fund our share repurchase program for at least the next 12 months and thereafter for the \nforeseeable future.\nThe following table presents our cash flows (in millions):\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\nNet cash provided by operating activities $ 57,683 $ 38,747 $ 36,314 \nNet cash used in investing activities $ (7,570) $ (30,059) $ (19,864) \nNet cash used in financing activities $ (50,728) $ (10,292) $ (7,299) \nCash Provided by Operating Activities\nCash provided by operating activities during 2021 mostly consisted of $39.37 billion net income adjusted for certain \nnon-cash items, including $9.16 billion of share-based compensation expense and $7.97 billion of depreciation and \namortization. The increase in cash flow from operating activities during 2021 compared to 2020 was primarily due to higher \nnet income as adjusted for certain non-cash items, such as share-based compensation expense and deferred income taxes, \npartially offset by changes in working capital.\nCash Used in Investing Activities\nCash used in investing activities during 2021 primarily consisted of $18.57 billion of purchases of property and \nequipment as we continued to invest in data centers, servers, office facilities, and network infrastructure offset by \n$12.18 billion of net sales and maturities of marketable securities. The decrease in cash used in investing activities during \n2021 compared to 2020 was mostly due to decreases in net purchases of marketable securities and equity investments, \npartially offset by an increase in purchases of property and equipment.\nWe anticipate making capital expenditures of approximately $29 billion to $34 billion in 2022.\n70'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 71}, page_content='Cash Used in Financing Activities\nCash used in financing activities during 2021 mostly consisted of $44.54 billion for repurchases of our Class A \ncommon stock and $5.51 billion of taxes paid related to net share settlement of RSUs. The increase in cash used in financing \nactivities during 2021 compared to 2020 was mostly due to the increase in repurchases of our Class A common stock.\nFree Cash Flow \nIn addition to other financial measures presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we monitor free cash flow (FCF) as \na non-GAAP measure to manage our business, make planning decisions, evaluate our performance, and allocate resources. \nWe define FCF as net cash provided by operating activities reduced by net purchases of property and equipment and principal \npayments on finance leases.\nWe believe that FCF is one of the key financial indicators of our business performance over the long term and provides \nuseful information regarding how cash provided by operating activities compares to the property and equipment investments \nrequired to maintain and grow our business. \nWe have chosen our definition for FCF because we believe that this methodology can provide useful supplemental \ninformation to help investors better understand underlying trends in our business. We use FCF in discussions with our senior \nmanagement and board of directors.\nFCF has limitations as an analytical tool, and you should not consider it in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of \nother GAAP financial measures, such as net cash provided by operating activities. FCF is not intended to represent our \nresidual cash flow available for discretionary expenses. Some of the limitations of FCF are:\n• FCF does not reflect our future contractual commitments; and\n• other companies in our industry present similarly titled measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness\nas comparative measures.\nManagement compensates for the inherent limitations associated with using the FCF measure through disclosure of \nsuch limitations, presentation of our financial statements in accordance with GAAP, and reconciliation of FCF to the most \ndirectly comparable GAAP measure, net cash provided by operating activities, as presented below.\nThe following is a reconciliation of FCF to the most comparable GAAP measure, net cash provided by operating \nactivities (in millions):\nYear Ended December 31,\n2021 2020 2019\nNet cash provided by operating activities $ 57,683 $ 38,747 $ 36,314 \nLess: Purchases of property and equipment (18,567) (15,115) (15,102) \nLess: Principal payments on finance leases (677) (604) (552) \nFree cash flow $ 38,439 $ 23,028 $ 20,660 \nOff-Balance Sheet Arrangements\nAs of December 31, 2021, we did not have any off-balance sheet arrangements that are reasonably likely to have a \nmaterial current or future effect on our financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures, or capital \nresources.\n71'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 72}, page_content='Contractual Obligations\nOur principal commitments consist mostly of obligations under operating leases and other contractual commitments. \nOur operating lease obligations mostly include among others, certain of our offices, data centers, colocations and land. Our \nother contractual commitments are primarily related to our investments in servers, network infrastructure and Reality Labs. \nThe following table summarizes our commitments to settle contractual obligations in cash as of December 31, 2021 (in \nmillions):\nPayment Due by Period \nTotal 2022 2023-2024 2025-2026 Thereafter\nOperating lease obligations, including \nimputed interest(1) $ 25,410 $ 1,559 $ 3,966 $ 3,837 $ 16,048 \nFinance lease obligations, including imputed \ninterest(1) 2,303 678 603 322 700 \nTransition tax payable 1,537 — 848 689 — \nOther contractual commitments 23,080 14,502 5,426 609 2,543 \nTotal contractual obligations $ 52,330 $ 16,739 $ 10,843 $ 5,457 $ 19,291 \n_________________________\n(1) Includes variable lease payments that were fixed subsequent to lease commencement or modification.\nAdditionally, as part of the normal course of business, we may also enter into multi-year agreements to purchase\nrenewable energy that do not specify a fixed or minimum volume commitment or to purchase certain server components that \ndo not specify a fixed or minimum price commitment. These agreements are generally entered into in order to secure either \nvolume or price. Using projected market prices or expected volume consumption, the total estimated spend is approximately \n$8.06 billion. The ultimate spend under these agreements may vary and will be based on prevailing market prices or actual \nvolume purchased.\nOur other liabilities also include $4.40 billion related to the uncertain tax positions as of December 31, 2021. Due to \nuncertainties in the timing of the completion of tax audits, the timing of the resolution of these positions is uncertain and we \nare unable to make a reasonably reliable estimate of the timing of payments in individual years beyond 12 months. As a \nresult, this amount is not included in the above contractual obligations table.\nContingencies\nWe are involved in legal proceedings, claims, and regulatory, tax or government inquiries and investigations. We \nrecord a liability when we believe that it is both probable that a liability has been incurred, and that the amount can be \nreasonably estimated. If we determine there is a reasonable possibility that we may incur a loss and the loss or range of loss \ncan be estimated, we disclose the possible loss in the accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements to the \nextent material. Significant judgment is required to determine both probability and the estimated amount of loss. Such matters \nare inherently unpredictable and subject to significant uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control. Should any of \nthese estimates and assumptions change or prove to be incorrect, it could have a material impact on our results of operations, \nfinancial position, and cash flows.\nSee Note 11 — Commitments and Contingencies and Note 14 — Income Taxes in the notes to our consolidated \nfinancial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and Supplementary Data" and Part I, Item 3, "Legal \nProceedings" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K for additional information regarding contingencies.\nRecently Issued Accounting Pronouncements \nFor further information on recently issued accounting pronouncements, see Note 1 — Summary of Significant \nAccounting Policies in the accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial \nStatements and Supplementary Data" of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.\n72'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 73}, page_content='Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk\nWe are exposed to market risks, including changes to foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, and equity \ninvestment risk.\nForeign Currency Exchange Risk\nWe have foreign currency risks related to our revenue and operating expenses denominated in currencies other than the \nU.S. dollar, primarily the Euro. Accordingly, changes in exchange rates, and in particular a strengthening of the U.S. dollar, \nhave in the past, and may in the future, negatively affect our revenue and other operating results as expressed in U.S. dollars.\nWe have experienced and will continue to experience fluctuations in our net income as a result of transaction gains or \nlosses related to revaluing monetary asset and liability balances that are denominated in currencies other than the functional \ncurrency of the entities in which they are recorded. At this time, we have not entered into, but in the future we may enter into, \nderivatives or other financial instruments in an attempt to hedge our foreign currency exchange risk. It is difficult to predict \nthe effect hedging activities would have on our results of operations. Foreign currency losses of $140 million, $129 million, \nand $105 million were recognized in 2021, 2020, and 2019, respectively, as interest and other income, net in our consolidated \nstatements of income. \nInterest Rate Sensitivity\nOur exposure to changes in interest rates relates primarily to interest earned and market value on our cash and cash \nequivalents and marketable securities.\nOur cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities consist of cash, certificates of deposit, time deposits, money \nmarket funds, U.S. government securities, U.S. government agency securities, and investment grade corporate debt securities. \nOur investment policy and strategy are focused on preservation of capital and supporting our liquidity requirements. Changes \nin U.S. interest rates affect the interest earned on our cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities, and the market \nvalue of those securities. A hypothetical 100 basis point increase in interest rates would have resulted in a decrease of \n$714 million and $794 million in the market value of our available-for-sale debt securities as of December 31, 2021 and \nDecember 31, 2020, respectively. Any realized gains or losses resulting from such interest rate changes would only occur if \nwe sold the investments prior to maturity.\nEquity Investment Risk\nOur equity investments are subject to a wide variety of market-related risks that could have a material impact on the \ncarrying value of our holdings. We continually evaluate our equity investments in privately-held companies. \nOur equity investments are investments in equity securities of privately-held companies without readily determinable \nfair values. We elected to account for most of our equity investments using the measurement alternative, which is cost, less \nany impairment, adjusted for changes in fair value resulting from observable transactions for identical or similar investments \nof the same issuer. We perform a qualitative assessment at each reporting date to determine whether there are triggering \nevents for impairment. The qualitative assessment considers factors such as, but not limited to, the investee\'s financial \ncondition and business outlook; industry and sector performance; economic or technological environment; and other relevant \nevents and factors affecting the investee. Valuations of our equity investments are complex due to the lack of readily \navailable market data and observable transactions. Volatility in the global economic climate and financial markets, including \nrecent and ongoing effects related to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which requires significant judgments, could \nresult in a material impairment charge on our equity investments. Equity investments accounted for under the equity method \nwere immaterial as of December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2020. Our total equity investments had a carrying value of \n$6.78 billion and $6.23 billion as of December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2020, respectively.\nFor additional information about our equity investments, see Note 1 — Summary of Significant Accounting Policies, \nNote 5 — Equity Investments, and Note 6 — Fair Value Measurements in the notes to the consolidated financial statements \nincluded in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and Supplementary Data" and Part II, Item 7, "Management’s Discussion \nand Analysis of Financial Conditions and Results of Operations — Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates" contained in \nthis Annual Report on Form 10-K.\n73'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 74}, page_content="Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data\nMETA PLATFORMS, INC. \nINDEX TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS \nPage\nReports of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm (PCAOB ID No. 42) 75\nConsolidated Financial Statements:\nConsolidated Balance Sheets 79\nConsolidated Statements of Income 80\nConsolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income 81\nConsolidated Statements of Stockholders' Equity 82\nConsolidated Statements of Cash Flows 83\nNotes to Consolidated Financial Statements 85\n74\n"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 75}, page_content='Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm\nTo the Stockholders and the Board of Directors of Meta Platforms, Inc.\nOpinion on the Financial Statements\nWe have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Meta Platforms, Inc. (the Company) as of December 31, \n2021 and 2020, the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders\' equity and cash flows \nfor each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2021, and the related notes (collectively referred to as the \n"consolidated financial statements"). In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material \nrespects, the financial position of the Company at December 31, 2021 and 2020, and the results of its operations and its cash \nflows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2021, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted \naccounting principles. \nWe also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) \n(PCAOB), the Company\'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2021, based on criteria established in \nInternal Control – Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission \n(2013 framework), and our report dated February 2, 2022 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.\nBasis for Opinion\nThese financial statements are the responsibility of the Company\'s management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion \non the Company\'s financial statements based on our audits. We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and \nare required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the \napplicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.\nWe conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB. Those standards require that we plan and perform \nthe audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement, whether due \nto error or fraud. Our audits included performing procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial \nstatements, whether due to error or fraud, and performing procedures that respond to those risks. Such procedures included \nexamining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements. Our audits also \nincluded evaluating the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the \noverall presentation of the financial statements. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. \nCritical Audit Matters\nThe critical audit matters communicated below are matters arising from the current period audit of the financial statements \nthat were communicated or required to be communicated to the Audit & Risk Oversight Committee and that: (1) relate to \naccounts or disclosures that are material to the financial statements and (2) involved our especially challenging, subjective or \ncomplex judgments. The communication of critical audit matters does not alter in any way our opinion on the consolidated \nfinancial statements, taken as a whole, and we are not, by communicating the critical audit matters below, providing separate \nopinions on the critical audit matters or on the accounts or disclosures to which they relate.\n75'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 76}, page_content="Loss Contingencies\nDescription of the \nMatter\nAs described in Note 11 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company is party to various \nlegal proceedings, claims, and regulatory or government inquiries and investigations. The Company \naccrues a liability when it believes a loss is probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated. In \naddition, the Company believes it is reasonably possible that it will incur a loss in some of these \ncases, actions or inquiries described above. When applicable, the Company discloses an estimate of \nthe amount of loss or range of possible loss that may be incurred. However, for certain other matters, \nthe Company discloses that the amount of such losses or a range of possible losses cannot be \nreasonably estimated at this time.\nAuditing the Company's accounting for, and disclosure of, these loss contingencies was especially \nchallenging due to the significant judgment required to evaluate management's assessments of the \nlikelihood of a loss, and their estimate of the potential amount or range of such losses.\nHow We Addressed \nthe Matter in Our \nAudit\nWe obtained an understanding, evaluated the design and tested the operating effectiveness of controls \nover the identification and evaluation of these matters, including controls relating to the Company's \nassessment of the likelihood that a loss will be realized and their ability to reasonably estimate the \npotential range of possible losses. \nTo test the Company's assessment of the probability of incurrence of a loss, whether the loss was \nreasonably estimable, and the conclusion and disclosure regarding any range of possible losses, \nincluding when the Company believes it cannot be reasonably estimated at this time, we read the \nminutes or a summary of the meetings of the committees of the board of directors, read the \nproceedings, claims, and regulatory, or government inquiries and investigations, or summaries as we \ndeemed appropriate, requested and received internal and external legal counsel confirmation letters, \nmet with internal and external legal counsel to discuss the nature of the various matters, and obtained \nrepresentations from management. We also evaluated the appropriateness of the related disclosures \nincluded in Note 11 to the consolidated financial statements.\n76"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 77}, page_content="Uncertain Tax Positions\nDescription of the \nMatter\nAs discussed in Note 14 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company has received certain \nnotices from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) related to transfer pricing agreements with the \nCompany's foreign subsidiaries for certain periods examined. The IRS has stated that it will also \napply its position to tax years subsequent to those examined. If the IRS prevails in its position, it \ncould result in an additional federal tax liability, plus interest and any penalties asserted. The \nCompany uses judgment to (1) determine whether a tax position's technical merits are more-likely-\nthan-not to be sustained and (2) measure the amount of tax benefit that qualifies for recognition.\nAuditing the Company's accounting for, and disclosure of, these uncertain tax positions was \nespecially challenging due to the significant judgment required to assess management's evaluation of \ntechnical merits and the measurement of the tax position based on interpretations of tax laws and \nlegal rulings.\nHow We Addressed \nthe Matter in Our \nAudit\nWe obtained an understanding, evaluated the design and tested the operating effectiveness of controls \nover the Company's process to assess the technical merits of tax positions related to these transfer \npricing agreements and to measure the benefit of those tax positions. \nAs part of our audit procedures over the Company's accounting for these positions, we involved our \ntax professionals to assist with our assessment of the technical merits of the Company's tax positions. \nThis included assessing the Company's correspondence with the relevant tax authorities, evaluating \nincome tax opinions or other third-party advice obtained by the Company, and requesting and \nreceiving confirmation letters from third-party advisors. We also used our knowledge of, and \nexperience with, the application of international and local income tax laws by the relevant income tax \nauthorities to evaluate the Company's accounting for those tax positions. We analyzed the Company's \nassumptions and data used to determine the amount of the federal tax liability recognized and tested \nthe mathematical accuracy of the underlying data and calculations. We also evaluated the \nappropriateness of the related disclosures included in Note 14 to the consolidated financial statements \nin relation to these matters.\n/s/ Ernst & Young LLP \nWe have served as the Company's auditor since 2007.\nRedwood City, California \nFebruary 2, 2022 \n77"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 78}, page_content="Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm\nTo the Stockholders and the Board of Directors of Meta Platforms, Inc.\nOpinion on Internal Control over Financial Reporting\nWe have audited Meta Platforms, Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2021, based on criteria \nestablished in Internal Control – Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the \nTreadway Commission (2013 framework) (the COSO criteria). In our opinion, Meta Platforms, Inc. (the Company) \nmaintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2021, based on the \nCOSO criteria.\nWe also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) \n(PCAOB), the consolidated balance sheets of the Company as of December 31, 2021 and 2020, the related consolidated \nstatements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period \nended December 31, 2021, and the related notes and our report dated February 2, 2022 expressed an unqualified opinion \nthereon.\nBasis for Opinion \nThe Company's management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its \nassessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management's \nReport on Internal Control over Financial Reporting. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's internal \ncontrol over financial reporting based on our audit. We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are \nrequired to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable \nrules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB.\nWe conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB. Those standards require that we plan and perform \nthe audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in \nall material respects.\nOur audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material \nweakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, \nand performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a \nreasonable basis for our opinion.\nDefinition and Limitations of Internal Control Over Financial Reporting \nA company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the \nreliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally \naccepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures \nthat (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and \ndispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to \npermit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and \nexpenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the \ncompany; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or \ndisposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.\nBecause of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, \nprojections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate \nbecause of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.\n/s/ Ernst & Young LLP \nRedwood City, California \nFebruary 2, 2022\n78"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 79}, $ 340 $ 68 $ 43 \nSee Accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.\n84'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 85}, page_content="META PLATFORMS, INC. \nNOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS \nNote 1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies\nOrganization and Description of Business \nWe were incorporated in Delaware in July 2004. In October 2021, we changed our corporate name from Facebook, \nInc. to Meta Platforms, Inc. Our mission is to give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together. \nAll of our products, including our apps, share the vision of helping to bring the metaverse to life.\nWe report our financial results based on two reportable segments: Family of Apps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL). The \nsegment information aligns with how the chief operating decision maker (CODM), who is our Chief Executive Officer \n(CEO), reviews and manages the business. We generate substantially all of our revenue from advertising.\nBasis of Presentation\nWe prepared the consolidated financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles \n(GAAP). The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Meta Platforms, Inc., its subsidiaries where we have \ncontrolling financial interests, and any variable interest entities for which we are deemed to be the primary beneficiary. All \nintercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.\nUse of Estimates\nPreparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires the use of estimates and judgments \nthat affect the reported amounts in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. These estimates form the \nbasis for judgments we make about the carrying values of our assets and liabilities, which are not readily apparent from other \nsources. We base our estimates and judgments on historical information and on various other assumptions that we believe are \nreasonable under the circumstances. GAAP requires us to make estimates and judgments in several areas, including, but not \nlimited to, those related to revenue recognition, valuation of equity investments, income taxes, loss contingencies, valuation \nof long-lived assets including goodwill, intangible assets, and property and equipment, and their associated estimated useful \nlives, credit losses of available-for-sale (AFS) debt securities, credit losses of accounts receivable, fair value of financial \ninstruments, and leases. These estimates are based on management's knowledge about current events and expectations about \nactions we may undertake in the future. Actual results could differ materially from those estimates.\nIn connection with our periodic reviews of the estimated useful lives of property and equipment, we extended the \nestimated average useful lives of selected cohorts of servers and network assets from three years to four years in prior years \nas well as in 2021 as a result of longer refresh cycles in our data centers. Prior year changes individually or in aggregate did \nnot have a material impact to the consolidated financial statements. The effect of the 2021 changes was a reduction in \ndepreciation expense of $620 million and an increase in net income of $516 million, or $0.18 per diluted share for the year \nended December 31, 2021. The impact from the changes in our estimates was calculated based on the asset bases existing as \nof the effective dates of the changes and applying the revised estimated useful lives prospectively.\nRevenue Recognition\nRevenue is recognized when control of the promised goods or services is transferred to our customers, in an amount \nthat reflects the consideration we expect to be entitled to in exchange for those goods or services. \nWe determine revenue recognition by applying the following steps:\n• identification of the contract, or contracts, with a customer;\n• identification of the performance obligations in the contract;\n• determination of the transaction price;\n• allocation of the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract; and\n• recognition of revenue when, or as, we satisfy a performance obligation.\n85"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 86}, page_content='Revenue excludes sales and usage ‑based taxes where it has been determined that we are acting as a pass ‑through \nagent.\nAdvertising\nAdvertising revenue is generated by displaying ad products on Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and third-party \naffiliated websites or mobile applications. Marketers pay for ad products either directly or through their relationships with \nadvertising agencies or resellers, based on the number of impressions delivered or the number of actions, such as clicks, taken \nby our users.\nWe recognize revenue from the display of impression-based ads in the contracted period in which the impressions are \ndelivered. Impressions are considered delivered when an ad is displayed to users. We recognize revenue from the delivery of \naction-based ads in the period in which a user takes the action the marketer contracted for. In general, we report advertising \nrevenue on a gross basis, since we control the advertising inventory before it is transferred to our customers. Our control is \nevidenced by our sole ability to monetize the advertising inventory before it is transferred to our customers. For revenue \ngenerated from arrangements that involve third-party publishers, we evaluate whether we are the principal or the agent, and \nfor those advertising revenue arrangements where we are the agent, we recognize revenue on a net basis.\nWe may accept lower consideration than the amount promised per the contract for certain revenue transactions and \ncertain customers may receive cash-based incentives, credits, or refunds, which are accounted for as variable consideration \nwhen estimating the amount of revenue to recognize. We estimate these amounts and reduce revenue based on the amounts \nexpected to be provided to customers. We believe that there will not be significant changes to our estimates of variable \nconsideration.\nReality Labs Revenue\nRL revenue is generated from the delivery of consumer hardware products, such as Meta Quest, Facebook Portal, and \nwearables, and related software and content.  Revenue is recognized at the time control of the products  is transferred to \ncustomers, which is generally at the time of delivery, in an amount that reflects the consideration RL expects to be entitled to \nin exchange for the products.\nOther Revenue\nOther revenue consists of net fees we receive from developers using our Payments infrastructure and revenue from \nvarious other sources.\nDeferred Revenue and Deposits\nDeferred revenue and deposits mostly consists of billings and payments we receive from marketers in advance of \nrevenue recognition, revenue not yet recognized for unspecified software upgrades and updates for various RL products. \nDeposits relate to unused balances held on behalf of our users who primarily use these balances to make purchases in games \non our platform. Once the unused balance is utilized by a user, the majority of this amount would then be payable to the \ndeveloper and the balance would be recognized as revenue. The increase in the deferred revenue and deposits balance for the \nyear ended December 31, 2021 was driven by cash payments from customers in advance of satisfying our performance \nobligations in RL sales and advertising revenue, offset by revenue recognized that was included in the deferred revenue \nbalance at the beginning of the period.\nOur payment terms vary by the products or services offered. The term between billings and when payment is due is not \nsignificant. For certain products or services and customer types, we require payment before the products or services are \ndelivered to the customer.\nPractical Expedients and Exemptions\nWe expense sales commissions when incurred if the amortization period is one year or less. These costs are recorded \nwithin marketing and sales on our consolidated statements of income.\n86'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 87}, page_content="We do not disclose the value of unsatisfied performance obligations for (i) contracts with an original expected length \nof one year or less and (ii) contracts for which we recognize revenue at the amount to which we have the right to invoice for \nservices performed.\nCost of Revenue\nOur cost of revenue consists primarily of expenses associated with the delivery and distribution of our products. These \ninclude expenses related to the operation of our data centers and technical infrastructure, such as depreciation expense from \nservers, network infrastructure and buildings, as well as payroll and related expenses which include share-based \ncompensation for employees on our operations teams, and energy and bandwidth costs. Cost of revenue also includes costs \nassociated with partner arrangements, including traffic acquisition costs and credit card and other fees related to processing \ncustomer transactions; RL cost of products sold; and content costs.\nContent Costs\nOur content costs are mostly related to payments to content providers from whom we license video and music to \nincrease engagement on the platform. For licensed video, we expense the cost per title when the title is accepted and available \nfor viewing if the capitalization criteria are not met. Video content costs that meet the criteria for capitalization were not \nmaterial to date.\nFor licensed music, we expense the license fees over the contractual license period. Expensed content costs are \nincluded in cost of revenue on the consolidated statements of income.\nSoftware Development Costs\nSoftware development costs, including costs to develop software products or the software component of products to be \nmarketed or sold to external users, are expensed before the software or technology reach technological feasibility, which is \ntypically reached shortly before the release of such products.\nSoftware development costs also include costs to develop software to be used solely to meet internal needs and \napplications used to deliver our services. These software development costs meet the criteria for capitalization once the \npreliminary project stage is complete and it is probable that the project will be completed and the software will be used to \nperform the function intended.\nDevelopment costs that meet the criteria for capitalization were not material to date.\nShare-based Compensation\nShare-based compensation expense consists of the company's restricted stock units (RSUs) expense. RSUs granted to \nemployees are measured based on the grant-date fair value. In general, our RSUs vest over a service period of four years. \nShare-based compensation expense is generally recognized based on the straight-line basis over the requisite service period. \nWe account for forfeitures as they occur.\nIncome Taxes\nWe are subject to income taxes in the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions. Significant judgment is \nrequired in determining our provision for income taxes and income tax assets and liabilities, including evaluating \nuncertainties in the application of accounting principles and complex tax laws.\nWe record a provision for income taxes for the anticipated tax consequences of the reported results of operations using \nthe asset and liability method. Under this method, we recognize deferred income tax assets and liabilities for the expected \nfuture consequences of temporary differences between the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities, as well as \nfor loss and tax credit carryforwards. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using the tax rates that are expected to \napply to taxable income for the years in which those tax assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. We \nrecognize the deferred income tax effects of a change in tax rates in the period of the enactment.\n87"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 88}, page_content="We record a valuation allowance to reduce our deferred tax assets to the net amount that we believe is more likely than \nnot to be realized. We consider all available evidence, both positive and negative, including historical levels of income, \nexpectations and risks associated with estimates of future taxable income and ongoing tax planning strategies in assessing the \nneed for a valuation allowance. \nWe recognize tax benefits from uncertain tax positions only if we believe that it is more likely than not that the tax \nposition will be sustained on examination by the taxing authorities based on the technical merits of the position. These \nuncertain tax positions include our estimates for transfer pricing that have been developed based upon analyses of appropriate \narms-length prices. Similarly, our estimates related to uncertain tax positions concerning research tax credits are based on an \nassessment of whether our available documentation corroborating the nature of our activities supporting the tax credits will \nbe sufficient. Although we believe that we have adequately reserved for our uncertain tax positions (including net interest and \npenalties), we can provide no assurance that the final tax outcome of these matters will not be materially different. We make \nadjustments to these reserves in accordance with the income tax accounting guidance when facts and circumstances change, \nsuch as the closing of a tax audit or the refinement of an estimate. To the extent that the final tax outcome of these matters is \ndifferent from the amounts recorded, such differences will affect the provision for income taxes in the period in which such \ndetermination is made, and could have a material impact on our financial condition and operating results. \nAdvertising Expense\nAdvertising costs are expensed when incurred and are included in marketing and sales expenses on the consolidated \nstatements of income. We incurred advertising expenses of $2.99 billion, $2.26 billion, and $1.57 billion for the years ended \nDecember 31, 2021, 2020, and 2019, respectively.\nCash and Cash Equivalents, Marketable Securities, and Restricted Cash\nCash and cash equivalents consist of cash on deposit with banks and highly liquid investments with maturities of \n90 days or less from the date of purchase.\nWe hold investments in marketable securities, consisting of U.S. government securities, U.S. government agency \nsecurities, and investment grade corporate debt securities. We classify our marketable securities as available-for-sale (AFS) \ninvestments in our current assets because they represent investments of cash available for current operations. Our AFS \ninvestments are carried at estimated fair value with any unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, included in accumulated \nother comprehensive income (loss) in stockholders' equity. AFS debt securities with an amortized cost basis in excess of \nestimated fair value are assessed to determine what amount of that difference, if any, is caused by expected credit losses. \nAllowance for credit losses on AFS debt securities are recognized as a charge in interest and other income, net on our \nconsolidated statements of income, and any remaining unrealized losses, net of taxes, are included in accumulated other \ncomprehensive income (loss) in stockholders' equity. The amounts of credit losses recorded for the years ended December 31, \n2021 and 2020 were not material. There was no impairment charge for any unrealized losses in 2019. We determine realized \ngains or losses on sale of marketable securities on a specific identification method and include such gains or losses in interest \nand other income, net on the consolidated statements of income.\nWe also maintain a multi-currency notional cash pool for our participating entities with a third-party bank provider. \nActual cash balances are not physically converted and are not commingled between participating legal entities. We classify \nthe overdraft balances within accrued expenses and other current liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets. \nWe classify certain restricted cash balances within prepaid expenses and other current assets and other assets on the \nconsolidated balance sheets based upon the term of the remaining restrictions.\nEquity Investments \nOur equity investments are investments in equity securities of privately-held companies without readily determinable \nfair values. We elected to account for most of our equity investments using the measurement alternative, which is cost, less \nany impairment, adjusted for changes in fair value from observable transactions for identical or similar investments of the \nsame issuer as of the respective transaction dates. The change in carrying value, if any, is recognized in interest and other \nincome, net on our consolidated statements of income. We periodically review our equity investments for impairment. If \n88"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 89}, page_content="indicators exist and the estimated fair value of an investment is below the carrying amount, we will write down the \ninvestment to fair value. \nIn addition, we also held equity investments accounted for under the equity method which were immaterial as of \nDecember 31, 2021 and 2020. \nFair Value Measurements\nWe apply fair value accounting for all financial assets and liabilities and non-financial assets and liabilities that are \nrecognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements on a recurring basis. We define fair value as the price that \nwould be received from selling an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at \nthe measurement date. When determining the fair value measurements for assets and liabilities, which are required to be \nrecorded at fair value, we consider the principal or most advantageous market in which we would transact and the market-\nbased risk measurements or assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability, such as risks \ninherent in valuation techniques, transfer restrictions and credit risk. Fair value is estimated by applying the following \nhierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value into three levels and bases the categorization within the \nhierarchy upon the lowest level of input that is available and significant to the fair value measurement:\nLevel 1- Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.\nLevel 2- Observable inputs other than quoted prices in active markets for identical assets and liabilities, quoted prices \nfor identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets, or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by \nobservable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.\nLevel 3- Inputs that are generally unobservable and typically reflect management's estimate of assumptions that market \nparticipants would use in pricing the asset or liability.\nOur cash equivalents and marketable securities are classified within Level 1 or Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy \nbecause their fair value is derived from quoted market prices or alternative pricing sources and models utilizing observable \nmarket inputs.\nOur equity investments accounted for using the measurement alternative are recorded at fair value on a non-recurring \nbasis. When indicators of impairment exist or observable price changes of qualified transactions occur, the respective equity \ninvestment would be classified within Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy because the valuation methods include a \ncombination of the observable transaction price at the transaction date and other unobservable inputs including volatility, \nrights, and obligations of the securities we hold. \nAccounts Receivable and Allowances\nAccounts receivable are recorded and carried at the original invoiced amount less an allowance for any potential \nuncollectible amounts. We make estimates of expected credit and collectibility trends for the allowance for credit losses and \nallowance for unbilled receivables based upon our assessment of various factors, including historical experience, the age of \nthe accounts receivable balances, credit quality of our customers, current economic conditions, reasonable and supportable \nforecasts of future economic conditions, and other factors that may affect our ability to collect from customers. Expected \ncredit losses are recorded as general and administrative expenses on our consolidated statements of income. As of \nDecember 31, 2021 and 2020, the allowances for accounts receivable were immaterial. \nProperty and Equipment\nProperty and equipment, which includes amounts recorded under finance leases, which are amortized, are stated at cost \nless accumulated depreciation. Depreciation is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the \nassets or the remaining lease term, whichever is shorter.\n89"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 90}, page_content='The estimated useful lives of property and equipment and amortization periods of finance lease right-of-use assets are \ndescribed below: \nProperty and Equipment Useful Life/ Amortization period\nServers and network assets Four years\nBuildings 25 to 30 years\nEquipment and other One to 25 years\nFinance lease right-of-use assets Three to 20 years\nLeasehold improvements Lesser of estimated useful life or remaining lease term\nWe evaluate at least annually the recoverability of property and equipment for possible impairment whenever events or \ncircumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. If such review indicates that the \ncarrying amount of property and equipment assets is not recoverable, and the asset\'s fair value is less than the carrying \namount, an impairment charge is recognized. We have not recorded any material impairment charges during the years \npresented. \nThe useful lives of our property and equipment are determined by management when those assets are initially \nrecognized and are routinely reviewed for the remaining estimated useful lives. Our current estimate of useful lives represents \nthe best estimate of the useful lives based on current facts and circumstances, but may differ from the actual useful lives due \nto changes in future circumstances such as changes to our business operations, changes in the planned use of assets, and \ntechnological advancements. When we change the estimated useful life assumption for any asset, the remaining carrying \namount of the asset is accounted for prospectively and depreciated or amortized over the revised estimated useful life. See \nsection "Use of Estimates" above for additional information regarding changes in the estimated useful lives of our servers and \nnetwork assets.\nServers and network assets include property and equipment mostly in our data centers, which is used to support \nproduction traffic. Land and assets held within construction in progress are not depreciated. Construction in progress is \nrelated to the construction or development of property and equipment that have not yet been placed in service for their \nintended use.\nThe cost of maintenance and repairs is expensed as incurred. When assets are retired or otherwise disposed of, the cost \nand related accumulated depreciation are removed from their respective accounts, and any gain or loss on such sale or \ndisposal is reflected in income from operations.\nLease Obligations\nWe have operating leases comprised of certain offices, data centers, land, colocations, network infrastructure, and \nother equipment. We also have finance leases for certain network infrastructure. We determine if an arrangement is a lease at \ninception. Most of our leases contain lease and non-lease components. Non-lease components include fixed payments for \nmaintenance, utilities, real estate taxes, and management fees. We combine fixed lease and non-lease components and \naccount for them as a single lease component. Our lease agreements may contain variable costs such as contingent rent \nescalations, common area maintenance, insurance, real estate taxes, or other costs. Such variable lease costs are expensed as \nincurred on the consolidated statements of income. For certain colocation and equipment leases, we apply a portfolio \napproach to effectively account for the operating lease right-of-use (ROU) assets and lease liabilities.\nFor leases with a lease term greater than 12 months, ROU assets and lease liabilities are recognized on the \nconsolidated balance sheets at the commencement date based on the present value of the remaining fixed lease payments and \nincludes only payments that are fixed and determinable at the time of commencement. \nOur lease terms may include options to extend or terminate the lease when it is reasonably certain that we will exercise \nsuch options. When determining the probability of exercising such options, we consider contract-based, asset-based, entity-\nbased, and market-based factors.\n90'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 91}, page_content='As most of our leases do not provide an implicit rate, we use our incremental borrowing rate based on the information \navailable at the commencement date in determining the present value of lease payments. Our incremental borrowing rate is a \nhypothetical rate based on our understanding of what our credit rating would be in a similar economic environment.\nOperating leases are included in operating lease ROU assets, operating lease liabilities, current, and operating lease \nliabilities, non-current on our consolidated balance sheets. Finance leases are included in property and equipment, net, \naccrued expenses and other current liabilities, and other liabilities on our consolidated balance sheets.\nOperating lease costs are recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease terms. Finance lease assets are amortized on \na straight-line basis over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the assets or the lease terms.\nLoss Contingencies\nWe are involved in legal proceedings, claims, and regulatory, tax or government inquiries and investigations that arise \nin the ordinary course of business. Certain of these matters include speculative claims for substantial or indeterminate \namounts of damages. Additionally, we are required to comply with various legal and regulatory obligations around the world, \nand we regularly become subject to new laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which we operate. The requirements for \ncomplying with these obligations may be uncertain and subject to interpretation and enforcement by regulatory and other \nauthorities, and any failure to comply with such obligations could eventually lead to asserted legal or regulatory action. With \nrespect to these matters, asserted and unasserted, we evaluate the associated developments on a regular basis and accrue a \nliability when we believe that it is both probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated. If \nwe determine there is a reasonable possibility that we may incur a loss and the loss or range of loss can be reasonably \nestimated, we disclose the possible loss in the accompanying notes to the consolidated financial statements to the extent \nmaterial. \nWe review the developments in our contingencies that could affect the amount of the provisions that have been \npreviously recorded, and the matters and related reasonably possible losses disclosed. We make adjustments to our provisions \nand changes to our disclosures accordingly to reflect the merits of our defenses and the impact of negotiations, settlements, \nregulatory proceedings, rulings, advice of legal counsel, and updated information. Significant judgment is required to \ndetermine the probability of loss and the estimated amount of loss, including when and if the probability and estimate has \nchanged for asserted and unasserted matters. Certain factors, in particular, have resulted in significant changes to these \nestimates and judgments in prior quarters based on updated information available. For example, in certain jurisdictions where \nwe operate, fines and penalties may be the result of new laws and preliminary interpretations regarding the basis of assessing \ndamages, which may make it difficult to estimate what such fines and penalties would amount to if successfully asserted \nagainst us. In addition, certain government inquiries and investigations, such as matters before our lead European Union \nprivacy regulator, the IDPC, are subject to review by other regulatory bodies before decisions can be finalized, which can \nlead to significant changes in the outcome of an inquiry. As a result of these and other factors, we reasonably expect that our \nestimates and judgments with respect to our contingencies may continue to be revised in future quarters. \nBusiness Combinations\nWe allocate the fair value of purchase consideration to the tangible assets acquired, liabilities assumed and intangible \nassets acquired based on their estimated fair values. The excess of the fair value of purchase consideration over the fair values \nof these identifiable assets and liabilities is recorded as goodwill to reporting units based on the expected benefit from the \nbusiness combination. Allocation of purchase consideration to identifiable assets and liabilities affects the amortization \nexpense, as acquired finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over the useful life, whereas any indefinite-lived intangible \nassets, including goodwill, are not amortized. During the measurement period, which is not to exceed one year from the \nacquisition date, we record adjustments to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, with the corresponding offset to \ngoodwill. Upon the conclusion of the measurement period, any subsequent adjustments are recorded to earnings. Acquisition-\nrelated expenses are recognized separately from business combinations and are expensed as incurred.\nGoodwill and Intangibles Assets\nWe allocate goodwill to reporting units based on the expected benefit from business combinations. We evaluate our \nreporting units annually, as well as when changes in our operating segments occur. For changes in reporting units, we \nreassign goodwill using a relative fair value allocation approach. Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level \n91'), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 92}, page_content="annually or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances would more likely than not reduce the fair value of a \nreporting unit below its carrying value. We have two reporting units subject to goodwill impairment testing. As of \nDecember 31, 2021, no impairment of goodwill has been identified.\nWe evaluate the recoverability of finite-lived intangible assets for possible impairment whenever events or \ncircumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. The evaluation of these intangible \nassets are performed at the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other \nassets and liabilities. Recoverability of these assets is measured by a comparison of the carrying amounts to the future \nundiscounted cash flows the assets are expected to generate from the use and eventual disposition. If such review indicates \nthat the carrying amount of finite-lived intangible assets is not recoverable, and the assets fair value is less than the carrying \namount, an impairment charge is recognized. We have not recorded any material impairment charges during the years \npresented.\nOur finite-lived intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets. \nIndefinite-lived intangible assets are not amortized. If an indefinite-lived intangible asset is subsequently determined to have \na finite useful life, the asset will be tested for impairment and accounted for as a finite-lived intangible asset prospectively \nover its estimated remaining useful life. We routinely review the remaining estimated useful lives of finite-lived intangible \nassets. If we change the estimated useful life assumption for any asset, the remaining unamortized balance is amortized over \nthe revised estimated useful life.\nForeign Currency\nGenerally, the functional currency of our international subsidiaries is the local currency. We translate the financial \nstatements of these subsidiaries to U.S. dollars using month-end rates of exchange for assets and liabilities, and average rates \nof exchange for revenue, costs, and expenses. Translation gains and losses are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive \nincome (loss) as a component of stockholders' equity. As of December 31, 2021, we had a cumulative translation loss, net of \ntax of $677 million and as of December 31, 2020, we had a cumulative translation gain, net of tax of $439 million. \nForeign currency transaction gains and losses from transactions denominated in a currency other than the functional \ncurrency of the subsidiary involved are recorded within interest and other income, net on our consolidated statements of \nincome. Net losses resulting from foreign currency transactions were $140 million, $129 million, and $105 million for the \nyears ended December 31, 2021, 2020, and 2019, respectively.\nCredit Risk and Concentration\nOur financial instruments that are potentially subject to concentrations of credit risk consist primarily of cash, cash \nequivalents, restricted cash, marketable securities, and accounts receivable. The majority of cash equivalents consists of \nmoney market funds, that primarily invest in U.S. government and agency securities. Marketable securities consist of \ninvestments in U.S. government securities, U.S. government agency securities, and investment grade corporate debt \nsecurities. Our investment portfolio in corporate debt securities is highly liquid and diversified among individual issuers. The \namount of credit losses recorded for the year ended December 31, 2021 was not material.\nAccounts receivable are typically unsecured and are derived from revenue earned from customers across different \nindustries and countries. We generated 41%, 42%, and 43% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020, \nand 2019, respectively, from marketers and developers based in the United States, with the majority of revenue outside of the \nUnited States coming from customers located in western Europe, China, Canada, Australia, Brazil, and Thailand.\nWe perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers and generally do not require collateral. We maintain an \nallowance for estimated credit losses, and bad debt expense on these losses was not material during the years ended \nDecember 31, 2021, 2020, or 2019. In the event that accounts receivable collection cycles deteriorate, our operating results \nand financial position could be adversely affected.\nNo customer represented 10% or more of total revenue during the years ended December 31, 2021, 2020, and 2019.\n92"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 93}, page_content="Recently Adopted Accounting Pronouncements\nOn January 1, 2021, we adopted Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2020-01, Investments—Equity Securities \n(Topic 321), Investments—Equity Method and Joint Ventures (Topic 323), and Derivatives and Hedging (Topic 815) (ASU \n2020-01), which clarifies the interaction of the accounting for equity securities under Topic 321, the accounting for equity \nmethod investments in Topic 323, and the accounting for certain forward contracts and purchased options in Topic 815. The \nadoption of this new standard did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.\nOn October 1, 2021, we early adopted ASU No. 2020-06, Debt—Debt with Conversion and Other Options (Subtopic \n470-20) and Derivatives and Hedging—Contracts in Entity's Own Equity (Subtopic 815-40): Accounting for Convertible\nInstruments and Contracts in an Entity’s Own Equity (ASU 2020-06), which simplifies the accounting for convertible\ninstruments by reducing the number of accounting models available for convertible debt instruments. This guidance also\neliminates the treasury stock method to calculate diluted earnings per share for convertible instruments and requires the use of\nthe if-converted method. The new standard was effective for us beginning January 1, 2022, with early adoption permitted.\nThe adoption of this new standard did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.\nOn October 1, 2021, we early adopted ASU No. 2021-05, Leases (Topic 842): Lessors – Certain Leases with Variable \nLease Payments (ASU 2016-02), which requires a lessor to classify a lease with variable lease payments that do not depend \non an index or rate as an operating lease if specified criteria are met. The new standard was effective for us beginning \nJanuary 1, 2022, with early adoption permitted. The adoption of this new standard did not have a material impact on our \nconsolidated financial statements. \nAccounting Pronouncements Not Yet Adopted\nIn October 2021, the FASB issued ASU No. 2021-08, Business Combinations (Topic 805): Accounting for Contract \nAssets and Contract Liabilities from Contracts with Customers (ASU 2021-08), which clarifies that an acquirer of a business \nshould recognize and measure contract assets and contract liabilities in a business combination in accordance with \nAccounting Standards Codification (ASC) Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606). This guidance \nwill be effective for us in the first quarter of 2023 on a prospective basis, with early adoption permitted. We are currently \nevaluating the impact of the new guidance on our consolidated financial statements.\nIn November 2021, the FASB issued ASU No. 2021-10, Government Assistance (Topic 832): Disclosure by Business \nEntities about Government Assistance (ASU 2021-10), which improves the transparency of government assistance received \nby most business entities by requiring the disclosure of: (1) the types of government assistance received; (2) the accounting \nfor such assistance; and (3) the effect of the assistance on a business entity's financial statements. This guidance will be \neffective for us in the year ended December 31, 2022, with early adoption permitted. We are currently evaluating the impact \nof the new guidance on our consolidated financial statements.\nNote 2. Earnings per Share\nWe compute earnings per share (EPS) of Class A and Class B common stock using the two-class method. As the \nliquidation and dividend rights for both Class A and Class B common stock are identical, the undistributed earnings are \nallocated on a proportionate basis to the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period. Basic EPS is \ncomputed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of shares of our Class A and Class B common stock \noutstanding.\nFor the calculation of diluted EPS, net income for basic EPS is adjusted by the effect of dilutive securities, including \nawards under our equity compensation plans.\nIn addition, the computation of the diluted EPS of Class A common stock assumes the conversion of our Class B \ncommon stock to Class A common stock, while the diluted EPS of Class B common stock does not assume the conversion of \nthose shares to Class A common stock. Goodwill and Intangible Assets\nDuring the year ended December 31, 2021, we purchased certain intangible assets and completed several business \nacquisitions that were not material to our consolidated financial statements, individually and in aggregate. These \ntwo actions subsequently were transferred and consolidated in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California \nwith the putative securities class action described above relating to our platform and user data practices. On September 25, \n2019, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the consolidated putative securities class action, with leave to amend. \nOn November 15, 2019, a second amended complaint was filed in the consolidated putative securities class action. On \nAugust 7, 2020, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the second amended complaint, with leave to amend. On \nOctober 16, 2020, a third amended complaint was filed in the consolidated putative securities class action. On December 20, \n2021, the district court granted our motion to dismiss the third amended complaint, with prejudice. On January 17, 2022, the \nplaintiffs filed a notice of appeal of the order dismissing their case. In addition, our platform and user data practices, as well \nas the events surrounding the misuse of certain data by a developer, became the subject of U.S. Federal Trade Commission \n(FTC), state attorneys general, and other government inquiries in the United States, Europe, and other jurisdictions. We \nentered into a settlement and modified consent order to resolve the FTC inquiry, which took effect in April 2020. Among \nother matters, our settlement with the FTC required us to pay a penalty of $5.0 billion which was paid in April 2020 upon the \neffectiveness of the modified consent order. The state attorneys general inquiry and certain government inquiries in other \njurisdictions remain ongoing. On July 16, 2021, a stockholder derivative action was filed in Delaware Chancery Court against \ncertain of our directors and officers asserting breach of fiduciary duty and related claims relating to our historical platform \nand user data practices, as well as our settlement with the FTC. On July 20, 2021, other stockholders filed an amended \nderivative complaint in a related Delaware Chancery Court action, asserting breach of fiduciary duty and related claims \nagainst certain of our current and former directors and officers in connection with our historical platform and user data \npractices. On November 4, 2021, the lead plaintiffs filed a second amended and consolidated complaint in the stockholder \nderivative action. We believe the lawsuits described above are without merit, and we are vigorously defending them.\nWe also notify the Irish Data Protection Commission (IDPC), our lead European Union privacy regulator under the \nGeneral Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), of certain other personal data breaches and privacy issues, and are subject to \ninquiries and investigations by the IDPC and other European regulators regarding various aspects of our regulatory \ncompliance. The GDPR is still a relatively new law and draft decisions in investigations by the IDPC are subject to review by \nother European privacy regulators as part of the GDPR's consistency mechanism, which may lead to significant changes in \nthe final outcome of such investigations. As a result, the interpretation and enforcement of the GDPR, as well as the \nimposition and amount of penalties for non-compliance, are subject to significant uncertainty. Although we are vigorously \ndefending our regulatory compliance, we have accrued significant amounts for loss contingencies related to these inquiries \nand investigations in Europe, and we believe there is a reasonable possibility that additional accruals for losses related to \nthese matters could be material in the aggregate.\nWe are also subject to other government inquiries and investigations relating to our business activities and disclosure \npractices.
