With respect to the matters \ndescribed above that do not include an estimate of the amount of loss or range of possible loss, such losses or range of \npossible losses either cannot be estimated or are not individually material, but we believe there is a reasonable possibility that \nthey may be material in the aggregate.\nWe are also party to various other legal proceedings, claims, and regulatory, tax or government inquiries and \ninvestigations that arise in the ordinary course of business. For example, we are subject to various litigation and government \ninquiries and investigations, formal or informal, by competition authorities in the United States, Europe, and other \njurisdictions. Such investigations, inquiries, and lawsuits concern, among other things, our business practices in the areas of \nsocial networking or social media services, digital advertising, and/or mobile or online applications, as well as our \nacquisitions. For example, in June 2019 we were informed by the FTC that it had opened an antitrust investigation of our \ncompany. On December 9, 2020, the FTC filed a complaint against us in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia \nalleging that we engaged in anticompetitive conduct and unfair methods of competition in violation of Section 5 of the \nFederal Trade Commission Act and Section 2 of the Sherman Act, including by acquiring Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp \nin 2014 and by maintaining conditions on access to our platform. In addition, beginning in the third quarter of 2019, we \nbecame the subject of antitrust investigations by the U.S. Department of Justice and state attorneys general. On December 9, \n2020, the attorneys general from 46 states, the territory of Guam, and the District of Columbia filed a complaint against us in \nthe U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia alleging that we engaged in anticompetitive conduct in violation of \nSection 2 of the Sherman Act, including by acquiring Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 and by maintaining \nconditions on access to our platform. The complaint also alleged that we violated Section 7 of the Clayton Act by acquiring \nInstagram and WhatsApp. The complaints of the FTC and attorneys general both sought a permanent injunction against our \ncompany's alleged violations of the antitrust laws, and other equitable relief, including divestiture or reconstruction of \nInstagram and WhatsApp. On June 28, 2021, the court granted our motions to dismiss the complaints filed by the FTC and \nattorneys general, dismissing the FTC's complaint with leave to amend and dismissing the attorneys general's case without \nprejudice. On July 28, 2021, the attorneys general filed a notice of appeal of the order dismissing their case. On August 19, \n2021, the FTC filed an amended complaint, and on October 4, 2021, we filed a motion to dismiss this amended complaint. On \nJanuary 11, 2022, the court denied our motion to dismiss the FTC's amended complaint. Multiple putative class actions have \nalso been filed in state and federal courts in the United States against us alleging violations of antitrust laws and other causes \nof action in connection with these acquisitions and other alleged anticompetitive conduct, and seeking damages and \nunspecified injunctive relief. Several of the cases brought on behalf of certain advertisers and users were consolidated in the \nU.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. On January 14, 2022, the court granted, in part, and denied, in part, \nour motion to dismiss the consolidated actions. We believe these lawsuits are without merit, and we are vigorously defending \nthem. \nAdditionally, we are required to comply with various legal and regulatory obligations around the world. The \nrequirements for complying with these obligations may be uncertain and subject to interpretation and enforcement by \nregulatory and other authorities, and any failure to comply with such obligations could eventually lead to asserted legal or \nregulatory action. With respect to these other legal proceedings, claims, regulatory, tax, or government inquiries and \ninvestigations, and other matters, asserted and unasserted, we evaluate the associated developments on a regular basis and \naccrue a liability when we believe a loss is probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated. In addition, we believe \nthere is a reasonable possibility that we may incur a loss in some of these other matters. We believe that the amount of losses \nor any estimable range of possible losses with respect to these other matters will not, either individually or in the aggregate, \nhave a material adverse effect on our business and consolidated financial statements. \nThe ultimate outcome of the legal and related matters described in this section, such as whether the likelihood of loss is \nremote, reasonably possible, or probable, or if and when the reasonably possible range of loss is estimable, is inherently \nuncertain. Therefore, if one or more of these matters were resolved against us for amounts in excess of management's \nestimates of loss, our results of operations and financial condition, including in a particular reporting period in which any \nsuch outcome becomes probable and estimable, could be materially adversely affected.\nFor information regarding income tax contingencies, see Note 14 — Income Taxes.\n103"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 104}, page_content="Indemnifications\nIn the normal course of business, to facilitate transactions of services and products, we have agreed to indemnify \ncertain parties with respect to certain matters. We have agreed to hold certain parties harmless against losses arising from a \nbreach of representations or covenants, or out of intellectual property infringement or other claims made by third parties. \nThese agreements may limit the time within which an indemnification claim can be made and the amount of the claim. In \naddition, we have entered into indemnification agreements with our officers, directors, and certain employees, and our \ncertificate of incorporation and bylaws contain similar indemnification obligations. \nIt is not possible to determine the maximum potential amount under these indemnification agreements due to the \nlimited history of prior indemnification claims and the unique facts and circumstances involved in each particular agreement. \nHistorically, payments made by us under these agreements have not had a material impact on our consolidated financial \nstatements. Stockholders' Equity\nCommon Stock\nOur certificate of incorporation authorizes the issuance of Class A common stock and Class B common stock. As of \nDecember 31, 2021, we are authorized to issue 5,000 million shares of Class A common stock and 4,141 million shares of \nClass B common stock, each with a par value of $0.000006 per share. Holders of our Class A common stock and Class B \ncommon stock are entitled to dividends when, as and if, declared by our board of directors, subject to the rights of the holders \nof all classes of stock outstanding having priority rights to dividends. As of December 31, 2021, we have not declared any \ndividends. The holder of each share of Class A common stock is entitled to one vote, while the holder of each share of \nClass B common stock is entitled to ten votes. Shares of our Class B common stock are convertible into an equivalent number \nof shares of our Class A common stock and generally convert into shares of our Class A common stock upon transfer. \nClass A common stock and Class B common stock are referred to as common stock throughout the notes to these financial \nstatements, unless otherwise noted.\nAs of December 31, 2021, there were 2,328 million shares of Class A common stock and 413 million shares of Class B \ncommon stock issued and outstanding.\nShare Repurchase Program\nOur board of directors has authorized a share repurchase program of our Class A common stock, which commenced in \nJanuary 2017 and does not have an expiration date. As of December 31, 2020, $8.60 billion remained available and \nauthorized for repurchases under this program. In January 2021 and October 2021, additional $25.0 billion and $50.0 billion \nof repurchases were authorized under this program, respectively. In 2021, we repurchased and subsequently retired \n136 million shares of our Class A common stock for an aggregate amount of $44.81 billion. As of December 31, 2021, \n$38.79 billion remained available and authorized for repurchases. \nThe timing and actual number of shares repurchased under the repurchase program depend on a variety of factors, \nincluding price, general business and market conditions, and other investment opportunities, and shares may be repurchased \nthrough open market purchases or privately negotiated transactions, including through the use of trading plans intended to \nqualify under Rule 10b5-1 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. \nShare-based Compensation Plans\nSince 2020, we have maintained one active share-based employee compensation plan, the 2012 Equity Incentive Plan, \nwhich was amended in each of June 2016, February 2018 (Amended 2012 Plan). During all years presented, we recognized interest and penalties related to \nunrecognized tax benefits within the provision for income taxes on the consolidated statements of income. The amount of \ninterest and penalties accrued as of December 31, 2021 and 2020 were $960 million and $774 million, respectively.\nIf the balance of gross unrecognized tax benefits of $9.81 billion as of December 31, 2021 were realized in a future \nperiod, this would result in a tax benefit of $5.70 billion within our provision of income taxes at such time.\nWe are subject to taxation in the United States and various other state and foreign jurisdictions. The material \njurisdictions in which we are subject to potential examination include the United States and Ireland. We are under \nexamination by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for our 2014 through 2019 tax years and by the Irish tax authorities for \nour 2016 through 2018 tax years. Our 2020 and subsequent tax years remain open to examination by the IRS. Our 2019 and \nsubsequent tax years remain open to examination in Ireland.\nIn July 2016, we received a Statutory Notice of Deficiency (Notice) from the IRS related to transfer pricing with our \nforeign subsidiaries in conjunction with the examination of the 2010 tax year. While the Notice applies only to the 2010 tax \nyear, the IRS stated that it will also apply its position for tax years subsequent to 2010 and has done so in years covered by \nthe second Notice described below. We do not agree with the position of the IRS and have filed a petition in the Tax Court \nchallenging the Notice. On January 15, 2020, the IRS's amendment to answer was filed stating that it planned to assert at trial \nan adjustment that is higher than the adjustment stated in the Notice. The first session of the trial was completed in March \n2020 and a second session commenced in October 2021. Based on the information provided, we believe that, if the IRS \nprevails in its updated position, this could result in an additional federal tax liability of an estimated, aggregate amount of up \nto approximately $9.0 billion in excess of the amounts in our originally filed U.S. return, plus interest and any penalties \nasserted. \nIn March 2018, we received a second Notice from the IRS in conjunction with the examination of our 2011 through \n2013 tax years. The IRS applied its position from the 2010 tax year to each of these years and also proposed new adjustments \nrelated to other transfer pricing with our foreign subsidiaries and certain tax credits that we claimed. If the IRS prevails in its \nposition for these new adjustments, this could result in an additional federal tax liability of up to approximately $680 million \nin excess of the amounts in our originally filed U.S. returns, plus interest and any penalties asserted. We do not agree with the \npositions of the IRS in the second Notice and have filed a petition in the Tax Court challenging the second Notice. \nWe have previously accrued an estimated unrecognized tax benefit consistent with the guidance in ASC 740, Income \nTaxes (ASC 740), that is lower than the potential additional federal tax liability from the positions taken by the IRS in the two \nNotices and its Pretrial Memorandum. In addition, if the IRS prevails in its positions related to transfer pricing with our \nforeign subsidiaries, the additional tax that we would owe would be partially offset by a reduction in the tax that we owe \nunder the mandatory transition tax on accumulated foreign earnings from the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. As of \nDecember 31, 2021, we have not resolved these matters and proceedings continue in the Tax Court.\nWe believe that adequate amounts have been reserved in accordance with ASC 740 for any adjustments to the \nprovision for income taxes or other tax items that may ultimately result from these examinations. The timing of the \nresolution, settlement, and closure of any audits is highly uncertain, and it is reasonably possible that the balance of gross \nunrecognized tax benefits could significantly change in the next 12 months. Given the number of years remaining that are \nsubject to examination, we are unable to estimate the full range of possible adjustments to the balance of gross unrecognized \ntax benefits. If the taxing authorities prevail in the assessment of additional tax due, the assessed tax, interest, and penalties, if \nany, could have a material adverse impact on our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows.\nNote 15. Segment and Geographical Information\nBeginning in the fourth quarter of 2021, we report our financial results based on two reportable segments: Family of \nApps (FoA) and Reality Labs (RL). FoA includes Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, WhatsApp, and other services. RL \nincludes augmented and virtual reality related consumer hardware, software, and content. As of December 31, 2021 , our \noperating segments are the same as our reportable segments.\nThe CODM, who is our CEO, allocates resources to and assesses the performance of each operating segment using \ninformation about the operating segment's revenue and income (loss) from operations. The CODM does not evaluate \noperating segments using asset or liability information.\n108"), Document(metadata={'source': './meta.pdf', 'page': 109}, page_content='Revenue and costs and expenses are generally directly attributed to our segments. These costs and expenses include \ncertain product development related operating expenses, costs associated with the partnership arrangements, consumer \nhardware product costs, content costs, and legal-related costs. Indirect costs are allocated to segments based on a reasonable \nallocation methodology, when such costs are significant to the performance measures of the operating segments. Controls and Procedures\nEvaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures\nOur management, with the participation of our chief executive officer (CEO) and chief financial officer (CFO), has \nevaluated the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules 13a- 15(e) and 15d- 15(e) under the \nSecurities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (Exchange Act)), as of the end of the period covered by this Annual Report on \nForm 10-K. Based on such evaluation, our CEO and CFO have concluded that as of December 31, 2021, our disclosure \ncontrols and procedures are designed at a reasonable assurance level and are effective to provide reasonable assurance that \ninformation we are required to disclose in reports that we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, \nsummarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the rules and forms of the Securities and Exchange \nCommission (SEC), and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our CEO and \nCFO, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.\nManagement's Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting\nOur management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (as \ndefined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Exchange Act). Management conducted an assessment of the effectiveness of our internal \ncontrol over financial reporting based on the criteria set forth in Internal Control—Integrated Framework issued by the \nCommittee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework). Based on the assessment, \nmanagement has concluded that its internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2021 to provide \nreasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements in accordance \nwith U.S. GAAP. Our independent registered public accounting firm, Ernst & Young LLP, has issued an audit report with \nrespect to our internal control over financial reporting, which appears in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.\nChanges in Internal Control\nThere were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting identified in management's evaluation pursuant \nto Rules 13a-15(d) or 15d-15(d) of the Exchange Act during the fourth quarter of 2021 that materially affected, or are \nreasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.\nLimitations on Effectiveness of Controls and Procedures and Internal Control over Financial Reporting\nIn designing and evaluating the disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting, \nmanagement recognizes that any controls and procedures, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only \nreasonable assurance of achieving the desired control objectives.
